John Barrasso, the chairman of the GOP conference, and Trump has accepted, according to two people familiar with the planning who requested anonymity to discuss the closed-door meeting. The meeting will be held in a location away from the Capitol, as is common practice for campaign-related events.\n\nThe gathering will be the first time that Trump has met with the GOP conference since he was president, and the first time since the attack by his supporters on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The meeting was first reported by NBC News.\n\nMany senators who had criticized Trump after the attack have now endorsed his run for the presidency, including Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell and other members of Senate leadership.\n\nThe GOP Senate conference was also uniformly supportive of Trump after the May 31 hush money verdict, with many of them joining Trump's criticism of the judge and jury. The verdict made Trump the first former American president found guilty of felony crimes when a New York jury convicted him on all charges in a scheme to influence the 2016 election with a hush money payment to a porn actor.\n\nInstead of distancing themselves from Trump, Republicans have rallied around him in hopes that voters will believe that the jury verdict in the New York court was a form of political retribution. Some senators attended the trial to show their support for Trump.\n\nTrump is expected to appeal last month's conviction on all 34 charges.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-06-388787484", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "19:45:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T19:45:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T08:19:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.rocketcitynow.com/article/news/nation-world/trump-capitol-hill-visit/507-45897b72-7150-41d7-94be-394bb09f1e06", "title": "Trump returns to Capitol Hill and meets with Republican lawmakers, a first since Jan. 6 attack", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Donald Trump made a triumphant return Thursday to Capitol Hill, whipping up House and Senate Republicans in his first meetings since the Jan.6, 2021, attacks. He was embraced by GOP lawmakers who find themselves newly energized by his bid to retake the White House.\n\nDespite pending federal charges against Trump for conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, and his recent guilty verdict in an unrelated hush money trial, the Republican former president arrived emboldened as the party's presumptive nominee. He has successfully purged the GOP of critics, silenced most skeptics and enticed once-critical lawmakers aboard his MAGA-fueled campaign.\n\nA packed room of House Republicans sang \"Happy Birthday\" to Trump in a private breakfast meeting at GOP campaign headquarters across the street from the Capitol. The lawmakers gave him a baseball and bat from the annual congressional game. Trump bragged that even his telephone rallies for lawmakers could draw bigger crowds than mega-popstar Taylor Swift, who has yet to make any endorsement.\n\n\"There's tremendous unity in the Republican Party,\" Trump said in brief remarks later at Senate GOP headquarters.\n\nTrump spent about an hour each with House and Senate Republicans delivering free-wheeling remarks, fielding questions and discussing issues -- including Russia and immigration, tax cuts and other priorities for a potential second term.\n\nDuring the morning session, Trump said he thinks House Speaker Mike Johnson is doing a \"terrific job,\" according to a Republican in the private breakfast meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it. Trump asked Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, the speaker's chief Republican critic, if she was being \"nice\" to Johnson, another Republican said.\n\n\"President Trump brought an extraordinary amount of energy, excitement and enthusiasm this morning,\" Johnson said afterward, noting high fund-raising tallies since the guilty verdict. \"We're feeling good.\"\n\nThe Republican speaker had demurred earlier over whether he's asked Trump to respect the peaceful transfer of presidential power and commit to not doing another Jan. 6. \"Of course he respects that, we all do, and we've all talked about it, ad nauseum.\"\n\nThursday afternoon offered the first encounter in years between Trump and Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell, who once blamed Trump for the \"disgraceful\" attack that he called an \"insurrection\" but now endorses the party's presumptive nominee.\n\nMcConnell said Trump received standing ovations from the senators and the two \"had a really positive meeting.\" The senator said, \"He and I got a chance to talk a little bit, shook hands a few times.\"\n\nMany potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\nOn one major controversial issue, Trump told lawmakers that abortion rules should be left to the states and said he supported exceptions for rape, incest and to save the life of the mother, lawmakers said.\n\n\"Anybody who thought that this president was going to be down after the sham trial. it's only giving him even more energy,\" said Rep. Tom Emmer, the GOP whip. \"Donald Trump is crushing this election.\"\n\nBut Trump's private meetings with House and Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol were infused with the symbolism of his return as the U.S. president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of power.\n\n\"It's frustrating,\" said former U.S. Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of Jan. 6, the day when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building in an effort to overturn President Joe Biden's election.\n\nDunn spoke of the \"irony\" of Trump returning to the area and lawmakers now embracing him. \"It just shows the lack of backbone they have when they're truly putting party and person over country,\" he said. \"And it's sad.\"\n\nBiden was overseas Thursday attending a summit of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations, but the president's campaign unveiled a new ad blaming Trump for lighting the \"fire\" of Jan. 6 and threatening democracy.\n\nMany of those who once stood up to Trump are long gone from office and the Republicans who remain seem increasingly enthusiastic about the possibility of him retaking the White House, and the down-ballot windfall that could mean for their own GOP majorities in Congress.\n\nSen. John Thune, the GOP whip who is vying to replace McConnell as leader, told The Associated Press that he was interested in hearing from Trump about the fall election. \"I think there's an opportunity there to really make this a big win,\" he said.\n\nAs democracies around the world come under threat from a far-rightward shift, some analysts warn that the U.S. system, once seemingly immune from authoritarian impulses, is at risk of populist and extremist forces like those that Trump inspired to sack the Capitol.\n\n\"This is just another example of House Republicans bending the knee to Donald Trump,\" said Rep. Pete Aguilar of California, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus.\n\nMaking Jan. 6 a cornerstone of his reelection campaign, Trump celebrates those who stormed the Capitol as \"warriors\" and \"patriots,\" and he has vowed to pardon any number of the more than 1,300 convicted of crimes for the assault on the seat of U.S. democracy.\n\nMoreover, Trump has vowed to seek retribution by ousting officials at the U.S. Justice Department, which is prosecuting him in a four-count indictment to overturn the election ahead of the Jan. 6 attack and another case over storing classified documents at his Mar-A-Largo home.\n\nRepublicans, particularly in the House but increasingly in the Senate, are vigorously following his lead, complaining of an unfair justice system. Alongside Trump, the House and Senate GOP campaign arms scored some of their highest fundraising periods yet after a jury found him guilty in the New York hush money case.\n\nWhen former GOP Speaker Paul Ryan on Fox News reiterated this week that he wouldn't be voting for Trump and wished Republicans had another choice for president, he was immediately ostracized by Trump allies.\n\n\"Paul Ryan, you're a piece of garbage,\" said Rep. Troy Nehls, R-Texas. \"We should kick you out of the party.\"\n\nOf the Republicans who voted to impeach Trump over Jan. 6 and convict him on the charge of inciting the insurrection, only a few remain in office.\n\nSen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, and Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, had not been expected to attend Thursday's closed-door session with Trump. But Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, had a change of plans and was to join.\n\nAlso Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., said he would likely join the Trump meeting, expecting \"he's going to be the next president, so you have to work\" together.\n\nAsked if he was concerned about the direction of the Trump Republican Party, Cassidy said: \"Let the day's own troubles be sufficient for the day. You can fill yourself up with anxiety about tomorrow, but will it change a thing? No.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Jill Colvin, Farnoush Amiri and Mary Clare Jalonick contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "rocketcitynow.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8176625887", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "19:53:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T19:53:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T19:45:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/trump-returns-to-capitol-hill-and-whips-up-republican-lawmakers-in-first-meeting-since-jan/article_7f4209d0-130d-58ba-8568-481e6ce3b101.html", "title": "Trump returns to Capitol Hill and whips up Republican lawmakers in first meeting since Jan. 6 attack", "body": "Republican presidential candidate former President Donald Trump speaks with reporters at the National Republican Senatorial Committee, Thursday, June 13, 2024, in Washington.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Donald Trump made a triumphant return to Capitol Hill on Thursday, his first with lawmakers since the Jan.6, 2021 attacks, embraced by energized House and Senate Republicans who find themelves reinvigorated by his bid to retake the White House.\n\nDespite pending federal charges against Trump for conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, and his recent guilty verdict in an unrelated hush money trial, the Republican former president arrived emboldened as the party's presumptive nominee. He has successfully purged the GOP of critics, silenced most skeptics and enticed once-critical lawmakers aboard his MAGA-fueled campaign.\n\nA packed room of House Republicans sang \"Happy Birthday\" to Trump in a private breakfast meeting at GOP campaign headquarters across the street from the Capitol. The lawmakers gave him a baseball and bat from the annual congressional game, and senators later presented an American flag cake with \"45\" candles -- and then \"47\" -- referring to the next presidency. Trump bragged that even his telephone rallies for lawmakers could draw bigger crowds than mega-popstar Taylor Swift, who has yet to make any endorsement.\n\nIn one remarkable moment, Trump and his most prominent Republican critic, Senate GOP leader Mitch McConnell, shook hands, and fist-bumped.\n\n\"There's tremendous unity in the Republican Party,\" Trump said in brief remarks at Senate GOP headquarters.\n\nTrump spent about an hour each with House and Senate Republicans delivering free-wheeling remarks, fielding questions and discussing issues -- including Russia and immigration, tax cuts and other priorities for a potential second term.\n\nDuring the morning session, Trump said he thinks House Speaker Mike Johnson is doing a \"terrific job,\" according to a Republican in the private meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it. Trump asked Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, the speaker's chief Republican critic, if she was being \"nice\" to Johnson, another Republican said.\n\n\"President Trump brought an extraordinary amount of energy, excitement and enthusiasm this morning,\" Johnson said afterward, noting high fund-raising tallies since the guilty verdict. \"We're feeling good.\"\n\nThe Republican speaker had demurred earlier over whether he's asked Trump to respect the peaceful transfer of presidential power and commit to not doing another Jan. 6. \"Of course he respects that, we all do, and we've all talked about it, ad nauseum.\"\n\nMany potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\n\"Anybody who thought that this president was going to be down after the sham trial. it's only giving him even more energy,\" said Rep. Tom Emmer, the GOP whip. \"Donald Trump is crushing this election.\"\n\nBut Trump's private meetings with House and Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol were infused with the symbolism of his return as the U.S. president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of power.\n\n\"It's frustrating,\" said former U.S. Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of Jan. 6, the day when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building in an effort to overturn President Joe Biden's election.\n\nDunn spoke of the \"irony\" of Trump returning to the area and lawmakers now embracing him. \"It just shows the lack of backbone they have when they're truly putting party and person over country,\" he said. \"And it's sad.\"\n\nBiden was overseas Thursday attending a summit of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations, but the president's campaign unveiled a new ad blaming Trump for lighting the \"fire\" of Jan. 6 and threatening democracy.\n\nMany of those who once stood up to Trump are long gone from office and the Republicans who remain seem increasingly enthusiastic about the possibility of him retaking the White House, and the down-ballot windfall that could mean for their own GOP majorities in Congress.\n\nThursday afternoon offered the first encounter in years between Trump and McConnell, who once blamed Trump for the \"disgraceful\" attack that he called an \"insurrection\" but now endorses the party's presumptive nominee.\n\nAccording to Sen. John Barrasso, R-Wyo., who organized the conference meeting, after Trump addressed the group McConnell gave a thumbs up and the two approached each other and exchanged the fist-bump.\n\n\"We had a really positive meeting,\" McConnell said. \"He and I got a chance to talk a little bit, shook hands a few times.\"\n\nAs democracies around the world come under threat from a far-rightward shift, some analysts warn that the U.S. system, once seemingly immune from authoritarian impulses, is at risk of populist and extremist forces like those that Trump inspired to sack the Capitol.\n\n\"This is just another example of House Republicans bending the knee to Donald Trump,\" said Rep. Pete Aguilar of California, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus.\n\nMaking Jan. 6 a cornerstone of his reelection campaign, Trump celebrates those who stormed the Capitol as \"warriors\" and \"patriots,\" and he has vowed to pardon any number of the more than 1,300 convicted of crimes for the assault on the seat of U.S. democracy.\n\nMoreover, Trump has vowed to seek retribution by ousting officials at the U.S. Justice Department, which is prosecuting him in a four-count indictment to overturn the election ahead of the Jan. 6 attack and another case over storing classified documents at his Mar-A-Largo home.\n\nRepublicans, particularly in the House but increasingly in the Senate, are vigorously following his lead, complaining of an unfair justice system. It's having noticeable results: the House and Senate GOP campaign arms scored some of their highest fundraising periods yet after a jury found him guilty in the New York hush money case.\n\nWhen former GOP Speaker Paul Ryan on Fox News reiterated this week that he wouldn't be voting for Trump and wished Republicans had another choice for president, he was immediately ostracized by Trump allies.\n\n\"Paul Ryan, you're a piece of garbage,\" said Rep. Troy Nehls, R-Texas. \"We should kick you out of the party.\"\n\nOf the Republicans who voted to impeach Trump over Jan. 6 and convict him on the charge of inciting the insurrection, only a few remain in office.\n\nSen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, and Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, had not been expected to attend Thursday's closed-door session with Trump. But Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, had a change of plans and was to join.\n\nAlso Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., joined join the Trump meeting, expecting \"he's going to be the next president, so you have to work\" together.\n\nAsked if he was concerned about the direction of the Trump Republican Party, Cassidy said: \"Let the day's own troubles be sufficient for the day. You can fill yourself up with anxiety about tomorrow, but will it change a thing? No.\"\n\nAssociated Press writers Jill Colvin, Farnoush Amiri, Kevin Freking, Mary Clare Jalonick and Stephen Groves contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-06-388602568", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:02:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:02:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T08:19:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.weareiowa.com/article/news/nation-world/trump-capitol-hill-visit/507-45897b72-7150-41d7-94be-394bb09f1e06", "title": "Trump returns to Capitol Hill and meets with Republican lawmakers, a first since Jan. 6 attack", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Donald Trump is making a triumphant return to Capitol Hill on Thursday, meeting with House and Senate Republicans, his first since urging a mob to \"fight like hell\" ahead of the Jan.6, 2021 attack. GOP lawmakers find themselves newly energized and reinvigorated by his bid to retake the White House.\n\nDespite the federal charges against Trump for conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, and his recent guilty verdict in an unrelated hush money trial, the Republican former president arrived emboldened as the party's presumptive nominee. He has successfully purged the GOP of critics, silenced most skeptics and enticed once-critical lawmakers aboard his MAGA-fueled campaign.\n\nA packed room of House Republicans sang \"Happy Birthday\" to Trump in the private breakfast meeting at GOP campaign headquarters across the street from the Capitol. The lawmakers gave him a baseball and bat from the annual congressional game.\n\n\"We're excited to welcome President Trump back,\" said House Speaker Mike Johnson a day earlier.\n\nThe Republican speaker had demurred over whether he's asked Trump to respect the peaceful transfer of presidential power and commit to not doing another Jan. 6. \"Of course he respects that, we all do, and we've all talked about it, ad nauseum.\"\n\nTrump told Johnson Thursday he thinks the speaker is doing a \"terrific job,\" according to a Republican in the private meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it. Trump asked Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, the speaker's chief Republican critic, if she was being nice to Johnson, another Republican said.\n\nTrump is expected to be delivering remarks and discussing issues animating his campaign -- including mass immigration deportations but also tax cuts and other priorities for a potential second term.\n\nMany potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, that are laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\nBut the private meetings with House and later in the afternoon Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol are infused with symbolism of Trump's return as the U.S. president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of presidential power.\n\n\"It's frustrating,\" said former U.S. Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of Jan. 6, when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building trying to overturn President Joe Biden's election.\n\nDunn spoke of the \"irony\" of Trump returning to the area and lawmakers now embracing him. \"It just shows the lack of backbone they have when they're truly putting party and person over country,\" he said. \"And it's sad.\"\n\nBiden was overseas Thursday attending a summit of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations, but the president's campaign unveiled a new ad blaming Trump for lighting the \"fire\" of Jan. 6 and threatening democracy.\n\nMany of those who once stood up to Trump are long gone from office and the Republicans who remain seem increasingly enthusiastic about the possibility of him retaking the White House, and the down-ballot windfall that could mean for their own GOP majorities in Congress.\n\nJohnson met with senators on Wednesday ahead of Trump's arrival as the Republicans mapped out potential priorities.\n\nOutgoing Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who once blamed Trump for the \"disgraceful\" attack that he called an \"insurrection\" now endorses the party's presumptive nominee and said: \"Of course I'll be at the meeting.\"\n\nSen. John Thune, the GOP whip who is vying to replace McConnell as leader, told The Associated Press that he was interested in hearing from Trump about the fall election. \"I think there's an opportunity there to really make this a big win,\" he said.\n\nAs democracies around the world come under threat from a far-rightward shift, experts warn that the U.S. system, once seemingly immune from authoritarian impulses, is at risk of populist and extremist forces like those that Trump inspired to sack the Capitol.\n\n\"This is just another example of House Republicans bending the knee to Donald Trump,\" said Rep. Pete Aguilar of California, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus.\n\nMaking Jan. 6 a cornerstone of his reelection campaign, Trump celebrates those who stormed the Capitol as \"warriors\" and \"patriots,\" and he has vowed to pardon any number of the more than 1,300 America convicted of crimes for the assault on the seat of U.S. democracy.\n\nMoreover, Trump has vowed to seek retribution by ousting officials at the U.S. Justice Department, which is prosecuting him in a four-count indictment to overturn the election ahead of the Jan. 6 attack and another case over storing classified documents at his Mar-A-Largo home.\n\nRepublicans, particularly in the House but increasingly in the Senate, are vigorously following his lead, complaining of an unfair justice system. The House voted to hold Attorney General Merrick Garland in contempt of Congress and is re-investigating the House committee that investigated Jan. 6.\n\nAlongside Trump, the House and Senate GOP campaign arms scored some of their highest fundraising periods yet after a jury found him guilty in the New York hush money case.\n\nWhen former GOP Speaker Paul Ryan on Fox News reiterated this week that he wouldn't be voting for Trump and wished Republicans had another choice for president, he was immediately ostracized by Trump allies.\n\n\"Paul Ryan, you're a piece of garbage,\" said Rep. Troy Nehls, R-Texas. \"We should kick you out of the party.\"\n\nOf the Republicans who voted to impeach Trump over Jan. 6 and convict him on the charge of inciting the insurrection, only a few remain in office.\n\nSen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, and Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, and Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah are not expected to attend Thursday's closed-door session with Trump.\n\nBut Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., said he would likely join the Trump meeting at GOP senators' campaign headquarters, expecting \"he's going to be the next president, so you have to work\" together.\n\nAsked if he was concerned about the direction of the Trump Republican Party, Cassidy: \"Let the day's own troubles be sufficient for the day. You can fill yourself up with anxiety about tomorrow, but will it change a thing? No.\"\n\nSen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C., who confronted Trump at times but did not join in the vote to convict him in the Capitol attack, said he did not expect the meeting to be contentious as Republicans hope to seize the Senate majority this fall.\n\n\"Look, we've got to win. And our ability to get a majority in the Senate is intrinsically linked to Trump winning. So we're like, one team, one vision. And I think that will be largely what we talk about,\" Tillis said.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Jill Colvin, Farnoush Amiri and Mary Clare Jalonick contributed to this report.", "source": "dmoz/Society/Gay, Lesbian, and Bisexual/Politics", "wgt": 12}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Housing", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Housing", "wgt": 11}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://media.tegna-media.com/assets/CCT/images/f0532b5d-a981-4ef2-b5d2-ca6fa0d14f4e/20240530T225119/f0532b5d-a981-4ef2-b5d2-ca6fa0d14f4e_1140x641.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9641178", "eventUri": "eng-9641178", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-01-06", "textStart": 1187, "textEnd": 1193, "freq": 7}], "sentiment": 0.1058823529411765, "wgt": 217, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-388503197", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "14:31:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T14:31:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T14:04:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/trump-returns-to-capitol-hill-and-meets-with-republican-lawmakers-a-first-since-jan-6/article_3f7ce16a-f34a-5e7f-aa76-c4aaac0e19a0.html", "title": "Trump returns to Capitol Hill and meets with Republican lawmakers, a first since Jan. 6 attack", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Donald Trump is making a triumphant return to Capitol Hill on Thursday, meeting with House and Senate Republicans, his first since urging a mob to \"fight like hell\" ahead of the Jan.6, 2021 attack. GOP lawmakers find themselves newly energized and reinvigorated by his bid to retake the White House.\n\nDespite the federal charges against Trump for conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, and his recent guilty verdict in an unrelated hush money trial, the Republican former president arrived emboldened as the party's presumptive nominee. He has successfully purged the GOP of critics, silenced most skeptics and enticed once-critical lawmakers aboard his MAGA-fueled campaign.\n\nA packed room of House Republicans sang \"Happy Birthday\" to Trump in the private breakfast meeting at GOP campaign headquarters across the street from the Capitol.\n\n\"We're excited to welcome President Trump back,\" said House Speaker Mike Johnson the day earlier.\n\nThe Republican speaker had demurred over whether he's asked Trump to respect the peaceful transfer of presidential power and commit to not doing another Jan. 6. \"Of course he respects that, we all do, and we've all talked about it, ad nauseum.\"\n\nTrump told the speaker behind closed doors Thursday he thinks Johnson is doing a \"terrific job,\" according to a Republican in the private meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it.\n\nTrump is expected to be delivering remarks and discussing issues animating his campaign -- including mass immigration deportations but also tax cuts and other priorities for a potential second term.\n\nMany potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, that are laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\nBut the private meetings with House and later in the afternoon the Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol are infused with symbolism of Trump's return as the U.S. president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of presidential power.\n\n\"It's frustrating,\" said former U.S. Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of Jan. 6, when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building trying to overturn President Joe Biden's election.\n\nDunn spoke of the \"irony\" of Trump returning to the area and lawmakers now embracing him. \"It just shows the lack of backbone they have when they're truly putting party and person over country,\" he said. \"And it's sad.\"\n\nMany of those who once stood up to Trump are long gone from office and the Republicans who remain seem increasingly enthusiastic about the possibility of him retaking the White House, and the down-ballot windfall that could mean for their own GOP majorities in Congress.\n\nJohnson met with senators on Wednesday ahead of Trump's arrival as the Republicans mapped out potential priorities.\n\nOutgoing Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who once blamed Trump for the \"disgraceful\" attack that he called an \"insurrection\" now endorses the party's presumptive nominee and said: \"Of course I'll be at the meeting.\"\n\nSen. John Thune, the GOP whip who is vying to replace McConnell as leader, told The Associated Press that he's interested in hearing from Trump about the fall election and \"ways in which we, as a team, and him individually can appeal to the constituencies and people that may not traditionally vote Republican.\"\n\nThune said, \"I think there's an opportunity there to really make this a big win.\"\n\nAs democracies around the world come under threat from a far-rightward shift, experts warn that the U.S. system, once seemingly immune from authoritarian impulses, is at risk of populist and extremist forces like those that Trump inspired to sack the Capitol.\n\n\"This is just another example of House Republicans bending the knee to Donald Trump,\" said Rep. Pete Aguilar of California, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus.\n\nMaking Jan. 6 a cornerstone of his reelection campaign, Trump celebrates those who stormed the Capitol as \"warriors\" and \"patriots,\" and he has vowed to pardon any number of the more than 1,300 America convicted of crimes for the assault on the seat of U.S. democracy.\n\nMoreover, Trump has vowed to seek retribution by ousting officials at the U.S. Justice Department, which is prosecuting him in a four-count indictment to overturn the election ahead of the Jan. 6 attack and another case over storing classified documents at his Mar-A-Largo home.\n\nRepublicans, particularly in the House but increasingly in the Senate, are vigorously following his lead, complaining of an unfair justice system. The House voted to hold Attorney General Merrick Garland in contempt of Congress and is re-investigating the House committee that investigated Jan. 6.\n\nAlongside Trump, the House and Senate GOP campaign arms scored some of their highest fundraising periods yet after a jury found him guilty in the New York hush money case.\n\nWhen former GOP Speaker Paul Ryan on Fox News reiterated this week that he wouldn't be voting for Trump and wished Republicans had another choice for president, he was immediately ostracized by Trump allies.\n\n\"Paul Ryan, you're a piece of garbage,\" said Rep. Troy Nehls, R-Texas. \"We should kick you out of the party.\"\n\nOf the Republicans who voted to impeach Trump over Jan. 6 and convict him on the charge of inciting the insurrection, only a few remain in office.\n\nSen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, and Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, are not expected to attend Thursday's closed-door session with Trump.\n\nBut Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., said he would likely join the Trump meeting at GOP senators' campaign headquarters, expecting \"he's going to be the next president, so you have to work\" together.\n\nAsked if he was concerned about the direction of the Trump Republican Party, Cassidy: \"Let the day's own troubles be sufficient for the day. You can fill yourself up with anxiety about tomorrow, but will it change a thing? No.\"\n\nSen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C., who confronted Trump at times but did not join in the vote to convict him in the Capitol attack, said he did not expect the meeting to be contentious as Republicans hope to seize the Senate majority this fall.\n\n\"Look, we've got to win. And our ability to get a majority in the Senate is intrinsically linked to Trump winning. So we're like, one team, one vision. And I think that will be largely what we talk about,\" Tillis said.\n\nAssociated Press writers Jill Colvin and Mary Clare Jalonick contributed to this report.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. {"uri": "8176544545", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "18:31:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T18:31:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T18:30:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/trump-returns-to-capitol-hill-and-whips-up-republican-lawmakers-a-first-meeting-since-jan/article_7f4209d0-130d-58ba-8568-481e6ce3b101.html", "title": "Trump returns to Capitol Hill and whips up Republican lawmakers, a first meeting since Jan. 6 attack", "body": "Rep. Matt Gaetz, R-Fla., joined at left by Rep. Tim Burchett, R-Tenn., arrives as former President Donald Trump returns to Washington for meetings with Republican lawmakers to unite on his political agenda, just a few steps off the Capitol campus, Thursday, June 13, 2025 in Washington.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Donald Trump made a triumphant return Thursday to Capitol Hill, whipping up House and Senate Republicans in his first meetings since the Jan.6, 2021 attacks, embraced by GOP lawmakers who find themselves newly energized by his bid to retake the White House.\n\nDespite the federal charges against Trump for conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, and his recent guilty verdict in an unrelated hush money trial, the Republican former president arrived emboldened as the party's presumptive nominee. He has successfully purged the GOP of critics, silenced most skeptics and enticed once-critical lawmakers aboard his MAGA-fueled campaign.\n\nA packed room of House Republicans sang \"Happy Birthday\" to Trump in the private breakfast meeting at GOP campaign headquarters across the street from the Capitol. The lawmakers gave him a baseball and bat from the annual congressional game. Trump bragged that even his telephone rallies for lawmakers could draw bigger crowds than mega-popstar Taylor Swift, who has yet to make any endorsement.\n\n\"President Trump brought an extraordinary amount of energy, excitement and enthusiasm this morning,\" said House Speaker Mike Johnson, noting high fund-raising tallies since the guilty verdict. \"We're feeling good.\"\n\nThe Republican speaker had demurred earlier over whether he's asked Trump to respect the peaceful transfer of presidential power and commit to not doing another Jan. 6. \"Of course he respects that, we all do, and we've all talked about it, ad nauseum.\"\n\nTrump told Johnson Thursday he thinks the speaker is doing a \"terrific job,\" according to a Republican in the private meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it. He asked Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, the speaker's chief Republican critic, if she was being \"nice\" to Johnson, another Republican said.\n\nTrump spent about an hour with House Republicans delivering free-wheeling remarks, fielding questions and discussing issues -- including Russia and immigration and also tax cuts and other priorities for a potential second term. On one major controversial issue, Trump told lawmakers that abortion rules should be left to the states and said he supported exceptions for rape, incest and to save the life of the mother, lawmakers said.\n\nSenate Republicans welcomed Trump next in the afternoon, as protesters clamored at both locations and police beefed up security.\n\nMany potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\n\"Anybody who thought that this president was going to be down after the sham trial. it's only giving him even more energy,\" said Rep. Tom Emmer, the GOP whip. \"Donald Trump is crushing this election.\"\n\nBut Trump's private meetings with House and Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol were infused with the symbolism of his return as the U.S. president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of power.\n\n\"It's frustrating,\" said former U.S. Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of Jan. 6, the day when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building in an effort to overturn President Joe Biden's election.\n\nDunn spoke of the \"irony\" of Trump returning to the area and lawmakers now embracing him. \"It just shows the lack of backbone they have when they're truly putting party and person over country,\" he said. \"And it's sad.\"\n\nBiden was overseas Thursday attending a summit of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations, but the president's campaign unveiled a new ad blaming Trump for lighting the \"fire\" of Jan. 6 and threatening democracy.\n\nMany of those who once stood up to Trump are long gone from office and the Republicans who remain seem increasingly enthusiastic about the possibility of him retaking the White House, and the down-ballot windfall that could mean for their own GOP majorities in Congress.\n\nThursday was to include an encounter between Trump and Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who once blamed Trump for the \"disgraceful\" attack that he called an \"insurrection\" but now endorses the party's presumptive nominee. \"Of course I'll be at the meeting.\"\n\nSen. John Thune, the GOP whip who is vying to replace McConnell as leader, told The Associated Press that he was interested in hearing from Trump about the fall election. \"I think there's an opportunity there to really make this a big win,\" he said.\n\nAs democracies around the world come under threat from a far-rightward shift, some analysts warn that the U.S. system, once seemingly immune from authoritarian impulses, is at risk of populist and extremist forces like those that Trump inspired to sack the Capitol.\n\n\"This is just another example of House Republicans bending the knee to Donald Trump,\" said Rep. Pete Aguilar of California, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus.\n\nMaking Jan. 6 a cornerstone of his reelection campaign, Trump celebrates those who stormed the Capitol as \"warriors\" and \"patriots,\" and he has vowed to pardon any number of the more than 1,300 convicted of crimes for the assault on the seat of U.S. democracy.\n\nMoreover, Trump has vowed to seek retribution by ousting officials at the U.S. Justice Department, which is prosecuting him in a four-count indictment to overturn the election ahead of the Jan. 6 attack and another case over storing classified documents at his Mar-A-Largo home.\n\nRepublicans, particularly in the House but increasingly in the Senate, are vigorously following his lead, complaining of an unfair justice system. Alongside Trump, the House and Senate GOP campaign arms scored some of their highest fundraising periods yet after a jury found him guilty in the New York hush money case.\n\nWhen former GOP Speaker Paul Ryan on Fox News reiterated this week that he wouldn't be voting for Trump and wished Republicans had another choice for president, he was immediately ostracized by Trump allies.\n\n\"Paul Ryan, you're a piece of garbage,\" said Rep. Troy Nehls, R-Texas. \"We should kick you out of the party.\"\n\nOf the Republicans who voted to impeach Trump over Jan. 6 and convict him on the charge of inciting the insurrection, only a few remain in office.\n\nSen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, and Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, were not expected to attend Thursday's closed-door session with Trump. But Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, had a change of plans and was to join.\n\nAlso Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., said he would likely join the Trump meeting at GOP senators' campaign headquarters, expecting \"he's going to be the next president, so you have to work\" together.\n\nAsked if he was concerned about the direction of the Trump Republican Party, Cassidy said: \"Let the day's own troubles be sufficient for the day. You can fill yourself up with anxiety about tomorrow, but will it change a thing? No.\"\n\nAssociated Press writers Jill Colvin, Farnoush Amiri, Kevin Freking, Mary Clare Jalonick and Stephen Groves contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9641178", "eventUri": "eng-9641178", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "-01-06", "textStart": 1719, "textEnd": 1725, "freq": 6}, {"uri": "2024-06-388596811", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "15:57:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T15:57:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T15:56:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/9/525491/World/International/Trump-returns-to-Capitol-Hill-and-meets-with-Repub.aspx", "title": "Trump returns to Capitol Hill and meets with Republican lawmakers, a first since Jan. 6 attack", "body": "Former President Donald Trump arrives at the Capitol Hill Club in Washington. AP\n\nDespite the federal charges against Trump for conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, and his recent guilty verdict in an unrelated hush money trial, the Republican former president arrived emboldened as the party's presumptive nominee. He has successfully purged the GOP of critics, silenced most skeptics, and enticed once-critical lawmakers aboard his MAGA-fueled campaign.\n\nA packed room of House Republicans sang \"Happy Birthday\" to Trump in the private breakfast meeting at GOP campaign headquarters across the street from the Capitol. The lawmakers gave him a baseball and bat from the annual congressional game.\n\n\"We're excited to welcome President Trump back,\" said House Speaker Mike Johnson a day earlier.\n\nThe Republican speaker had demurred over whether he's asked Trump to respect the peaceful transfer of presidential power and commit to not doing another Jan. 6. \"Of course he respects that, we all do, and we've all talked about it, ad nauseum.\"\n\nTrump told Johnson Thursday he thinks the speaker is doing a \"terrific job,\" according to a Republican in the private meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it. Trump asked Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, the speaker's chief Republican critic if she was being nice to Johnson, another Republican said.\n\nTrump is expected to be delivering remarks and discussing issues animating his campaign -- including mass immigration deportations but also tax cuts and other priorities for a potential second term.\n\nMany potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, that are laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\nBut the private meetings with House and later in the afternoon Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol are infused with symbolism of Trump's return as the US president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of presidential power.\n\n\"It's frustrating,\" said former US Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of Jan. 6, when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building trying to overturn President Joe Biden's election.\n\nDunn spoke of the \"irony\" of Trump returning to the area and lawmakers now embracing him. \"It just shows the lack of backbone they have when they're truly putting party and person over country,\" he said. \"And it's sad.\"\n\nBiden was overseas Thursday attending a summit of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations, but the president's campaign unveiled a new ad blaming Trump for lighting the \"fire\" of Jan. 6 and threatening democracy.\n\nMany of those who once stood up to Trump are long gone from office and the Republicans who remain seem increasingly enthusiastic about the possibility of him retaking the White House, and the down-ballot windfall that could mean for their own GOP majorities in Congress.\n\nJohnson met with senators on Wednesday ahead of Trump's arrival as the Republicans mapped out potential priorities.\n\nOutgoing Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who once blamed Trump for the \"disgraceful\" attack that he called an \"insurrection\" now endorses the party's presumptive nominee and said: \"Of course I'll be at the meeting.\"\n\nSen. John Thune, the GOP whip who is vying to replace McConnell as leader, told The Associated Press that he was interested in hearing from Trump about the fall election. \"I think there's an opportunity there to really make this a big win,\" he said.\n\nAs democracies around the world come under threat from a far-rightward shift, experts warn that the US system, once seemingly immune from authoritarian impulses, is at risk of populist and extremist forces like those that Trump inspired to sack the Capitol.\n\n\"This is just another example of House Republicans bending the knee to Donald Trump,\" said Rep. Pete Aguilar of California, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus.\n\nMaking Jan. 6 a cornerstone of his reelection campaign, Trump celebrates those who stormed the Capitol as \"warriors\" and \"patriots,\" and he has vowed to pardon any number of the more than 1,300 Americans convicted of crimes for the assault on the seat of US democracy.\n\nMoreover, Trump has vowed to seek retribution by ousting officials at the US Justice Department, which is prosecuting him in a four-count indictment to overturn the election ahead of the Jan. 6 attack and another case over storing classified documents at his Mar-A-Largo home.\n\nRepublicans, particularly in the House but increasingly in the Senate, are vigorously following his lead, complaining of an unfair justice system. The House voted to hold Attorney General Merrick Garland in contempt of Congress and is re-investigating the House committee that investigated Jan. 6.\n\nAlongside Trump, the House and Senate GOP campaign arms scored some of their highest fundraising periods yet after a jury found him guilty in the New York hush-money case.\n\nWhen former GOP Speaker Paul Ryan on Fox News reiterated this week that he wouldn't be voting for Trump and wished Republicans had another choice for president, he was immediately ostracized by Trump allies.\n\n\"Paul Ryan, you're a piece of garbage,\" said Rep. Troy Nehls, R-Texas. \"We should kick you out of the party.\"\n\nOf the Republicans who voted to impeach Trump over Jan. 6 and convict him on the charge of inciting the insurrection, only a few remain in office.\n\nSen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, and Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, and Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah are not expected to attend Thursday's closed-door session with Trump.\n\nBut Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., said he would likely join the Trump meeting at GOP senators' campaign headquarters, expecting \"he's going to be the next president, so you have to work\" together.\n\nAsked if he was concerned about the direction of the Trump Republican Party, Cassidy: \"Let the day's own troubles be sufficient for the day. You can fill yourself up with anxiety about tomorrow, but will it change a thing? No.\"\n\nSen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C., who confronted Trump at times but did not join in the vote to convict him in the Capitol attack, said he did not expect the meeting to be contentious as Republicans hope to seize the Senate majority this fall.\n\n\"Look, we've got to win. And our ability to get a majority in the Senate is intrinsically linked to Trump winning. So we're like, one team, one vision. And I think that will be largely what we talk about,\" Tillis said.", "source": {"uri": "english.ahram.org.eg", "dataType": "news", "title": "\u062c\u0631\u064a\u062f\u0629 {"uri": "8176413644", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:44:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:44:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T16:43:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/trump-returns-to-capitol-hill-and-whips-up-republican-lawmakers-a-first-meeting-since-jan-6-attack-1.6924989", "title": "Trump returns to Capitol Hill and whips up Republican lawmakers, a first meeting since Jan. 6 attack", "body": "Donald Trump made a triumphant return Thursday to Capitol Hill, whipping up House and Senate Republicans in his first meetings since the Jan.6, 2 021 attacks, cheered by GOP lawmakers who find themselves newly energized by his bid to retake the White House.\n\nDespite the federal charges against Trump for conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, and his recent guilty verdict in an unrelated hush money trial, the Republican former president arrived emboldened as the party's presumptive nominee. He has successfully purged the GOP of critics, silenced most skeptics and enticed once-critical lawmakers aboard his MAGA-fuelled campaign.\n\nA packed room of House Republicans sang \"Happy Birthday\" to Trump in the private breakfast meeting at GOP campaign headquarters across the street from the Capitol. The lawmakers gave him a baseball and bat from the annual congressional game. Trump bragged that even his telephone rallies for lawmakers could draw bigger crowds than mega-popstar Taylor Swift, who has yet to make any endorsement.\n\n\"President Trump brought an extraordinary amount of energy, excitement and enthusiasm this morning,\" said House Speaker Mike Johnson, noting high fund-raising tallies since the guilty verdict. \"We're feeling good.\"\n\nThe Republican speaker had demurred earlier over whether he's asked Trump to respect the peaceful transfer of presidential power and commit to not doing another Jan. 6. \"Of course he respects that, we all do, and we've all talked about it, ad nauseum.\"\n\nTrump told Johnson Thursday he thinks the speaker is doing a \"terrific job,\" according to a Republican in the private meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it. He asked Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, the speaker's chief Republican critic, if she was being \"nice\" to Johnson, another Republican said.\n\nTrump spent about an hour with House Republicans delivering free-wheeling remarks, fielding questions and discussing issues -- including Russia and immigration and also tax cuts and other priorities for a potential second term. On one major controversial issue, Trump told lawmakers that abortion rules should be left to the states and said he supported exceptions for rape, incest and to save the life of the mother, lawmakers said.\n\nSenate Republicans meet next with Trump in the afternoon.\n\nPolice, protesters and press gather as former U.S. President Donald Trump returns to Washington for meetings with Republican lawmakers to unite on his political agenda, just a few steps off the Capitol campus, Thursday, June 13, 2024. (J. Scott Applewhite / AP Photo)\n\nMany potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\n\"Anybody who thought that this president was going to be down after the sham trial. it's only giving him even more energy,\" said Rep. Tom Emmer, the GOP whip. \"Donald Trump is crushing this election.\"\n\nBut Trump's private meetings with House and Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol are infused with symbolism of his return as the U.S. president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of power.\n\n\"It's frustrating,\" said former U.S. Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of Jan. 6, when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building.\n\nDunn spoke of the \"irony\" of Trump returning to the area and lawmakers now embracing him. \"It just shows the lack of backbone they have when they're truly putting party and person over country,\" he said. \"And it's sad.\"\n\nBiden was overseas Thursday attending a summit of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations, but the president's campaign unveiled a new ad blaming Trump for lighting the \"fire\" of Jan. 6 and threatening democracy.\n\nMany of those who once stood up to Trump are long gone from office and the Republicans who remain seem increasingly enthusiastic about the possibility of him retaking the White House, and the down-ballot windfall that could mean for their own GOP majorities in Congress.\n\nOutgoing Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who once blamed Trump for the \"disgraceful\" attack that he called an \"insurrection\" now endorses the party's presumptive nominee and said: \"Of course I'll be at the meeting.\"\n\nSen. John Thune, the GOP whip who is vying to replace McConnell as leader, told The Associated Press that he was interested in hearing from Trump about the fall election. \"I think there's an opportunity there to really make this a big win,\" he said.\n\nAs democracies around the world come under threat from a far-rightward shift, experts warn that the U.S. system, once seemingly immune from authoritarian impulses, is at risk of populist and extremist forces like those that Trump inspired to sack the Capitol.\n\n\"This is just another example of House Republicans bending the knee to Donald Trump,\" said Rep. Pete Aguilar of California, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus.\n\nMaking Jan. 6 a cornerstone of his reelection campaign, Trump celebrates those who stormed the Capitol as \"warriors\" and \"patriots,\" and he has vowed to pardon any number of the more than 1,300 America convicted of crimes for the assault on the seat of U.S. democracy.\n\nMoreover, Trump has vowed to seek retribution by ousting officials at the U.S. Justice Department, which is prosecuting him in a four-count indictment to overturn the election ahead of the Jan. 6 attack and another case over storing classified documents at his Mar-A-Largo home.\n\nRepublicans, particularly in the House but increasingly in the Senate, are vigorously following his lead, complaining of an unfair justice system. Alongside Trump, the House and Senate GOP campaign arms scored some of their highest fundraising periods yet after a jury found him guilty in the New York hush money case.\n\nRepublican presidential candidate Donald Trump speaks at a campaign rally June 9, 2024 in Las Vegas. (John Locher / AP Photo)\n\nWhen former GOP Speaker Paul Ryan on Fox News reiterated this week that he wouldn't be voting for Trump and wished Republicans had another choice for president, he was immediately ostracized by Trump allies.\n\n\"Paul Ryan, you're a piece of garbage,\" said Rep. Troy Nehls, R-Texas. \"We should kick you out of the party.\"\n\nOf the Republicans who voted to impeach Trump over Jan. 6 and convict him on the charge of inciting the insurrection, only a few remain in office.\n\nSen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, and Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, were not expected to attend Thursday's closed-door session with Trump. But Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, had a change of plans and will now join.\n\nAlso Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., said he would likely join the Trump meeting at GOP senators' campaign headquarters, expecting \"he's going to be the next president, so you have to work\" together.\n\nAsked if he was concerned about the direction of the Trump Republican Party, Cassidy: \"Let the day's own troubles be sufficient for the day. You can fill yourself up with anxiety about tomorrow, but will it change a thing? No.\"\n\nSen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C., who confronted Trump at times but did not join in the vote to convict him in the Capitol attack, said he did not expect the meeting to be contentious as Republicans hope to seize the Senate majority this fall.\n\n\"Look, we've got to win. And our ability to get a majority in the Senate is intrinsically linked to Trump winning. So we're like, one team, one vision. {"uri": "8176679823", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "20:38:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T20:38:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T20:37:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/politics/cheers-cake-and-a-fist-bump-from-gop-as-trump-returns-to-capitol-hill-in-a-first-since-jan-6-riot/", "title": "Cheers, cake and a fist-bump from GOP as Trump returns to Capitol Hill in a first since Jan. 6 riot - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Donald Trump made a triumphant return to Capitol Hill on Thursday, his first with lawmakers since the Jan.6, 2021 attacks, embraced by energized House and Senate Republicans who find themselves reinvigorated by his bid to retake the White House.\n\nDespite pending federal charges against Trump for conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, and his recent guilty verdict in an unrelated hush money trial, the Republican former president arrived emboldened as the party's presumptive nominee. He has successfully purged the GOP of critics, silenced most skeptics and enticed once-critical lawmakers aboard his MAGA-fueled campaign.\n\nA packed room of House Republicans sang \"Happy Birthday\" to Trump in a private breakfast meeting at GOP campaign headquarters across the street from the Capitol. The lawmakers gave him a baseball and bat from the annual congressional game, and senators later presented an American flag cake with \"45\" candles -- and then \"47'' -- referring to the next presidency. Trump bragged that even his telephone rallies for lawmakers could draw bigger crowds than mega-popstar Taylor Swift, who has yet to make any endorsement.\n\nIn one remarkable moment, Trump and his most prominent Republican critic, Senate GOP leader Mitch McConnell, shook hands, and fist-bumped.\n\n\"There's tremendous unity in the Republican Party,\" Trump said in brief remarks at Senate GOP headquarters.\n\nTrump spent about an hour each with House and Senate Republicans delivering free-wheeling remarks, fielding questions and discussing issues -- including Russia and immigration, tax cuts and other priorities for a potential second term.\n\nDuring the morning session, Trump said House Speaker Mike Johnson is doing a \"terrific job,\" according to a Republican in the private meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it. Trump asked Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, the speaker's chief Republican critic, if she was being \"nice\" to Johnson, another Republican said.\n\n\"President Trump brought an extraordinary amount of energy, excitement and enthusiasm this morning,\" Johnson said afterward, noting high fund-raising tallies since the guilty verdict. \"We're feeling good.\"\n\nThe Republican speaker had demurred earlier over whether he's asked Trump to respect the peaceful transfer of presidential power and commit to not doing another Jan. 6. \"Of course he respects that, we all do, and we've all talked about it, ad nauseum.\"\n\nMany potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\n\"Anybody who thought that this president was going to be down after the sham trial. it's only giving him even more energy,\" said Rep. Tom Emmer, the GOP whip. \"Donald Trump is crushing this election.\"\n\nBut Trump's private meetings with House and Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol were infused with the symbolism of his return as the U.S. president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of power.\n\n\"It's frustrating,\" said former U.S. Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of Jan. 6, the day when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building in an effort to overturn President Joe Biden's election.\n\nDunn spoke of the \"irony\" of Trump returning to the area and lawmakers now embracing him. \"It just shows the lack of backbone they have when they're truly putting party and person over country,\" he said. \"And it's sad.\"\n\nBiden was overseas Thursday attending a summit of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations, but the president's campaign unveiled a new ad blaming Trump for lighting the \"fire\" of Jan. 6 and threatening democracy.\n\nMany of those who once stood up to Trump are long gone from office and the Republicans who remain seem increasingly enthusiastic about the possibility of him retaking the White House, and the down-ballot windfall that could mean for their own GOP majorities in Congress.\n\nThursday afternoon offered the first encounter in years between Trump and McConnell, who once blamed Trump for the \"disgraceful\" attack that he called an \"insurrection\" but now endorses the party's presumptive nominee.\n\nTrump addressed the situation directly, saying he intends to work with everyone and that McConnell had \"done his best\" as leader, said Sen. Markwayne Mullin, R-Okla., an ally of the former president.\n\nAccording to Sen. John Barrasso, R-Wyo., who organized the conference meeting, after Trump addressed the group McConnell gave a thumbs up and the two approached each other and exchanged the fist-bump.\n\n\"We had a really positive meeting,\" McConnell said. \"He and I got a chance to talk a little bit, shook hands a few times.\"\n\nAs democracies around the world come under threat from a far-rightward shift, some analysts warn that the U.S. system, once seemingly immune from authoritarian impulses, is at risk of populist and extremist forces like those that Trump inspired to sack the Capitol.\n\n\"This is just another example of House Republicans bending the knee to Donald Trump,\" said Rep. Pete Aguilar of California, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus.\n\nMaking Jan. 6 a cornerstone of his reelection campaign, Trump celebrates those who stormed the Capitol as \"warriors\" and \"patriots,\" and he has vowed to pardon any number of the more than 1,200 people charged with crimes for the assault on the seat of U.S. democracy.\n\nMoreover, Trump has vowed to seek retribution by ousting officials at the U.S. Justice Department, which is prosecuting him in a four-count indictment to overturn the election ahead of the Jan. 6 attack and another case over storing classified documents at his Mar-A-Largo home.\n\nRepublicans, particularly in the House but increasingly in the Senate, are vigorously following his lead, complaining of an unfair justice system. It's having noticeable results: the House and Senate GOP campaign arms scored some of their highest fundraising periods yet after a jury found him guilty in the New York hush money case.\n\nWhen former GOP Speaker Paul Ryan on Fox News reiterated this week that he wouldn't be voting for Trump and wished Republicans had another choice for president, he was immediately ostracized by Trump allies.\n\n\"Paul Ryan, you're a piece of garbage,\" said Rep. Troy Nehls, R-Texas. \"We should kick you out of the party.\"\n\nOf the Republicans who voted to impeach Trump over Jan. 6 and convict him on the charge of inciting the insurrection, only a few remain in office.\n\nSen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, and Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, had not been expected to attend Thursday's closed-door session with Trump. But Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, joined as did Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La.\n\nCassidy said he's attending the Trump meeting expecting \"he's going to be the next president, so you have to work\" together.\n\nAsked if he was concerned about the direction of the Trump Republican Party, Cassidy said: \"Let the day's own troubles be sufficient for the day. You can fill yourself up with anxiety about tomorrow, but will it change a thing? No.\"\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.\n\nJoin our Newsletter for the latest news right to your inbox Email address Submit", "source": {"uri": "wsvn.com", John Barrasso, the chairman of the GOP conference, and Trump has accepted, according to two people familiar with the planning who requested anonymity to discuss the closed-door meeting. The meeting will be held in a location away from the Capitol, as is common practice for campaign-related events.\n\nThe gathering will be the first time that Trump has met with the GOP conference since he was president, and the first time since the attack by his supporters on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The meeting was first reported by NBC News.\n\nMany senators who had criticized Trump after the attack have now endorsed his run for the presidency, including Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell and other members of Senate leadership.\n\nhttps://www.yahoo.com/news/two-weeks-hush-money-verdict-221548856.html\n\nThe GOP has no principles, just the pursuit of power.", "source": {"uri": "democraticunderground.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Democratic Underground"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "dmoz/Society/Gay,_Lesbian,_and_Bisexual/Politics", "label": "dmoz/Society/Gay, Lesbian, and Bisexual/Politics", "wgt": 12}, {"uri": "dmoz/Science/Earth_Sciences/Conferences", "label": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9641178", "eventUri": "eng-9641178", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1294117647058823, "wgt": 213, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8176470525", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "17:28:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T17:28:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T17:27:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.ocregister.com/2024/06/13/trump-returns-to-capitol-hill-and-whips-up-republican-lawmakers-a-first-meeting-since-jan-6-attack/", "title": "Trump returns to Capitol Hill and whips up Republican lawmakers, a first meeting since Jan. 6 attack", "body": "By LISA MASCARO (AP Congressional Correspondent)\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Donald Trump made a triumphant return Thursday to Capitol Hill, whipping up House and Senate Republicans in his first meetings since the Jan.6, 2021 attacks, embraced by GOP lawmakers who find themselves newly energized by his bid to retake the White House.\n\nDespite the federal charges against Trump for conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, and his recent guilty verdict in an unrelated hush money trial, the Republican former president arrived emboldened as the party's presumptive nominee. He has successfully purged the GOP of critics, silenced most skeptics and enticed once-critical lawmakers aboard his MAGA-fueled campaign.\n\nA packed room of House Republicans sang \"Happy Birthday\" to Trump in the private breakfast meeting at GOP campaign headquarters across the street from the Capitol. The lawmakers gave him a baseball and bat from the annual congressional game. Trump bragged that even his telephone rallies for lawmakers could draw bigger crowds than mega-popstar Taylor Swift, who has yet to make any endorsement.\n\n\"President Trump brought an extraordinary amount of energy, excitement and enthusiasm this morning,\" said House Speaker Mike Johnson, noting high fund-raising tallies since the guilty verdict. \"We're feeling good.\"\n\nThe Republican speaker had demurred earlier over whether he's asked Trump to respect the peaceful transfer of presidential power and commit to not doing another Jan. 6. \"Of course he respects that, we all do, and we've all talked about it, ad nauseum.\"\n\nTrump told Johnson Thursday he thinks the speaker is doing a \"terrific job,\" according to a Republican in the private meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it. He asked Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, the speaker's chief Republican critic, if she was being \"nice\" to Johnson, another Republican said.\n\nTrump spent about an hour with House Republicans delivering free-wheeling remarks, fielding questions and discussing issues -- including Russia and immigration and also tax cuts and other priorities for a potential second term. On one major controversial issue, Trump told lawmakers that abortion rules should be left to the states and said he supported exceptions for rape, incest and to save the life of the mother, lawmakers said.\n\nSenate Republicans welcomed Trump next in the afternoon, as protesters clamored at both locations and police beefed up security.\n\nMany potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\n\"Anybody who thought that this president was going to be down after the sham trial. it's only giving him even more energy,\" said Rep. Tom Emmer, the GOP whip. \"Donald Trump is crushing this election.\"\n\nBut Trump's private meetings with House and Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol were infused with the symbolism of his return as the U.S. president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of power.\n\n\"It's frustrating,\" said former U.S. Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of Jan. 6, the day when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building in an effort to overturn President Joe Biden's election.\n\nDunn spoke of the \"irony\" of Trump returning to the area and lawmakers now embracing him. \"It just shows the lack of backbone they have when they're truly putting party and person over country,\" he said. \"And it's sad.\"\n\nBiden was overseas Thursday attending a summit of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations, but the president's campaign unveiled a new ad blaming Trump for lighting the \"fire\" of Jan. 6 and threatening democracy.\n\nMany of those who once stood up to Trump are long gone from office and the Republicans who remain seem increasingly enthusiastic about the possibility of him retaking the White House, and the down-ballot windfall that could mean for their own GOP majorities in Congress.\n\nThursday was to include an encounter between Trump and Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who once blamed Trump for the \"disgraceful\" attack that he called an \"insurrection\" but now endorses the party's presumptive nominee. \"Of course I'll be at the meeting.\"\n\nSen. John Thune, the GOP whip who is vying to replace McConnell as leader, told The Associated Press that he was interested in hearing from Trump about the fall election. \"I think there's an opportunity there to really make this a big win,\" he said.\n\nAs democracies around the world come under threat from a far-rightward shift, some analysts warn that the U.S. system, once seemingly immune from authoritarian impulses, is at risk of populist and extremist forces like those that Trump inspired to sack the Capitol.\n\n\"This is just another example of House Republicans bending the knee to Donald Trump,\" said Rep. Pete Aguilar of California, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus.\n\nMaking Jan. 6 a cornerstone of his reelection campaign, Trump celebrates those who stormed the Capitol as \"warriors\" and \"patriots,\" and he has vowed to pardon any number of the more than 1,300 convicted of crimes for the assault on the seat of U.S. democracy.\n\nMoreover, Trump has vowed to seek retribution by ousting officials at the U.S. Justice Department, which is prosecuting him in a four-count indictment to overturn the election ahead of the Jan. 6 attack and another case over storing classified documents at his Mar-A-Largo home.\n\nRepublicans, particularly in the House but increasingly in the Senate, are vigorously following his lead, complaining of an unfair justice system. Alongside Trump, the House and Senate GOP campaign arms scored some of their highest fundraising periods yet after a jury found him guilty in the New York hush money case.\n\nWhen former GOP Speaker Paul Ryan on Fox News reiterated this week that he wouldn't be voting for Trump and wished Republicans had another choice for president, he was immediately ostracized by Trump allies.\n\n\"Paul Ryan, you're a piece of garbage,\" said Rep. Troy Nehls, R-Texas. \"We should kick you out of the party.\"\n\nOf the Republicans who voted to impeach Trump over Jan. 6 and convict him on the charge of inciting the insurrection, only a few remain in office.\n\nSen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, and Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, were not expected to attend Thursday's closed-door session with Trump. But Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, had a change of plans and was to join.\n\nAlso Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., said he would likely join the Trump meeting at GOP senators' campaign headquarters, expecting \"he's going to be the next president, so you have to work\" together.\n\nAsked if he was concerned about the direction of the Trump Republican Party, Cassidy said: \"Let the day's own troubles be sufficient for the day. You can fill yourself up with anxiety about tomorrow, but will it change a thing? No.\"", "source": {"uri": "ocregister.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Orange County Register"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@ocregister.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type":
