{"uri": "8176396682", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:33:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:33:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T16:32:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/trump-returns-to-capitol-hill-and-whips-up-republican-lawmakers-a-first-meeting-since-jan/article_941ae265-206f-5b56-832c-79109a9ff50b.html", "title": "Trump returns to Capitol Hill and whips up Republican lawmakers, a first meeting since Jan. 6 attack", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Donald Trump made a triumphant return Thursday to Capitol Hill, whipping up House and Senate Republicans in his first meetings since the Jan.6, 2 021 attacks, cheered by GOP lawmakers who find themselves newly energized by his bid to retake the White House.\n\nDespite the federal charges against Trump for conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, and his recent guilty verdict in an unrelated hush money trial, the Republican former president arrived emboldened as the party's presumptive nominee. He has successfully purged the GOP of critics, silenced most skeptics and enticed once-critical lawmakers aboard his MAGA-fueled campaign.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nA packed room of House Republicans sang \"Happy Birthday\" to Trump in the private breakfast meeting at GOP campaign headquarters across the street from the Capitol. The lawmakers gave him a baseball and bat from the annual congressional game. Trump bragged that even his telephone rallies for lawmakers could draw bigger crowds than mega-popstar Taylor Swift, who has yet to make any endorsement.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"President Trump brought an extraordinary amount of energy, excitement and enthusiasm this morning,\" said House Speaker Mike Johnson, noting high fund-raising tallies since the guilty verdict. \"We're feeling good.\"\n\nThe Republican speaker had demurred earlier over whether he's asked Trump to respect the peaceful transfer of presidential power and commit to not doing another Jan. 6. \"Of course he respects that, we all do, and we've all talked about it, ad nauseum.\"\n\nTrump told Johnson Thursday he thinks the speaker is doing a \"terrific job,\" according to a Republican in the private meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it. He asked Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, the speaker's chief Republican critic, if she was being \"nice\" to Johnson, another Republican said.\n\nTrump spent about an hour with House Republicans delivering free-wheeling remarks, fielding questions and discussing issues -- including Russia and immigration and also tax cuts and other priorities for a potential second term. On one major controversial issue, Trump told lawmakers that abortion rules should be left to the states and said he supported exceptions for rape, incest and to save the life of the mother, lawmakers said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nSenate Republicans meet next with Trump in the afternoon.\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMany potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\n\"Anybody who thought that this president was going to be down after the sham trial. it's only giving him even more energy,\" said Rep. Tom Emmer, the GOP whip. \"Donald Trump is crushing this election.\"\n\nBut Trump's private meetings with House and Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol are infused with symbolism of his return as the U.S. president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of power.\n\n\"It's frustrating,\" said former U.S. Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of Jan. 6, when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building.\n\nDunn spoke of the \"irony\" of Trump returning to the area and lawmakers now embracing him. \"It just shows the lack of backbone they have when they're truly putting party and person over country,\" he said. \"And it's sad.\"\n\nBiden was overseas Thursday attending a summit of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations, but the president's campaign unveiled a new ad blaming Trump for lighting the \"fire\" of Jan. 6 and threatening democracy.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMany of those who once stood up to Trump are long gone from office and the Republicans who remain seem increasingly enthusiastic about the possibility of him retaking the White House, and the down-ballot windfall that could mean for their own GOP majorities in Congress.\n\nOutgoing Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who once blamed Trump for the \"disgraceful\" attack that he called an \"insurrection\" now endorses the party's presumptive nominee and said: \"Of course I'll be at the meeting.\"\n\nSen. John Thune, the GOP whip who is vying to replace McConnell as leader, told The Associated Press that he was interested in hearing from Trump about the fall election. \"I think there's an opportunity there to really make this a big win,\" he said.\n\nAs democracies around the world come under threat from a far-rightward shift, experts warn that the U.S. system, once seemingly immune from authoritarian impulses, is at risk of populist and extremist forces like those that Trump inspired to sack the Capitol.\n\n\"This is just another example of House Republicans bending the knee to Donald Trump,\" said Rep. Pete Aguilar of California, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus.\n\nMaking Jan. 6 a cornerstone of his reelection campaign, Trump celebrates those who stormed the Capitol as \"warriors\" and \"patriots,\" and he has vowed to pardon any number of the more than 1,300 America convicted of crimes for the assault on the seat of U.S. democracy.\n\nMoreover, Trump has vowed to seek retribution by ousting officials at the U.S. Justice Department, which is prosecuting him in a four-count indictment to overturn the election ahead of the Jan. 6 attack and another case over storing classified documents at his Mar-A-Largo home.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nRepublicans, particularly in the House but increasingly in the Senate, are vigorously following his lead, complaining of an unfair justice system. Alongside Trump, the House and Senate GOP campaign arms scored some of their highest fundraising periods yet after a jury found him guilty in the New York hush money case.\n\nWhen former GOP Speaker Paul Ryan on Fox News reiterated this week that he wouldn't be voting for Trump and wished Republicans had another choice for president, he was immediately ostracized by Trump allies.\n\n\"Paul Ryan, you're a piece of garbage,\" said Rep. Troy Nehls, R-Texas. \"We should kick you out of the party.\"\n\nOf the Republicans who voted to impeach Trump over Jan. 6 and convict him on the charge of inciting the insurrection, only a few remain in office.\n\nSen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, and Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, were not expected to attend Thursday's closed-door session with Trump. But Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, had a change of plans and will now join.\n\nAlso Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., said he would likely join the Trump meeting at GOP senators' campaign headquarters, expecting \"he's going to be the next president, so you have to work\" together.\n\nAsked if he was concerned about the direction of the Trump Republican Party, Cassidy: \"Let the day's own troubles be sufficient for the day. You can fill yourself up with anxiety about tomorrow, but will it change a thing? No.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nSen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C., who confronted Trump at times but did not join in the vote to convict him in the Capitol attack, said he did not expect the meeting to be contentious as Republicans hope to seize the Senate majority this fall.\n\n\"Look, we've got to win. And our ability to get a majority in the Senate is intrinsically linked to Trump winning. So we're like, one team, one vision. And I think that will be largely what we talk about,\" Tillis said.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Jill Colvin, Farnoush Amiri, Kevin Freking, Mary Clare Jalonick and Stephen Groves contributed to He has successfully purged the Republican party of critics, silenced most sceptics and enticed once-critical lawmakers aboard his campaign.\n\nA packed room of House Republicans sang Happy Birthday to Trump, who turns 78 on Friday, in a private breakfast meeting at Republican campaign headquarters across the street from the Capitol. The lawmakers gave him a baseball and bat from the annual congressional game, and senators later presented an American flag cake. Trump bragged that even his telephone rallies for lawmakers could draw bigger crowds than mega-popstar Taylor Swift, who has yet to make any endorsement.\n\nIn one remarkable moment, Trump and his most prominent Republican critic, Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, shook hands, and fist-bumped.\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s tremendous unity in the Republican Party,\u201d Trump said in brief remarks at Senate Republican headquarters.\n\nTrump spent about an hour each with House and Senate Republicans delivering free-wheeling remarks, fielding questions and discussing issues - including Russia and immigration, tax cuts and other priorities for a potential second term.\n\nDuring the morning session, Trump said he thinks House Speaker Mike Johnson is doing a \u201cterrific job\u201d, according to a Republican in the private meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it. Trump asked congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene, the speaker\u2019s chief Republican critic, if she was being \u201cnice\u201d to Johnson, another Republican said.\n\n\u201cPresident Trump brought an extraordinary amount of energy, excitement and enthusiasm this morning,\u201d Johnson said after the meeting, noting high fund-raising tallies since the guilty verdict. \u201cWe\u2019re feeling good.\u201d\n\nThe Republican speaker had demurred earlier over whether he has asked Trump to respect the peaceful transfer of presidential power and commit to not doing \u201canother January 6\u201d. \u201cOf course he respects that, we all do, and we\u2019ve all talked about it, ad nauseum.\u201d\n\nMany potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\n\u201cAnybody who thought that this president was going to be down after the sham trial, it\u2019s only giving him even more energy,\u201d said congressman Tom Emmer, the Republican whip. \u201cDonald Trump is crushing this election.\u201d\n\nBut Trump\u2019s private meetings with House and Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol were infused with the symbolism of his return as the US president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of power.\n\n\u201cIt\u2019s frustrating,\u201d said former US Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of January 6, the day when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building in an effort to overturn US President Joe Biden\u2019s election.\n\nDunn spoke of the \u201cirony\u201d of Trump returning to the area and lawmakers now embracing him. \u201cIt just shows the lack of backbone they have when they\u2019re truly putting party and person over country,\u201d Dunn said. \u201cAnd it\u2019s sad.\u201d\n\nBiden was in Italy on Thursday attending a summit of the Group of Seven leading industrialised nations (G7), but the president\u2019s campaign unveiled a new ad blaming Trump for lighting the \u201cfire\u201d of January 6 and threatening democracy.\n\nMany of those who once stood up to Trump are long gone from office and the Republicans who remain seem increasingly enthusiastic about the possibility of him retaking the White House, and the down-ballot windfall that could mean for their own Republican majorities in Congress.\n\nThursday afternoon offered the first encounter in years between Trump and McConnell, who once blamed Trump for the \u201cdisgraceful\u201d attack that he called an \u201cinsurrection\u201d but now endorses the party\u2019s presumptive nominee.\n\nAccording to Senator John Barrasso, who organised the conference meeting, after Trump addressed the group McConnell gave a thumbs up and the two approached each other and exchanged the fist-bump.\n\n\u201cWe had a really positive meeting,\u201d McConnell said. \u201cHe and I got a chance to talk a little bit, shook hands a few times.\u201d\n\nAs democracies around the world come under threat from a far-rightward shift, some analysts warn that the US system, once seemingly immune from authoritarian impulses, is at risk of populist and extremist forces like those that Trump inspired to sack the Capitol.\n\n\u201cThis is just another example of House Republicans bending the knee to Donald Trump,\u201d said congressman Pete Aguilar of California, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus.\n\nMaking January 6 a cornerstone of his reelection campaign, Trump celebrates those who stormed the Capitol as \u201cwarriors\u201d and \u201cpatriots\u201d, and he has vowed to pardon any number of the more than 1,300 convicted of crimes for the assault on the seat of US democracy.\n\nMoreover, Trump has vowed to seek retribution by ousting officials at the US Justice Department, which is prosecuting him in a four-count indictment to overturn the election ahead of the January 6 attack and another case over storing classified documents at his Mar-A-Largo, Florida home.\n\nRepublicans, particularly in the House but increasingly in the Senate, are vigorously following his lead, complaining of an unfair justice system. It is having noticeable results: the House and Senate Republican campaign arms scored some of their highest fundraising periods yet after a jury found him guilty in the New York hush money case.", {"uri": "2024-06-388410408", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "13:09:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T13:09:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T10:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.aol.com/republicans-tout-unity-trump-first-100000089.html", "title": "Republicans to tout 'unity' with Trump in his first visit to Capitol Hill since Jan. 6 attack", "body": "Republicans to tout 'unity' with Trump in his first visit to Capitol Hill since Jan. 6 attack\n\nScott Wong and Sahil Kapur and Frank Thorp V and Kate Santaliz and Syedah Asghar\n\nJune 13, 2024 at 12:00 PM\n\nWASHINGTON -- Three and a half years ago, President Donald Trump incited a violent riot at the Capitol in a bid to overturn Joe Biden's election victory and remain in power, a special House committee concluded after a lengthy investigation.\n\nOn Thursday, Trump will make his first visit to Capitol Hill since before the Jan. 6 attack as Republicans give a hero's welcome to their party's presumptive 2024 nominee.\n\nLess than five months before his rematch with Biden, Trump is scheduled to meet behind closed doors just blocks from the Capitol with House Republicans in the morning and GOP senators in the afternoon as the party discusses campaign messaging and its legislative strategy in 2025.\n\nTrump and Biden are locked in a competitive race, and control of Congress is up for grabs this fall, but many in the GOP express optimism about sweeping the 2024 elections and acting swiftly on Trump's agenda.\n\n\"It will be an expression of unity,\" Sen. Roger Wicker, R-Miss., a past GOP campaign chairman, told NBC News.\n\nEven some critics in the party plan to attend: Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., who voted to convict Trump in the impeachment trial after the Jan. 6 attack, said he thinks he will attend but is still firming up his schedule.\n\n\"The polls say he's going to be our next president, so you got to work with the guy,\" Cassidy said, joking that he does not know what to expect. \"Can you predict what Trump's going to do the next minute? No, of course not.\"\n\nIt will also be the first time since the Capitol riot that Trump will have been in the same room with Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky.; the two have not spoken since December 2020. At the time, McConnell slammed Trump as being \"practically and morally responsible for provoking the events\" of Jan. 6. He has since endorsed Trump for president -- and announced that he will step down as Senate GOP leader after this year.\n\n\"I said three years ago right after the Capitol was attacked that I would support our nominee, regardless of who it was -- including him. I've said earlier this year I support him. He's earned the nomination by the voters all across the country,\" McConnell told reporters Tuesday, without using Trump's name. \"And of course, I'll be at the meeting tomorrow.\"\n\nTrump returns to Washington just after he was convicted of 34 felony counts of falsifying business records related to hush money payments to an adult film star and as he awaits sentencing. Between meetings with House and Senate Republicans, Trump will sit down with CEOs in a meeting with the Business Roundtable, a lobbying group that says it represents more than 200 major companies, as Washington and key industries prepare for the reality that Trump might be president again.\n\nSeveral top contenders to be Trump's running mate will have a chance to catch his attention Thursday, as well. They include GOP Sens. JD Vance of Ohio, Marco Rubio of Florida and Tim Scott of South Carolina.\n\nHouse Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., a top Trump ally who played a key role in the GOP's effort to stop certification of Biden's 2020 victory, predicted that Trump would win a second term and would be \"the most consequential president of the modern era\" as he fixes the \"disaster\" created by the Biden administration.\n\n\"When he comes in, we've got to have a very aggressive first-100-day agenda; the first year will be important. I think we cannot waste a moment, because there are so many things to do,\" Johnson told reporters Wednesday. \"You don't put the cart before the horse, but you do have to be prepared to lead.\"\n\nOther Trump critics in the party are expected to skip the Senate meeting, including Sens. Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, Susan Collins of Maine and Mitt Romney of Utah. All three voted to convict Trump after he was impeached in connection with Jan. 6.\n\nRomney, who is retiring from the Senate this year, said he has a flight to catch at the time of the Trump gathering.\n\n\"I don't give him advice on what to say, and I'm sure he wouldn't listen to my advice anyway,\" Romney told reporters.\n\nSen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C., said he does not read much into McConnell's attending the meeting with Trump.\n\n\"I don't think it's anything more than Mitch showing respect for our presidential nominee,\" Tillis said. \"And showing up for the rest of us in the conference.\"\n\nTrump is not expected to set foot in the Capitol complex itself, which his supporters overran in 2021, during his visit. He will huddle in the morning with House Republicans at the Capitol Hill Club, a private Republican club just steps from the Capitol office buildings. In the afternoon, he will meet with GOP senators at the National Republican Senatorial Committee headquarters after he addresses the Business Roundtable.\n\nSen. Todd Young, R-Ind., who has not endorsed Trump for president, declined to say whether he will attend.\n\n\"No Trump questions,\" Young said, adding that it is a personal rule \"until I decide to make House GOP Conference Chairwoman Rep. Elise Stefanik advised lawmakers early Tuesday of the upcoming meeting with Trump.\n\nIt's a pivotal moment for the indicted former president, weeks before he is to be sentenced after being found guilty in the hush money trial and ahead of the Republican National Convention when he is expected to become the formal GOP nominee for president.\n\nThe Trump campaign did not confirm the meeting with House Republicans, but the senior campaign official said the Senate meeting will be focused on policy issues - including tax cuts.\n\nTrump's return to the GOP campaign offices across from the Capitol, his first since the mob of supporters rioted at the Capitol in 2021, comes as he faces other legal charges, including the four-part federal indictment brought by Justice Department Special Prosecutor Jack Smith in the conspiracy to overturn the 2020 election results.\n\nMost Republicans have endorsed Trump in the expected rematch against Biden, including Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell and other leaders who were critical of him in the aftermath of the 2021 attack.\n\nFormer President Donald Trump speaks during a news conference at Trump Tower, Friday, May 31, 2024, in New York. {"uri": "8176398666", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:34:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:34:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T16:33:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/trump-returns-to-capitol-hill-and-whips-up-republican-lawmakers-a-first-meeting-since-jan/article_48507aaa-a9aa-5265-8cbb-61f20ff30b2d.html", "title": "Trump returns to Capitol Hill and whips up Republican lawmakers, a first meeting since Jan. 6 attack", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Donald Trump made a triumphant return Thursday to Capitol Hill, whipping up House and Senate Republicans in his first meetings since the Jan.6, 2 021 attacks, cheered by GOP lawmakers who find themselves newly energized by his bid to retake the White House.\n\nDespite the federal charges against Trump for conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, and his recent guilty verdict in an unrelated hush money trial, the Republican former president arrived emboldened as the party's presumptive nominee. He has successfully purged the GOP of critics, silenced most skeptics and enticed once-critical lawmakers aboard his MAGA-fueled campaign.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nA packed room of House Republicans sang \"Happy Birthday\" to Trump in the private breakfast meeting at GOP campaign headquarters across the street from the Capitol. The lawmakers gave him a baseball and bat from the annual congressional game. Trump bragged that even his telephone rallies for lawmakers could draw bigger crowds than mega-popstar Taylor Swift, who has yet to make any endorsement.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"President Trump brought an extraordinary amount of energy, excitement and enthusiasm this morning,\" said House Speaker Mike Johnson, noting high fund-raising tallies since the guilty verdict. \"We're feeling good.\"\n\nThe Republican speaker had demurred earlier over whether he's asked Trump to respect the peaceful transfer of presidential power and commit to not doing another Jan. 6. \"Of course he respects that, we all do, and we've all talked about it, ad nauseum.\"\n\nTrump told Johnson Thursday he thinks the speaker is doing a \"terrific job,\" according to a Republican in the private meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it. He asked Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, the speaker's chief Republican critic, if she was being \"nice\" to Johnson, another Republican said.\n\nTrump spent about an hour with House Republicans delivering free-wheeling remarks, fielding questions and discussing issues -- including Russia and immigration and also tax cuts and other priorities for a potential second term. On one major controversial issue, Trump told lawmakers that abortion rules should be left to the states and said he supported exceptions for rape, incest and to save the life of the mother, lawmakers said.\n\nSenate Republicans meet next with Trump in the afternoon.\n\nMany potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"Anybody who thought that this president was going to be down after the sham trial. it's only giving him even more energy,\" said Rep. Tom Emmer, the GOP whip. \"Donald Trump is crushing this election.\"\n\nBut Trump's private meetings with House and Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol are infused with symbolism of his return as the U.S. president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of power.\n\n\"It's frustrating,\" said former U.S. Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of Jan. 6, when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building.\n\nDunn spoke of the \"irony\" of Trump returning to the area and lawmakers now embracing him. \"It just shows the lack of backbone they have when they're truly putting party and person over country,\" he said. \"And it's sad.\"\n\nBiden was overseas Thursday attending a summit of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations, but the president's campaign unveiled a new ad blaming Trump for lighting the \"fire\" of Jan. 6 and threatening democracy.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMany of those who once stood up to Trump are long gone from office and the Republicans who remain seem increasingly enthusiastic about the possibility of him retaking the White House, and the down-ballot windfall that could mean for their own GOP majorities in Congress.\n\nOutgoing Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who once blamed Trump for the \"disgraceful\" attack that he called an \"insurrection\" now endorses the party's presumptive nominee and said: \"Of course I'll be at the meeting.\"\n\nSen. John Thune, the GOP whip who is vying to replace McConnell as leader, told The Associated Press that he was interested in hearing from Trump about the fall election. \"I think there's an opportunity there to really make this a big win,\" he said.\n\nAs democracies around the world come under threat from a far-rightward shift, experts warn that the U.S. system, once seemingly immune from authoritarian impulses, is at risk of populist and extremist forces like those that Trump inspired to sack the Capitol.\n\n\"This is just another example of House Republicans bending the knee to Donald Trump,\" said Rep. Pete Aguilar of California, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMaking Jan. 6 a cornerstone of his reelection campaign, Trump celebrates those who stormed the Capitol as \"warriors\" and \"patriots,\" and he has vowed to pardon any number of the more than 1,300 America convicted of crimes for the assault on the seat of U.S. democracy.\n\nMoreover, Trump has vowed to seek retribution by ousting officials at the U.S. Justice Department, which is prosecuting him in a four-count indictment to overturn the election ahead of the Jan. 6 attack and another case over storing classified documents at his Mar-A-Largo home.\n\nRepublicans, particularly in the House but increasingly in the Senate, are vigorously following his lead, complaining of an unfair justice system. Alongside Trump, the House and Senate GOP campaign arms scored some of their highest fundraising periods yet after a jury found him guilty in the New York hush money case.\n\nWhen former GOP Speaker Paul Ryan on Fox News reiterated this week that he wouldn't be voting for Trump and wished Republicans had another choice for president, he was immediately ostracized by Trump allies.\n\n\"Paul Ryan, you're a piece of garbage,\" said Rep. Troy Nehls, R-Texas. \"We should kick you out of the party.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nOf the Republicans who voted to impeach Trump over Jan. 6 and convict him on the charge of inciting the insurrection, only a few remain in office.\n\nSen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, and Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, were not expected to attend Thursday's closed-door session with Trump. But Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, had a change of plans and will now join.\n\nAlso Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., said he would likely join the Trump meeting at GOP senators' campaign headquarters, expecting \"he's going to be the next president, so you have to work\" together.\n\nAsked if he was concerned about the direction of the Trump Republican Party, Cassidy: \"Let the day's own troubles be sufficient for the day. You can fill yourself up with anxiety about tomorrow, but will it change a thing? No.\"\n\nSen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C., who confronted Trump at times but did not join in the vote to convict him in the Capitol attack, said he did not expect the meeting to be contentious as Republicans hope to seize the Senate majority this fall.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"Look, we've got to win. And our ability to get a majority in the Senate is intrinsically linked to Trump winning. So we're like, one team, one vision. And I think that will be largely what we talk about,\" Tillis said.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Jill Colvin, Farnoush Amiri, Kevin Freking, Mary Clare Jalonick and Stephen Groves contributed to this report.\n\nRead more on the U.S. Election at thestar.com", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Star"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-388813546", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "20:24:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T20:24:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T19:46:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/trump-touts-tremendous-unity-meeting-194642546.html", "title": "Trump touts 'tremendous unity' after meeting with GOP lawmakers", "body": "June 13 (UPI) -- Donald Trump met with Republican lawmakers on Thursday to lay out his second-term agenda as the GOP aims to take back the Senate and the White House.\n\nThe presumptive GOP presidential nominee held a press conference on Capitol Hill with Congressional Republicans, where he affirmed there is \"tremendous unity in the Republican Party.\"\n\n\"We want to see borders. We want to see a strong military. ... We want to see just success for our country, and we don't have success right now,\" Trump said.\n\nTrump said high inflation and open borders are of \"great concern' to Republicans going into the election.\n\nThursday marked the first time Trump met with GOP leaders since his 34 felony convictions from his New York hush-money trial.\n\nEarlier, Trump met with House Republicans in a closed-door meeting at the Capitol Hill Club.\n\nIn the meeting, which comes after the Supreme Court struck down an effort to restrict access to the abortion drug mifepristone, Trump expressed his opinion that abortion access should be decided by the states and that exceptions to restrictions ought to be made in the case of rape, incest or to save the mother's life, according to ABC News.\n\nTrump also told Republicans they could have a 40-seat House majority if they weren't so \"afraid\" of the issue, ABC News reported.\n\nHouse Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., said Trump also had \"very complimentary\" things to say about House Republican leaders and that he told Johnson he was doing a good job, according to the Hill.\n\n\"We have to have continuity in leadership,\" Johnson said.\n\nJohnson has openly embraced Trump while hardline House Republicans such as Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., have attempted to oust him over his habit of toeing the line with Democrats to pass controversial spending bills earlier this year.\n\nIn the meeting with House lawmakers, Trump reportedly told Greene in a joking manner to be nice to Johnson after her failed attempt to vacate the speaker earlier this year, according to the Hill.\n\nDuring the meeting, Trump also promised to lean in hard on international trade tariffs because \"other countries have taken advantage of the United States, and we have tools [to address it],\" Rep. Tom Cole, R-Okla., told the Hill.\n\nTrump then met with Senate Republicans, some of whom voted to convict him in second impeachment trial in 2021, at the National Republican Senatorial Committee headquarters.\n\nSenate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., who was one of the seven to vote to convict Trump, shook hands with the former president and told reporters they had a \"really positive meeting.\"\n\nIt was the first time the two had met since 2020.\n\nSens. Susan Collins, R-Maine, and Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, who also voted to convict Trump in 2021, did not attend the meeting due to prior conflicts, they said.\n\nThursday also marked the first time Trump has been near the U.S. Capitol since the Jan. 6 riot in 2021. His meeting with Republicans prompted an advertisement from the Biden-Harris campaign that highlighted footage from the riot and claimed Trump is trying to \"burn it all down.\"\n\nTrump hit back at Democrats, claiming, \"They are getting away with murder.\"\n\nTrump also is scheduled to join over 200 CEOs in a quarterly meeting with of the Business Roundtable in Washington, D.C.\n\nBusiness Roundtable spokesperson Michael Steel said the group invited both Trump and President Joe Biden to speak, but Biden is currently overseas to attend the G7 Summit. {"uri": "8176728126", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "21:28:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T21:28:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T21:28:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "http://www.bangordailynews.com/2024/06/13/politics/washington/susan-collins-skips-donald-trumps-capitol-hill-meeting-with-republicans/", "title": "Susan Collins skips Donald Trump's Capitol Hill meeting with Republicans", "body": "U.S. Sen. Susan Collins skipped former President Donald Trump's Thursday meeting with Republicans as the party tries to put up a united front entering the November rematch between Trump and President Joe Biden.\n\nIt was Trump's first time meeting with lawmakers on Capitol Hill since the riots of Jan. 6, 2021. Despite pending federal charges against him for conspiring to overturn the 2020 election and his recent guilty verdict in New York, he arrived emboldened as the party's presumptive nominee.\n\nA packed room of House Republicans sang \"Happy Birthday\" to Trump at a private breakfast meeting at the Republican campaign headquarters across the street from the Capitol. Trump and his most prominent Republican critic, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, shook hands and fist-bumped.\n\n\"There's tremendous unity in the Republican Party,\" Trump said in brief remarks at Senate Republican headquarters.\n\nMany of Trump's former critics within the party have been alienated or driven from office. Of the Republicans who voted to impeach Trump over Jan. 6 and convict him on the charge of inciting the insurrection, only a few remain in office.\n\nOne of them is Collins, a Republican who said last year she is not voting for Trump in November. Neither she nor her centrist ally, Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, attended the meeting. A Collins spokesperson cited a private appointment that Collins did not change because it was a campaign meeting, and she is \"not involved in the presidential campaign.\"\n\nAs Washington was buzzing over the Trump summit, her office sent out a news release on the senator's meeting a day earlier with the R&B singer Usher on Type 1 diabetes screenings.\n\nTrump spent about an hour each with House and Senate Republicans delivering free-wheeling remarks, fielding questions and discussing issues from Russia to immigration and tax cuts. During the morning session, Trump said House Speaker Mike Johnson is doing a \"terrific job,\" according to a Republican in the private meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it.\n\nMany potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\nBut Trump's private meetings with House and Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol were infused with the symbolism of his return as the U.S. president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of power.\n\n\"It's frustrating,\" said former U.S. Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of Jan. 6, the day when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building in an effort to overturn Biden's election.\n\nThursday afternoon offered the first encounter in years between Trump and McConnell, who once blamed Trump for the \"disgraceful\" attack that he called an \"insurrection\" but now endorses the party's presumptive nominee.\n\nTrump addressed the situation directly, saying he intends to work with everyone and that McConnell had \"done his best\" as leader, said Sen. Markwayne Mullin, R-Oklahoma, an ally of the former president.\n\nMaking Jan. 6 a cornerstone of his reelection campaign, Trump celebrates those who stormed the Capitol as \"warriors\" and \"patriots,\" and he has vowed to pardon any number of the more than 1,200 people charged with crimes for the assault on the seat of U.S. democracy.\n\nMoreover, Trump has vowed to seek retribution by ousting officials at the U.S. Justice Department, which is prosecuting him in a four-count indictment to overturn the election ahead of the Jan. 6 attack and another case over storing classified documents at his Florida home.\n\nRepublicans, particularly in the House but increasingly in the Senate, are vigorously following his lead, complaining of an unfair justice system. It's having noticeable results: the House and Senate Republican campaign arms scored some of their highest fundraising periods yet after a jury found him guilty in the New York hush money case.", {"uri": "2024-06-388178444", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "09:56:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T09:56:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T09:11:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.aol.com/donald-trump-meeting-house-senate-091148002.html", "title": "Donald Trump is meeting with House, Senate Republicans in DC. Will they lay out a 2025 wish list?", "body": "Donald Trump is meeting with House, Senate Republicans in DC. Will they lay out a 2025 wish list?\n\nRiley Beggin and Ken Tran, USA TODAY\n\nJune 13, 2024 at 11:11 AM\n\nWASHINGTON - Former President Donald Trump will meet with Republican lawmakers Thursday to discuss campaign strategies and lay out their wish list if they defeat Democrats in November.\n\nIt's the first time Trump has returned to Capitol Hill since leaving office nearly four years ago, and the trip provides an opportunity for conservative leaders to plot which policy priorities they'll pursue if reelected.\n\nThe meetings with both House and Senate lawmakers also align with a meeting with the Business Roundtable, a powerful cohort of some of the country's largest companies that will host the former president while he's in the nation's capital. Trump is slated to meet with House Republican lawmakers in the morning at the Capitol Hill Club and Senate Republicans in the afternoon at the National Republican Senatorial Committee office, both locations adjacent to the Capitol grounds.\n\nThe visit comes after Trump was convicted by a New York jury in his hush money trial and weeks before he is slated to be formally nominated at the Republican National Convention. The twin meetings with congressional Republicans are supposed to help shore up unity in the party that has, at times, struggled to agree on major policy priorities, such as providing additional aid to Ukraine.\n\nHowever, some moderate members are expected to skip the meeting, such as Sens. Susan Collins, R-Maine, Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, and Mitt Romney, R-Utah. Several of their peers insisted that's not necessarily a problem.\n\n\"I think there's lots of reasons for people to not show up,\" including scheduling conflicts, said Sen. Kevin Cramer, R-N.D. \"It's a grand opportunity for us all to get together to kick off the official campaign but also to prepare, possibly, for a transition.\"\n\nDonald Trump, Mitch McConnell will meet for the first time in years as GOP leaders gather\n\nTop Republicans in Congress are expected to attend the meetings Thursday. That includes Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., who has not met in-person with the former president since 2020. The two have had a frosty relationship after McConnell accepted the results of the 2020 presidential election and blamed the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol attack on Trump.\n\nMcConnell declined to say if he would bring up the animosity with the former president at the Senate meeting, reiterating that he intended to support the 2024 GOP nominee, whoever it may be. However, the Kentucky Republican declined to even reference Trump by name.\n\n\"I've said earlier this year I support him. He's earned the nomination by the voters all across the country and of course I'll be at the meeting tomorrow,\" McConnell told reporters.\n\nHouse Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., on the other hand, is a stalwart Trump ally, having served on the former president's defense team during his first impeachment trial. The speaker told reporters Wednesday morning he wants to use the meetings to lay out a clear-cut conservative agenda should the GOP sweep the coming elections.\n\n\"When (Trump) comes in, we got to have a very aggressive first 100 days agenda. The first year will be important and I think we cannot waste a moment,\" House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., said\n\nTrump's visit is important for Johnson's leadership post as well. The former president defended the speaker from Georgia Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's threat to oust him last month. At the same time, Trump has occasionally thrown a wrench into Johnson's legislative agenda, including briefly derailing his plans over a controversial spying law in April.\n\nTrump's four sets of criminal charges could also shape the House GOP's legislative agenda this year. A number of Republicans support a bill led by Rep. Russell Fry, R-S.C., that would allow presidents and vice presidents to move civil and criminal state cases to federal court instead. Johnson said he supports the proposal, but a number of Republican lawmakers are skeptical about the legislation. In addition to his New York hush money case, Trump also faces state-level charges in Georgia over allegations he tried to steal the state in the 2020 presidential election.\n\nThe meetings may also serve another purpose: Giving Trump face time with several of the people he is considering as his running mate. That includes Sens. JD Vance, R-Ohio, Tim Scott, R-S.C., and Marco Rubio, R-Fla., as well as House members such as Rep. Elise Stefanik, R-N.Y. and Byron Donalds, R-Fla.\n\nRep. Marc Molinaro, R-N.Y., told reporters he expects to hear Trump give a \"lay of the land as he sees it\" of the 2024 elections. Other lawmakers told USA TODAY they expect the meeting to be critical towards building a working relationship between congressional Republicans and the former president should the GOP take full control of Washington, picking up the White House and the Senate and maintaining control of the House. That kind of sweep would be an uphill battle for either party.\n\n\"We're working on cementing this relationship now so when January 20th comes, we have a plan in place to work together with the White House and Congress,\" Rep. Mark Alford, R-Texas, said, noting a major part of the GOP agenda is renewing Trump's 2017 tax cuts, which expire in 2025.\n\n\"That's the main thing that we need to make sure we talk about: That we communicate for the next few months, have a plan going into January,\" said Sen. Tommy Tuberville, R-Ala. As for what is on the table? \"You name it. All the crap that we had to put up for four years.\"\n\nWhat does Mike Johnson want after 2024?\n\nJohnson also met with Senate Republicans over lunch Wednesday to begin discussions on a potential party-line package to chase next year.\n\nJohnson told reporters after the meeting that he expressed interest in enacting new tax and spending cuts. Tax cuts passed during the Trump administration are set to expire in 2025, which means the next president will have a significant opportunity to rewrite the country's tax code.\n\n\"I think now we're in the education\" phase of teaching members what can and cannot be accomplished using the unique legislative tool known as \"reconciliation,\" said Sen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C. Reconciliation can bypass the Senate's 60-vote threshold for certain budget legislation.\n\nDemocrats used the tool in the first two years of the Biden administration to pass sweeping clean energy tax credits and other policies in the Inflation Reduction Act, a massive piece of legislation that aimed to address issues from transportation and the environment to insulin prices.\n\n\"Then it's appropriate to start talking about, ok, what does a common agenda look like?\" Tillis said of his Republican colleagues. \"This is something we need to do pretty early in Trump's tenure.\"\n\nThis {"uri": "8176570166", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "18:54:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T18:54:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T18:53:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/trump-returns-to-capitol-hill-and-whips-up-republican-lawmakers-in-first-meeting-since-jan/article_48507aaa-a9aa-5265-8cbb-61f20ff30b2d.html", "title": "Trump returns to Capitol Hill and whips up Republican lawmakers in first meeting since Jan. 6 attack", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Donald Trump made a triumphant return Thursday to Capitol Hill, whipping up House and Senate Republicans in his first meetings since the Jan.6, 2021, attacks. He was embraced by GOP lawmakers who find themselves newly energized by his bid to retake the White House.\n\nDespite pending federal charges against Trump for conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, and his recent guilty verdict in an unrelated hush money trial, the Republican former president arrived emboldened as the party's presumptive nominee. He has successfully purged the GOP of critics, silenced most skeptics and enticed once-critical lawmakers aboard his MAGA-fueled campaign.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nA packed room of House Republicans sang \"Happy Birthday\" to Trump in a private breakfast meeting at GOP campaign headquarters across the street from the Capitol. The lawmakers gave him a baseball and bat from the annual congressional game. Trump bragged that even his telephone rallies for lawmakers could draw bigger crowds than mega-popstar Taylor Swift, who has yet to make any endorsement.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"There's tremendous unity in the Republican Party,\" Trump said in brief remarks later at Senate GOP headquarters.\n\nTrump spent about an hour each with House and Senate Republicans delivering free-wheeling remarks, fielding questions and discussing issues -- including Russia and immigration, tax cuts and other priorities for a potential second term.\n\nDuring the morning session, Trump said he thinks House Speaker Mike Johnson is doing a \"terrific job,\" according to a Republican in the private breakfast meeting and granted anonymity to discuss it. Trump asked Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, the speaker's chief Republican critic, if she was being \"nice\" to Johnson, another Republican said.\n\n\"President Trump brought an extraordinary amount of energy, excitement and enthusiasm this morning,\" Johnson said afterward, noting high fund-raising tallies since the guilty verdict. \"We're feeling good.\"\n\nThe Republican speaker had demurred earlier over whether he's asked Trump to respect the peaceful transfer of presidential power and commit to not doing another Jan. 6. \"Of course he respects that, we all do, and we've all talked about it, ad nauseum.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThursday afternoon offered the first encounter in years between Trump and Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell, who once blamed Trump for the \"disgraceful\" attack that he called an \"insurrection\" but now endorses the party's presumptive nominee.\n\nMcConnell said Trump received standing ovations from the senators and the two \"had a really positive meeting.\" The senator said, \"He and I got a chance to talk a little bit, shook hands a few times.\"\n\nMany potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\nOn one major controversial issue, Trump told lawmakers that abortion rules should be left to the states and said he supported exceptions for rape, incest and to save the life of the mother, lawmakers said.\n\n\"Anybody who thought that this president was going to be down after the sham trial. it's only giving him even more energy,\" said Rep. Tom Emmer, the GOP whip. \"Donald Trump is crushing this election.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBut Trump's private meetings with House and Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol were infused with the symbolism of his return as the U.S. president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of power.\n\n\"It's frustrating,\" said former U.S. Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of Jan. 6, the day when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building in an effort to overturn President Joe Biden's election.\n\nDunn spoke of the \"irony\" of Trump returning to the area and lawmakers now embracing him. \"It just shows the lack of backbone they have when they're truly putting party and person over country,\" he said. \"And it's sad.\"\n\nBiden was overseas Thursday attending a summit of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations, but the president's campaign unveiled a new ad blaming Trump for lighting the \"fire\" of Jan. 6 and threatening democracy.\n\nMany of those who once stood up to Trump are long gone from office and the Republicans who remain seem increasingly enthusiastic about the possibility of him retaking the White House, and the down-ballot windfall that could mean for their own GOP majorities in Congress.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nSen. John Thune, the GOP whip who is vying to replace McConnell as leader, told The Associated Press that he was interested in hearing from Trump about the fall election. \"I think there's an opportunity there to really make this a big win,\" he said.\n\nAs democracies around the world come under threat from a far-rightward shift, some analysts warn that the U.S. system, once seemingly immune from authoritarian impulses, is at risk of populist and extremist forces like those that Trump inspired to sack the Capitol.\n\n\"This is just another example of House Republicans bending the knee to Donald Trump,\" said Rep. Pete Aguilar of California, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus.\n\nMaking Jan. 6 a cornerstone of his reelection campaign, Trump celebrates those who stormed the Capitol as \"warriors\" and \"patriots,\" and he has vowed to pardon any number of the more than 1,300 convicted of crimes for the assault on the seat of U.S. democracy.\n\nMoreover, Trump has vowed to seek retribution by ousting officials at the U.S. Justice Department, which is prosecuting him in a four-count indictment to overturn the election ahead of the Jan. 6 attack and another case over storing classified documents at his Mar-A-Largo home.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nRepublicans, particularly in the House but increasingly in the Senate, are vigorously following his lead, complaining of an unfair justice system. Alongside Trump, the House and Senate GOP campaign arms scored some of their highest fundraising periods yet after a jury found him guilty in the New York hush money case.\n\nWhen former GOP Speaker Paul Ryan on Fox News reiterated this week that he wouldn't be voting for Trump and wished Republicans had another choice for president, he was immediately ostracized by Trump allies.\n\n\"Paul Ryan, you're a piece of garbage,\" said Rep. Troy Nehls, R-Texas. \"We should kick you out of the party.\"\n\nOf the Republicans who voted to impeach Trump over Jan. 6 and convict him on the charge of inciting the insurrection, only a few remain in office.\n\nSen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, and Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, had not been expected to attend Thursday's closed-door session with Trump. But Sen. Mitt Romney, R-Utah, had a change of plans and was to join.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAlso Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., said he would likely join the Trump meeting, expecting \"he's going to be the next president, so you have to work\" together.\n\nAsked if he was concerned about the direction of the Trump Republican Party, Cassidy said: \"Let the day's own troubles be sufficient for the day. You can fill yourself up with anxiety about tomorrow, but will it change a thing? No.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Jill Colvin, Farnoush Amiri, Kevin Freking, Mary Clare Jalonick and Stephen Groves contributed to this report.\n\nRead more on the U.S. Election at {"uri": "8174861250", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "19:58:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T19:58:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T19:51:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2741447/", "title": "Trump, seeking to show unity, will meet with Republican lawmakers at Capitol - ExBulletin", "body": "Former President Donald Trump plans to return to Washington on Thursday to meet with congressional Republicans near the U.S. Capitol, as the Republican Party attempts to present a united front and rally around a policy agenda as the election approaches of November.\n\nThe trip will be Trump's first meeting with Republican lawmakers since a jury found him guilty of all 34 counts of falsifying business records in his New York hush money case, making Trump the first former American president convicted of a crime. However, since the historic guilty verdict, Republicans have largely lined up behind Trump, as he and President Biden continue to find themselves engaged in a tight race.\n\nIt will also be Trump's first public visit to the Capitol since the January 6, 2021 insurrection, in which a pro-Trump mob stormed the Capitol complex to prevent the certification of Biden's 2020 election victory Although Trump was not at the Capitol that day, his efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 election, including his actions before and during the attack, are at the heart of the federal charges against him.\n\nAsked Wednesday if he had spoken to Trump about his commitment to a peaceful transfer of power, House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.) said of course. [Trump] respect that, and we all do.\n\n\"We're very happy to welcome back President Trump. There's great anticipation and great excitement here, and I feel great,\" Johnson said, later adding that GOP lawmakers were eager to talk about the plans after November and bouncing off ideas with [Trump] tomorrow.\n\nTrump is first expected to meet with House Republicans at 9:30 a.m. Thursday at the Capitol Hill Club, just steps from the Capitol, followed by another meeting with Senate Republicans also very close to the Capitol at 12:30 p.m.\n\nA Trump campaign official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss the meeting, said it would focus on how Republicans can work together to advance policies to save America .\n\nHouse Republican leaders briefed conference members at their weekly meeting on Wednesday about Trump's visit the next day, urging lawmakers to arrive early at the Capitol Hill Club ahead of the gathering. Few details were given about what might be discussed with Trump, who is the Republican Party's presumptive presidential nominee.\n\nI don't know what the point is [of Trumps visit] East. I found out along with everyone else, Rep. Scott Perry (R-Pa.) said Wednesday morning. So, just happy to entertain the former president and hopefully the next president of the United States. Well, see what he has in mind.\n\nSeveral Republican lawmakers said Wednesday they expected Trump to brief them on what he sees as the top concerns of the American people and to outline a role for how lawmakers could support his re-election efforts over the next five months.\n\nWe don't have time to let personalities get in the way, Rep. Ralph Norman (R-S.C.) said Wednesday, later adding: To me, it's about righting the country, saving the country.\n\nNorman, who supported former U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley in the primary, said he would also continue to push her to become Trump's running mate.\n\nA moderate House Republican, who represents a swing district and spoke on condition of anonymity to freely discuss the meeting, said he was bracing for chaos. But Rep. Nick LaLota (R-N.Y.), a moderate from a swing district, rejected the idea that the Thursday meeting could become tense.\n\n\"I think it will be a meeting focused on morale building and team building, where I expect morale to be good,\" he said.\n\nAsked if he was excited about Trump's visit, Rep. Chip Roy (R-Tex.), one of the former president's main GOP antagonists at the Capitol, said he anticipated definitely to attend. Roy said he thinks Republicans need to have a conversation about what we want to accomplish in Spring 25, to talk about the agenda and policies we should address.\n\nI mean, people keep throwing around phrases like reconciliation and all that, but what's that going to mean? what are we doing? What are we doing about tax policy? What are we actually going to do at the border? Roy said. So we need to be very clear about these things. So I hope to be able to talk about it tomorrow.\n\nRepublican senators were asked to expect to hear directly from President Trump when they meet about his plans for the summer and also share our ideas on a strategic government agenda for 2025, according to an invitation obtained by the Washington Post.\n\nTrump has clashed with Senate Republicans in the past, even though the majority of conference attendees strongly support him. Trump is also considering some conference members as his running mates, including Senators JD Vance of Ohio and Tim Scott of South Carolina.\n\nSenate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) plans to attend the meeting, which will mark the first time he and Trump have spoken since shortly after the 2020 election.\n\nMcConnell broke with Trump over his refusal to accept the results of the 2020 election and over the Jan. 6 attack, for which McConnell called Trump practically and morally responsible. Trump also later attacked McConnell's wife, former Trump Cabinet Secretary Elaine Chao, in racist terms. But McConnell, who is retiring as leader after the 2024 election, has already supported Trump's re-election, saying it's no surprise that as a candidate he has my support.\n\nAt least one Senate Republican who disagrees with Trump will not attend: Sen. Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, who voted to convict him after the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol. She told reporters this week that she had a conflict and could not attend Thursday's meeting.\n\nSenate Majority Leader Charles E. Schumer (D-N.Y.) disparaged the Republican Party's agenda ahead of the meeting Wednesday, saying Republicans' only policy idea was to recycle the same Trump tax cuts which proved to be unsuccessful seven years ago.\n\nTrump demonstrated his power over Senate Republicans from afar when he helped defeat bipartisan border security legislation earlier this year that would have cracked down on asylum applications at the U.S. border. Mexico.\n\nAlthough Sen. James Lankford (R-Okla.) led the GOP negotiations on the bipartisan legislation, after Trump made his opposition clear, Senate Republicans overwhelmingly abandoned the bill. Senate Republicans rejected the bill a second time last month.\n\nSome moderate House Republicans are still considering not attending their meeting with Trump, which could dampen his attempt to unify the conference. Trump is aware of GOP disunity, according to Rep. Byron Donalds (R-Fla.), who said he speaks to Trump frequently.\n\nBut Donalds, who is reportedly being considered as Trump's running mate, encouraged even lawmakers critical of Trump to attend the meeting.\n\nI think if you just want to be a distraction for the sake of distractions, he has little patience for that but frankly, I have little patience for that, Donalds said Wednesday. So I think members should introduce themselves. They should leave. It will be a full house.\n\nRep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Ga.), one of Trump's top allies in the House, downplayed the possibility of tensions resulting Thursday from the presence of figures such as Rep. {"uri": "2024-06-388504747", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "14:32:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T14:32:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T12:41:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/donald-trump-back-washington-meetings-040016916.html", "title": "Donald Trump back in Washington for meetings with vice presidential contenders, congressional allies and former foes", "body": "Former President Donald Trump is back in Washington for the first time since becoming the presumptive Republican nominee as well as a convicted felon, holding a pair of significant, closed-door meetings with key congressional allies, vice presidential hopefuls and even a few former outspoken opponents - all of whom are expected to line up behind him this fall.\n\nA bitter primary and general election cycle muddied by Trump's ongoing legal troubles have given Republicans little opportunity to sync up over the policies and proposals that generally drive an election year.\n\n\"He'll come and lead the team,\" GOP Rep. Matt Gaetz of Florida, a fierce Trump ally, told CNN. \"I think it's gonna be a pep rally environment for the former and future president.\"\n\nAhead of the meeting, Texas Republican Sen. John Cornyn noted it would be \"nice\" to \"get everybody singing from the same sheet of music.\" Cornyn has previously criticized Trump and said he preferred to see the GOP move in a different direction, before ultimately endorsing the former president in January.\n\nSenior campaign advisers said Trump was expected to express his campaign priorities and policies -- focusing on the economy, inflation, tax cuts and immigration during his meetings, first with House Republicans at the Capitol Hill club in the morning and then with Senate Republicans at the nearby National Republican Senatorial Committee building. He'll also reiterate his commitment to not cutting entitlement programs for seniors like Social Security and Medicare.\n\n\"We want to get everyone on the same page talking about policy, including the economy and inflation,\" one senior Trump adviser told CNN. \"That's the biggest factor in all the polling, it's the biggest thing people are worried about.\"\n\nTrump, who will be accompanied by his two top campaign officials, Susie Wiles and Chris LaCivita, among others, is also expected to discuss details around a potential second term agenda, including how to immediately implement his policy goals, with the help of lawmakers, if reelected to the White House. Meanwhile, House Republicans have been eager for information to help them jumpstart legislative action on Capitol Hill next year.\n\n\"We want to be part of that plan to hit the ground running,\" GOP Rep. Darrell Issa of California told CNN. \"When most presidents get elected, they anticipate they have eight years. This president knows he has four.\"\n\nAdvisers said the meetings would also be an opportunity to allow lawmakers to ask questions or bring up any pressing matters ahead of the November election, with Trump planning to open the floor to members after his remarks.\n\nHouse Majority Steve Scalise told CNN he's already talked to Trump directly about using a special budgetary tool to avoid the 60-vote threshold in the Senate - known as reconciliation - to advance tax cuts, border wall funding and other priorities if Republicans control all of Washington.\n\nSome of Trump's plans for a second term agenda have been outlined by the former President himself during rallies and interviews, including mass deportations of undocumented immigrants and leaving reproductive rights to the states, but other elements have been only proposed vaguely or behind closed doors, and leaked out by media outlets.\n\nTrump's reception among House and Senate Republicans is likely to vary\n\nSen. John Barrasso, the third-ranking Senate Republican, invited the full GOP conference to the Thursday event.\n\nHowever, some senators skeptical of Trump would not commit to attending. Sens. Lisa Murkowski of Alaska and Susan Collins of Maine, among a handful of GOP senators who have not endorsed Trump's 2024 election bid, are not attending, citing scheduling conflicts. Sen. Todd Young of Indiana wouldn't say if he was planning to attend, adding that he wasn't talking about Trump this week.\n\nThough Trump won't be inside the US Capitol building, his appearance on the Hill will also mark his first time meeting with some key Republicans since the January 6, 2021, insurrection there, including Senate GOP Leader Mitch McConnell.\n\nMcConnell, who has maintained an icy relationship with the former president ever since the Capitol attack, told CNN he will attend the meeting. The two have not spoken since the electoral college certified Joe Biden's victory in December 2020, though McConnell endorsed Trump earlier this year.\n\nAny tension is likely to be balanced out by some of Trump's biggest cheerleaders and potential vice-presidential picks, who will also be in attendance, including Sens. Tim Scott, Marco Rubio and JD Vance.\n\nOf those attending, many said they were looking for a more urgent focus, including Trump laying out a specific strategy to beat President Joe Biden.\n\n\"I will be honest with you. To think that we are going to talk a whole lot about a governing agenda on Thursday seems a little na\u00efve to me. That's like measuring the curtains,\" said Sen. Thom Tillis, a Republican from North Carolina. \"This is about winning in November, and my guess is we may touch on the agenda next year, but that's a multi-variable equation not the least of which is how well we do here in Congress to take the gavels back.\"\n\nOthers see it as an opportunity to try and reset the party after months of internal tensions over the future of House Speaker Mike Johnson, aiding the war in Ukraine and the divisions over the best strategy on border security.\n\nIn the House, a chamber that has traditionally been friendlier to Trump, members said the former president will find a supportive and enthusiastic audience, including some dressed to impress.\n\n\"I just think he wants to get everybody on the same page,\" said Sen. Markwayne Mullin, a key Trump ally. \"There's been a little tension there in the Senate. And so it's just trying to keep the tension from building and saying our focus is Joe Biden and this administration, not each other.\"\n\nGOP Rep. Troy Nehls said he has several different Trump ties to choose from, though he complained that his gold, Trump-branded sneakers are back in Texas.\n\n\"He will know that I support him 110%, and I will do everything I can to fight like hell to make sure that he's the next president,\" Nehls said.\n\nRep. Elise Stefanik, who - as Republican conference chair - was in charge of organizing the House meeting, will also chair the event. Stefanik is one of a short list of vice presidential hopefuls to receive vetting materials from the Trump campaign. Rep. Byron Donalds is also on that list and is expected to attend Thursday.\n\nTrump's visit comes as House GOP leadership is facing increasing pressure from the right flank to go after the Justice Department and defend Trump in the wake of his hush money conviction in New York.\n\nOne legislative proposal Republican leaders are now actively pursuing is a bill that would allow current and former presidents to move state-level cases to federal court. The legislation passed out of committee last September, but GOP leaders only started formally whipping the bill this week - on the eve of Trump's Capitol Hill visit and two weeks after his conviction.\n\nOne thing both House and Senate Republicans agreed on: Trump was unlikely to stay on message.\n\nWhen asked if they believe Trump will discuss policy plans and campaign strategy and while avoiding airing his grievances, one GOP lawmaker told CNN, \"You know the answer to that. It ain't in his DNA.\"\n\n\"What do I expect? You have no idea what Trump is going to talk about. It's just totally unpredictable,\" said Sen. Chuck Grassley, a Republican from Iowa.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [{"uri": "melanie_zanona@yahoo.com", "name": "Melanie Zanona", "type": {"uri": "8176551664", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "18:38:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T18:38:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T18:36:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://weisradio.com/2024/06/13/trump-assails-doj-in-washington-strategy-session-with-republicans/", "title": "Trump assails DOJ in Washington strategy session with Republicans - WEIS | Local & Area News, Sports, & Weather", "body": "(WASHINGTON) -- Donald Trump is making a rare appearance in Washington on Thursday to lay out his second-term agenda to Republican lawmakers as he continues to stress party unity in the wake of his historic felony conviction and a month from becoming the party's official nominee.\n\nThe former president is just blocks away from the U.S. Capitol to attend a slate of meetings with GOP allies.\n\nFirst, he huddled with House Republicans at the Capitol Hill Club. The meeting was behind closed doors, but multiple sources told ABC News the former president praised House Speaker Mike Johnson as doing a \"good job.\"\n\nTrump also criticized the Department of Justice as \"dirty bastards\" as he aired grievances about his legal challenges.\n\nThe meeting unfolded as the Supreme Court handed down a major decision preserving access to the abortion pill mifepristone. Sources told ABC News Trump did not mention the decision directly, but did discuss his view that abortion access should be decided by the states. He also insisted he believed in three exceptions to abortion restrictions: rape, incest and to save the life of the mother.\n\nPolitically, Trump told Republicans they could have a 40-seat majority in the House if they weren't so \"afraid\" of the issue, according to sources.\n\nHe also went after Democrats like former Speaker Nancy Pelosi and former Rep. Liz Cheney, sources said. Both Pelosi and Cheney, despite being on opposite sides of the aisle, are staunch critics of the former president.\n\nLater on Thursday, Trump will meet with Senate Republicans at the National Republican Senatorial Committee headquarters, where he will hold a news conference afterward.\n\nDuring the meetings, campaign officials say Trump will lay out his policy plans on immigration, entitlement programs and the economy.\n\n\"Looking ahead at the policies that will save the nation such as Trump's commitment to no impact on seniors with any cuts to Social Security or Medicare, policies that actually secure our borders and make our communities safe again, and an America first foreign policy that reclaims peace through strength and world leadership, and economic policies of lower taxes that reignite the vibrant trump economy we had just a few years ago,\" a campaign official said.\n\nTrump's last visit with Republicans happened while he was president in September 2020, when he gave remarks at the same members-only Republican club.\n\nTrump has stayed off the U.S. Capitol campus entirely since he left office shortly after the Jan. 6, 2021, attack. The closest he's come is when he met the executive board of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters near the Capitol building on Jan. 31.\n\nSenate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell is expected to attend the Thursday meeting between Trump and Senate Republicans.\n\nWhile Johnson and Trump have worked together on key issues since Johnson's rise to the speakership last fall, it will be the first time since 2020 that McConnell and Trump meet face-to-face.\n\nMcConnell and Trump have a rocky relationship, heightened after McConnell recognized President Joe Biden's victory in the wake of Trump's efforts to overturn the 2020 election.\n\nMcConnell, asked on Wednesday if he planned to \"confront\" Trump about their disagreements, dodged the question and repeated his usual support for the Republican \"nominee.\"\n\n\"I said three years ago, right after the Capitol was attacked, that I would support our nominee regardless of who it was -- including him,\" McConnell told reporters. \"I've said earlier this year, I support him -- he's earned the nomination by the voters all across the country. And of course, I'll be at the meeting tomorrow.\"\n\nJohnson has openly embraced Trump, who was crucial in supporting him when he faced the threat of being ousted threat by conservative GOP House hard-liners, saying coordination with Trump is important heading into November's election and a potential second Trump presidency.\n\n\"I think it's important for the country, to have us, to have close coordination,\" Johnson said at a news conference on Wednesday. \"I believe he'll have, can be, the most consequential president of the modern era, because we have to fix effectively every area of public policy.\"\n\nAt that news conference, Johnson also told ABC News he supports a bill that would allow current or former presidents to move state charges against them into federal court -- a measure aimed at showing support for Trump after being found guilty in his hush money trial in a New York state court.\n\n\"I think that's an idea that makes sense. It makes sense to most Republicans, and I think almost everyone will be in favor of that,\"\n\nAfter the Thursday morning meeting, Johnson said that Trump \"didn't bring up that specific piece of legislation.\"\n\n\"He did talk about his concern about the lawfare that's been waged against him -- and we all know it -- and I made the point in my introduction that it's backfired fantastically,\" Johnson said. \"President Trump has become a symbol of pushing back against corruption, the deep state of the weaponization of judicial system and that's a very encouraging development. So, I think that he made the point every time they indicted him, his polls went up.\"\n\nHowever, not every Republican is set to fully welcome back Trump when he comes to the nation's capital.\n\nSens. Susan Collins and Lisa Murkowski, who have been vocal Trump critics, have blamed previous conflicts as a reason for why they couldn't attend the meeting with Trump.\n\nSen. Mitt Romney, who had earlier said he needed to catch a flight, at midday Thursday said the flight had been canceled and he would be there.\n\nAll three voted with Republicans to impeach Trump for his actions related to Jan. 6.\n\nThe group of political meetings comes as Trump is scheduled to be in Washington D.C. to participate in a moderated discussion at a quarterly meeting of the Business Roundtable, a group consisting of more than 200 CEOs. Business Roundtable spokesman Michael Steel said the group invited both presumptive presidential nominees, but with Biden overseas to attend the G7 summit, White House chief of staff Jeff Zients is
