{"uri": "8175777049", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "10:04:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T10:04:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T10:03:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2024/06/13/first-time-since-jan-6-trump-comes-capitol-hill/", "title": "Analysis | For the first time since Jan. 6, Trump comes to Capitol Hill", "body": "\"I have been asked questions by about 20 reporters since then, 19 of the 20 have asked me whether I'm going to lunch,\" the GOP senator from Alaska said Wednesday.\n\n\"Lunch,\" as it were, is Thursday's gathering of Senate Republicans with their presumptive presidential nominee, Donald Trump, whom Murkowski voted to convict in an impeachment trial the month after the ex-president's supporters attacked the Capitol in an attempt to overturn the 2020 election.\n\nThat happened on Jan. 6, 2021, the day pro-Trump rioters stormed the Capitol in an attempt to prevent the certification of Joe Biden's victory. Thursday marks Trump's first trip back following that fateful day less than four years ago in the midst of a campaign he hopes will return him to Washington and the White House.\n\nSince then, Trump and many GOP lawmakers have tried to revise the history of that day and suggested that some of the rioters are political \"hostages,\" some of whom he plans to pardon. In Las Vegas last weekend, he claimed baselessly \"they were warriors but they were really, more than anything else, they're victims of what happened.\"\n\nBut with few exceptions, his incendiary rhetoric around a seminal moment in American political history has landed on the site of the attack with silence or even support from Republicans.\n\nLike several anti-Trump Republicans, Murkowski has found other plans and will not attend the luncheon at the National Republican Senatorial Committee a couple blocks from the Capitol. But she's already fed up with how much Trump has once again hijacked the events of this week, just like he did every week he was in the Oval Office.\n\n\"So it's like, once again, it's all about Trump all the time,\" the 22-year incumbent said Wednesday.\n\nAcross the Capitol, Rep. Jake Auchincloss (D-Mass.) paused 16 seconds reflecting on what it meant to have Trump back on Capitol Hill, the first meeting taking place Thursday morning with the House GOP in its campaign headquarters.\n\n\"It's an astounding example of GOP amnesia,\" Auchincloss finally said, pausing another dozen seconds before saying something else. \"It was a turning point when the GOP didn't turn on him.\"\n\nFor Auchincloss, who led Marine infantry units in Afghanistan, Jan. 6 was his third full day in Congress, a seminal moment that has shaped his views of life in the Capitol ever since. He used the votes on certifying Biden's victory as a measuring stick about which Republicans he would work with, at times refusing to consider crossing the aisle if the GOP lawmaker had voted to deny the results of a legitimate election.\n\nTrump does not plan to be on official congressional grounds Thursday, but he will be a stone's throw away for the first time since he was president. It will be the closest he has come to visiting since he tried to get the Secret Service and his aides to let him join his supporters in a trip there during the Capitol attack.\n\nRoughly 250 Republicans will attend the two meetings with the ex-president, supporting his attempt to formally return to the Capitol for a Jan. 20, 2025, inauguration ceremony.\n\nFor those supportive Republicans, Trump's visits are just part of the normal routine. Every four years the party out of power selects a nominee, and then he or she treks to Capitol Hill, hoping to forge unity for the election and plot a policy agenda.\n\n\"I think it's important for us to get together and make sure that we have an agenda coming in, so when he gets elected -- I believe that he will -- we're ready to go,\" said Sen. John Barrasso (Wyo.), the No. 3 GOP leader who will serve as the official host of the meeting.\n\nBut nothing with Trump is ever normal. Just two weeks ago a Manhattan jury convicted the former president on 34 felony counts for filing false business records over a hush money payment to cover up an alleged extramarital affair.\n\nSome of the same Capitol Police and D.C. police who clashed with his violent supporters -- about 140 officers were injured, while three died in the days after Jan. 6 -- will be detailed to provide security for Trump and lawmakers around the meetings.\n\nWhen his motorcade leaves the House GOP meeting, Trump will probably drive past the Supreme Court, which is slated to rule on his bid to exempt himself from two other pending federal criminal trials.\n\nWhen he huddles with Senate Republicans, Trump will sit just eight-tenths of a mile from the E. Barrett Prettyman U.S. Courthouse, where he will go on trial for his involvement in attempting to overturn the 2020 election, depending on the Supreme Court decision.\n\nAfter House Democrats voted to impeach him, a week after the Capitol insurrection, many believed they had dispatched with Trump in the political sense. After they led a year-long investigation into those events, the Justice Department got moving and eventually indicted the ex-president.\n\nBut those indictments only rallied conservative voters around Trump, turning his bid for this year's GOP nomination into a cakewalk, and Trump's legal strategy managed to delay the federal trials until likely past Election Day.\n\nThese Democrats view Thursday's visit as the final genuflection by congressional Republicans, a group that stands ready to allow Trump to win the White House and shut down the criminal cases against him.\n\n\"Justice still hasn't completely been served. I mean, until, everybody is held accountable, it's still going to feel incomplete and it's still going to feel unsettled,\" said Rep. Pete Aguilar (Calif.), the No. 3 Democratic leader who served on the select committee that investigated Trump's actions.\n\nTrump has always found greater support among House Republicans, so his morning huddle is likely to be akin to a pep rally. Their ranks have turned over so quickly in this political era that a large majority took office after his shocking presidential victory eight years ago.\n\nHouse Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.), who first won in 2016, authored a legal brief in December 2020 that a majority of the House GOP signed onto, trying to invalidate Biden's win. Johnson was one of a couple dozen Republicans who sycophantishly headed to New York during the trial to show public support for Trump.\n\nEven House Republicans in swing districts came out with strong statements of support after the Manhattan conviction.\n\nSenate Republicans, most of whom hold traditional conservative views, have always had a more distant relationship with the former reality-TV star. But Trump is unlikely to face a hostile audience.\n\nOf the four remaining Senate Republicans who voted to convict Trump in the 2021 impeachment trial, only Sen. Bill Cassidy (R-La.) is expected to attend the meeting Thursday. And, perhaps thinking ahead to his 2026 election, Cassidy has fallen in line.\n\n\"The polls say he's going to be our next president, so you got to work with him,\" Cassidy told reporters.\n\nTrump's last official visit to Senate Republicans appears to have been in May 2020, at the height of pandemic response. The news conference afterward led Trump into discussions about his weight, his support of a dangerous and unproven drug for fighting the coronavirus, his desire to fire certain State Department officials and broadsides against U.S. intelligence programs.\n\n\"He's always going to do the unexpected,\" Cassidy said, waxing philosophical about the future of his party under Trump. \"You can fill yourself up with anxiety about tomorrow, but will it change a thing? No, not at all.\"\n\nSens. Susan Collins (R-Maine) and Mitt Romney (R-Utah), who joined Murkowski and Cassidy in voting to convict Trump, have found other plans for lunch.\n\nSen. Todd Young (R-Ind.), whose GOP political role models come from the Ronald Reagan and John McCain wing, has declared he will not support Trump in November. He refused to say where he will have lunch Thursday.\n\n\"No Trump questions today,\" Young told reporters.\n\nSenate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) has not been in Trump's presence for almost four years. The two have not spoken since McConnell called him in mid-December 2020 to say he would recognize Biden's victory, and ever since Trump has regularly ridiculed the longest-serving Senate leader.\n\nAsked about Thursday's meeting, McConnell gave a vintage comment that expressed support for Trump without ever saying his name. \"He's earned the nomination by the voters all across the country,\" he said.\n\nFor Murkowski, the entire experience is a bit of political PTSD, seeing the Trump circus come back to town and consume Capitol Hill.\n\n\"All of a sudden everything else stops,\" she said, \"because they all want to know: Are you going to lunch, what do you think he's going to say, what are your expectations?\"", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8176139868", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "13:42:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T13:42:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T13:41:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.dailyherald.com/20240613/nation-and-world-politics/for-the-first-time-since-jan-6-trump-comes-to-capitol-hill/", "title": "For the first time since Jan. 6, Trump comes to Capitol Hill", "body": "Republican presidential candidate former President Donald Trump speaks Sunday at a campaign rally in Las Vegas. Associated Press\n\nSen. Lisa Murkowski got flashbacks upon returning to the Capitol on Tuesday facing an endless stream of questions about one topic.\n\n\"I have been asked questions by about 20 reporters since then, 19 of the 20 have asked me whether I'm going to lunch,\" the GOP senator from Alaska said Wednesday.\n\n\"Lunch,\" as it were, is Thursday's gathering of Senate Republicans with their presumptive presidential nominee, Donald Trump, whom Murkowski voted to convict in an impeachment trial the month after the ex-president's supporters attacked the Capitol in an attempt to overturn the 2020 election.\n\nThat happened on Jan. 6, 2021, the day pro-Trump rioters stormed the Capitol in an attempt to prevent the certification of Joe Biden's victory. Thursday marks Trump's first trip back after that fateful day less than four years ago in the midst of a campaign he hopes will return him to Washington and the White House.\n\nSince then, Trump and many GOP lawmakers have tried to revise the history of that day and suggested that some of the rioters are political \"hostages,\" some of whom he plans to pardon. In Las Vegas last weekend, he claimed baselessly that \"they were warriors but they were really, more than anything else, they're victims of what happened.\"\n\nBut with few exceptions, his incendiary rhetoric around a seminal moment in American political history has landed on the site of the attack with silence or even support from Republicans.\n\nLike several anti-Trump Republicans, Murkowski has found other plans and will not attend the luncheon at the National Republican Senatorial Committee a couple blocks from the Capitol. But she's already fed up with how much Trump has once again hijacked the events of this week, just like he did every week he was in the Oval Office.\n\n\"So it's like, once again, it's all about Trump all the time,\" the 22-year incumbent said Wednesday.\n\nAcross the Capitol, Rep. Jake Auchincloss, a Massachusetts Democrat, paused 16 seconds reflecting on what it meant to have Trump back on Capitol Hill, the first meeting taking place Thursday morning with the House GOP in its campaign headquarters.\n\n\"It's an astounding example of GOP amnesia,\" Auchincloss finally said, pausing another dozen seconds before saying something else. \"It was a turning point when the GOP didn't turn on him.\"\n\nFor Auchincloss, who led Marine infantry units in Afghanistan, Jan. 6 was his third full day in Congress, a seminal moment that has shaped his views of life in the Capitol ever since. He used the votes on certifying Biden's victory as a measuring stick about which Republicans he would work with, at times refusing to consider crossing the aisle if the GOP lawmaker had voted to deny the results of a legitimate election.\n\nTrump does not plan to be on official congressional grounds Thursday, but he will be a stone's throw away for the first time since he was president. It will be the closest he has come to visiting since he tried to get the Secret Service and his aides to let him join his supporters in a trip there during the Capitol attack.\n\nRoughly 250 Republicans will attend the two meetings with the ex-president, supporting his attempt to formally return to the Capitol for a Jan. 20, 2025, inauguration ceremony.\n\nFor those supportive Republicans, Trump's visits are just part of the normal routine. Every four years the party out of power selects a nominee, and then he or she treks to Capitol Hill, hoping to forge unity for the election and plot a policy agenda.\n\n\"I think it's important for us to get together and make sure that we have an agenda coming in, so when he gets elected -- I believe that he will -- we're ready to go,\" said Wyoming Sen. John Barrasso, the No. 3 GOP leader who will serve as the official host of the meeting.\n\nBut nothing with Trump is ever normal. Just two weeks ago, a Manhattan jury convicted the former president on 34 felony counts for filing false business records over a hush money payment to cover up an alleged extramarital affair.\n\nSome of the same Capitol Police and D.C. police who clashed with his violent supporters -- about 140 officers were injured, while three died in the days after Jan. 6 -- will be detailed to provide security for Trump and lawmakers around the meetings.\n\nWhen his motorcade leaves the House GOP meeting, Trump will probably drive past the Supreme Court, which is slated to rule on his bid to exempt himself from two other pending federal criminal trials.\n\nWhen he huddles with Senate Republicans, Trump will sit just eight-tenths of a mile from the E. Barrett Prettyman U.S. Courthouse, where he will go on trial for his involvement in attempting to overturn the 2020 election, depending on the Supreme Court decision.\n\nAfter House Democrats voted to impeach him, a week after the Capitol insurrection, many believed they had dispatched with Trump in the political sense. After they led a yearlong investigation into those events, the Justice Department got moving and eventually indicted the ex-president.\n\nBut those indictments only rallied conservative voters around Trump, turning his bid for this year's GOP nomination into a cakewalk, and Trump's legal strategy managed to delay the federal trials until probably past Election Day.\n\nThese Democrats view Thursday's visit as the final genuflection by congressional Republicans, a group that stands ready to allow Trump to win the White House and shutdown the criminal cases against him.\n\n\"Justice still hasn't completely been served. I mean, until everybody is held accountable, it's still going to feel incomplete and it's still going to feel unsettled,\" said California Rep. Pete Aguilar, the No. 3 Democratic leader who served on the select committee that investigated Trump's actions.\n\nTrump has always found greater support among House Republicans, so his morning huddle is likely to be akin to a pep rally. Their ranks have turned over so quickly in this political era that a large majority took office after his shocking presidential victory eight years ago.\n\nHouse Speaker Mike Johnson, a Louisiana Republican who first won in 2016, wrote a legal brief in December 2020 that a majority of the House GOP signed onto, trying to invalidate Biden's win. Johnson was one of a couple dozen Republicans who sycophantishly headed to New York during the trial to show public support for Trump.\n\nEven House Republicans in swing districts came out with strong statements of support after the Manhattan conviction.\n\nSenate Republicans, most of whom hold traditional conservative views, have always had a more distant relationship with the former reality-TV star. But Trump is unlikely to face a hostile audience.\n\nOf the four remaining Senate Republicans who voted to convict Trump in the 2021 impeachment trial, only Sen. Bill Cassidy, a Louisiana Republican, is expected to attend the meeting Thursday. And, perhaps thinking ahead to his 2026 election, Cassidy has fallen in line.\n\n\"The polls say he's going to be our next president, so you got to work with him,\" Cassidy told reporters.\n\nTrump's last official visit to Senate Republicans appears to have been in May 2020, at the height of pandemic response. The news conference afterward led Trump into discussions about his weight, his support of a dangerous and unproven drug for fighting the coronavirus, his desire to fire certain State Department officials and broadsides against U.S. intelligence programs.\n\n\"He's always going to do the unexpected,\" Cassidy said, waxing philosophical about the future of his party under Trump. \"You can fill yourself up with anxiety about tomorrow, but will it change a thing? No, not at all.\"\n\nSens. Susan Collins, a Maine Republican, and Mitt Romney, a Utah Republican who joined Murkowski and Cassidy in voting to convict Trump, have also found other plans for lunch.\n\nSen. Todd Young, an Indiana Republican whose GOP political role models come from the Ronald Reagan and John McCain wing, has declared that he will not support Trump in November. He refused to say where he will have lunch Thursday.\n\n\"No Trump questions today,\" Young told reporters.\n\nSenate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, has not been in Trump's presence for almost four years. The two have not spoken since McConnell called him in mid-December 2020 to say he would recognize Biden's victory, and ever since Trump has regularly ridiculed the longest-serving Senate leader.\n\nAsked about Thursday's meeting, McConnell gave a vintage comment that expressed support for Trump without ever saying his name. \"He's earned the nomination by the voters all across the country,\" he said.\n\nFor Murkowski, the entire experience is a bit of political PTSD, seeing the Trump circus come back to town and consume Capitol Hill.\n\n\"All of a sudden everything else stops,\" she said, \"because they all want to know: Are you going to lunch, what do you think he's going to say, what are your expectations?\"", "source": {"uri": "dailyherald.com", "dataType": Matt Gaetz of Florida, a fierce Trump ally, told CNN. I think this is going to be a pep rally environment for the former and future president.\n\nBefore the meeting, Texas Republican Sen. John Cornyn said it would be nice if everyone sang from the same sheet of music. Cornyn previously criticized Trump and said he preferred to see the Republican Party move in a different direction, before ultimately supporting the former president in January.\n\nTop campaign advisers said Trump is expected to articulate his campaign priorities and policies focused on the economy, inflation, tax cuts and immigration in his meetings, first with Republican Party members. Room at the Capitol Hill club in the morning, then with Senate Republicans at the neighboring National. Republican Senatorial Committee Building. Hell also reiterates his commitment to not eliminating senior benefit programs like Social Security and Medicare.\n\nWe want everyone to be on the same page when talking about policy, including the economy and inflation, a senior Trump adviser told CNN. It's the biggest factor in all the polls, it's the biggest thing that worries people.\n\nTrump, who will be accompanied by his two top campaign officials, Susie Wiles and Chris LaCivita, among others, is also expected to discuss the details of a possible agenda for a second term, including how to immediately implement his policy goals, with the help of legislators. if he is re-elected to the White House. Meanwhile, House Republicans were hungry for information to help them jumpstart legislative action at the Capitol next year.\n\nWe want to be part of this plan to be operational, Republican Party Rep. Darrell Issa of California told CNN. When most presidents are elected, they anticipate that they will have eight years. This president knows he has four.\n\nAdvisers said the meetings would also be an opportunity for lawmakers to ask questions or raise pressing topics ahead of the November election, with Trump planning to open the floor to members after his remarks.\n\nHouse majority Steve Scalise told CNN he has already spoken directly with Trump about using a special budget tool to avoid the 60-vote threshold in the Senate, known as reconciliation, to make advance tax cuts, border wall funding and other priorities if Republicans control all of Washington.\n\nSome of Trump's plans for a second term have been outlined by the former president himself in rallies and interviews, including mass deportations of undocumented immigrants and leaving reproductive rights to the states, but d Other elements were proposed only vaguely or behind closed doors, and were disclosed. relayed by the media.\n\nTrump's reception among House and Senate Republicans likely to vary\n\nSen. John Barrasso, the third-ranking Republican in the Senate, invited the entire GOP conference to Thursday's event.\n\nHowever, some senators skeptical of Trump have not committed to attending. Sen. Lisa Murkowski, one of the few Republican senators who did not support Trump's bid in the 2024 election, said she would not participate in the election due to a conflict. Sen. Todd Young of Indiana would not say whether he planned to attend, adding that he was not talking about Trump this week.\n\nAlthough Trump will not be inside the U.S. Capitol building, his appearance on the Hill will also mark his first meeting with some key Republicans since the January 6, 2021 insurrection, including Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell.\n\nMcConnell, who has had a frosty relationship with the former president since the Capitol attack, told CNN he would attend the meeting. The two have not spoken since the Electoral College certified Joe Biden's victory in December 2020, but McConnell supported Trump earlier this year.\n\nAny tension will likely be offset by some of Trump's biggest cheerleaders and potential vice presidential picks, who will also be in attendance, including Senators Tim Scott, Marco Rubio and JD Vance.\n\nAmong attendees, many said they were looking for a more pressing priority, including Trump laying out a specific strategy to beat President Joe Biden.\n\nI'll be honest with you. To think that we are going to talk a lot about the government agenda on Thursday seems a little naive to me. It's like measuring curtains, said Sen. Thom Tillis, a Republican from North Carolina. It's about winning in November, and I suppose we could tackle the agenda next year, but it's an equation with many variables, not the least of which is how successful we are, here in Congress, to take up the gavels.\n\nOthers see it as an opportunity to try to reset the party after months of internal tension over the future of House Speaker Mike Johnson, contributing to the war in Ukraine and divisions over the best security strategy. borders.\n\nIn the House, a traditionally more Trump-friendly chamber, members said the former president would find a supportive and enthusiastic audience, some dressed to impress.\n\nI just think he wants to get everyone on the same page, said Sen. Markwayne Mullin, a key Trump ally. There was a bit of tension in the Senate. It's just about trying to keep the tension from building and saying our focus is on Joe Biden and this administration, not on each other.\n\nGOP Rep. Troy Nehls said he had several different Trump ties to choose from, although he complained that his Trump-branded gold sneakers were back in Texas.\n\n\"He will know that I support him 110 percent and I will do everything I can to fight like hell to make sure he is the next president,\" Nehls said.\n\nRep. EliseStefanik, who as Republican conference chairwoman was responsible for organizing the House meeting, will also chair the event. Stefanik is among a short list of vice presidential candidates who will receive verification materials from the Trump campaign. Rep. Byron Donalds is also on that list and is expected to be in attendance Thursday.\n\nTrump's visit comes as House Republican leaders face growing pressure from the right flank to take on the Justice Department and defend Trump following his hush money conviction at New York.\n\nOne legislative proposal that Republican leaders are actively pursuing is a bill that would allow current and former presidents to bring state-level cases in federal court. The bill passed out of committee last September, but Republican Party leaders only began formally introducing it this week, on the eve of Trump's visit to the Capitol and two weeks after his conviction.\n\nOne thing House and Senate Republicans agreed on: Trump was unlikely to stick to his message.\n\nAsked if they thought Trump would discuss policy plans and campaign strategy and while avoiding airing his grievances, one Republican lawmaker told CNN: \"You know the answer to that question.\" It's not in his DNA.\n\nWhat am I waiting for? {"uri": "8176556578", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "18:42:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T18:42:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T18:41:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.kpbs.org/news/politics/2024/06/13/trump-met-with-gop-lawmakers-in-washington-to-rally-support-push-for-unity", "title": "Trump met with GOP lawmakers in Washington to rally support, push for unity", "body": "Former President Donald Trump held two separate meetings Thursday with GOP lawmakers in Washington. Trump used the events, each held blocks from the U.S. Capitol, to push for GOP members to unify behind him ahead of this year's presidential election.\n\nTrump ended his visit with Senate Republicans with a brief press availability where he listed goals for a GOP-led government and described the current state of the country in bleak and dysfunctional terms.\n\n\"We have great unity, we have great common sense,\" he said. \"A lot of very smart people in this room.\"\n\nTrump did not take any questions.\n\nThe former president began the day with a closed-door meeting with House Republicans where he pledged to support members so they can \"win big\" in November, praised Speaker Mike Johnson and discussed a wide range of issues including inflation and abortion.\n\nThe meeting, which took place near the U.S. Capitol, was his first visit back since he left office and since hiscriminal convictions in the New York hush money trial. Trump is meeting with Senate Republicans this afternoon.\n\nIt is also the first time Trump has visited Capitol Hill since the January 6th riot at the Capitol. Trump was not present that day as his supporters stormed the building and he has not visited the Capitol building in the years that followed - including President Biden's inauguration, which Trump skipped.\n\n\"President Trump brought an extraordinary amount of energy, and excitement and enthusiasm this morning,\" Johnson said while flanked by other House leaders after their more than hour-long meeting.\n\nThe afternoon session with the Senate was also an opportunity for Trump to address skeptics within the party. In recent months, more Senate Republicans, including those initially resistant to weigh in, have said they're supporting Trump's re-election run. Others, like Sen. Todd Young, R-Ind., have refused to back him or continue to avoid discussing their support for the former president.\n\nSen. Susan Collins of Maine, who was one of seven Senate Republicans to vote to convict Trump during his second impeachment trial, said she wouldn't attending the meeting because of a longstanding conflict.\n\nThe meetings mark a high-stakes affair for Trump and Republicans heading into the contentious final months of the campaign. While many Congressional Republicans are firmly behind Trump, there remains a divide among some as the former president faces multiple legal battles.\n\nSeveral members leaving the meeting highlighted Trump asking Georgia Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene to be \"nice\" to Johnson. Greene responded with a hand motion that signaled, \"maybe.\"\n\n\"President Trump was very much himself - no teleprompter, no notecards,\" said Greene, who led the failed effort to oust Johnson last month. \"He joked with everybody.\"\n\nGreene said there were no discussions about Trump's potential pick for vice president, and that Trump told members he \"feels a lot of states are in play\" with plans to spend money in New Jersey, New York, Minnesota and Virginia.\n\n\"He did say there's a few of you in the room that might not be happy with me because I'm supporting your opponent, but I will be doing tele-town halls for many of you, helping you get across the line, doing whatever it takes to win the House and win it big,\" she added.\n\nRep. Ralph Norman, R-S.C. said Trump was casting a wide net.\n\n\"There's no state he's not going in,\" he said.\n\nThat includes includes races where he isn't backing the incumbent.\n\nThe former president endorsed GOP Virginia Rep. Bob Good's primary challenger, John Maguire, ahead of next week's Republican primary. Good attended the meeting, but declined to discuss it with NPR on his way out.\n\nMembers said Trump did most of the talking in the meeting. Rep Ben Cline, R-Va., noted well over an hour into the session, \"it wasn't a discussion, Trump's just been talking,\" but he added Trump took some questions.\n\nTrump also took a swipe at those House GOP lawmakers who voted to impeach him in 2021, noting there weren't many left in Congress.\n\nLater, several members said he appeared to signal support of California Rep. David Valadao, who voted to impeach, but without naming him.\n\nHe also took a jab at Taylor Swift, noting he signed a bill during his administration to help songwriters, and that he was surprised Swift wasn't supporting him.\n\nSouth Carolina Rep. Nancy Mace said Trump devoted a significant portion of his remarks to speaking about abortion.\n\n\"Ensuring that women know that we care and that we're pro-woman and pro-life is a really important message for us going into November,\" Mace said. \"He talked about exceptions for rape, incest and life of the mother.\"\n\nMace, one of Trump's former enemies, now has his endorsement, and was congratulated on her recent primary win.\n\nRep. Marc Molinaro, running for reelection in a competitive district in New York, told reporters on the abortion discussion, \"his point was obviously to speak from your heart. And I've embraced this in my own district for the people I represent, just we've got to be respectful of the very difficult choices women have to make.\"\n\nNorman said the message from Trump on abortion was \"let the states decide.\" He told lawmakers he's not going to get into the details on specific restrictions and they shouldn't either, but if they weigh in on specific restrictions in terms of 8, 10, 12 week ban, \"use your heart.\"\n\nMultiple Republicans told NPR that Trump talked about ramping up pressure on China, and touted his own policy as president imposing tariffs on China.\n\nOne House Republican who has not yet endorsed Trump, Rep. Dave Schweikert, R-Ariz., said about the discussion, \"I was actually pleased it was mostly on economy, on inflation. He told reporters he planned to endorse Trump after the GOP convention.\n\nGOP lawmakers said Trump didn't weigh in on a specific tax strategy, or the speaker's proposal to push through an aggressive package early in 2025 using expedited budget rules, but urged them to vote to cut taxes.\n\n\"He talked about tax-free tips, which is a great opportunity for middle class workers, people who basically make a living on tips to not pay taxes on those things, a good thing, a popular thing with the middle class,\" Rep. Mike Garcia, R-Calif., said.\n\nFor their part, congressional Democrats said today marked a reminder of a dark moment in the country's history, pointing to Trump's role in the Jan. 6 attack.\n\n\"On January 6th, Donald Trump lit a match to democracy with an insurrection on Capitol Hill, and, today, he's arrived at the scene of the crime and continues to throw fuel on the flame,\" said California Democratic Rep. Zoe Lofgren, who served on the former Jan. 6 committee.", "source": {"uri": "kpbs.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "KPBS"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-388147683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "09:29:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T09:29:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T09:11:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/donald-trump-meeting-house-senate-091148056.html", "title": "Donald Trump is meeting with House, Senate Republicans in DC. Will they lay out a 2025 wish list?", "body": "WASHINGTON - Former President Donald Trump will meet with Republican lawmakers Thursday to discuss campaign strategies and lay out their wish list if they defeat Democrats in November.\n\nIt's the first time Trump has returned to Capitol Hill since leaving office nearly four years ago, and the trip provides an opportunity for conservative leaders to plot which policy priorities they'll pursue if reelected.\n\nThe meetings with both House and Senate lawmakers also align with a meeting with the Business Roundtable, a powerful cohort of some of the country's largest companies that will host the former president while he's in the nation's capital. Trump is slated to meet with House Republican lawmakers in the morning at the Capitol Hill Club and Senate Republicans in the afternoon at the National Republican Senatorial Committee office, both locations adjacent to the Capitol grounds.\n\nThe visit comes after Trump was convicted by a New York jury in his hush money trial and weeks before he is slated to be formally nominated at the Republican National Convention. The twin meetings with congressional Republicans are supposed to help shore up unity in the party that has, at times, struggled to agree on major policy priorities, such as providing additional aid to Ukraine.\n\nHowever, some moderate members are expected to skip the meeting, such as Sens. Susan Collins, R-Maine, Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, and Mitt Romney, R-Utah. Several of their peers insisted that's not necessarily a problem.\n\n\"I think there's lots of reasons for people to not show up,\" including scheduling conflicts, said Sen. Kevin Cramer, R-N.D. \"It's a grand opportunity for us all to get together to kick off the official campaign but also to prepare, possibly, for a transition.\"\n\nDonald Trump, Mitch McConnell will meet for the first time in years as GOP leaders gather\n\nTop Republicans in Congress are expected to attend the meetings Thursday. That includes Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., who has not met in-person with the former president since 2020. The two have had a frosty relationship after McConnell accepted the results of the 2020 presidential election and blamed the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol attack on Trump.\n\nMcConnell declined to say if he would bring up the animosity with the former president at the Senate meeting, reiterating that he intended to support the 2024 GOP nominee, whoever it may be. However, the Kentucky Republican declined to even reference Trump by name.\n\n\"I've said earlier this year I support him. He's earned the nomination by the voters all across the country and of course I'll be at the meeting tomorrow,\" McConnell told reporters.\n\nHouse Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., on the other hand, is a stalwart Trump ally, having served on the former president's defense team during his first impeachment trial. The speaker told reporters Wednesday morning he wants to use the meetings to lay out a clear-cut conservative agenda should the GOP sweep the coming elections.\n\n\"When (Trump) comes in, we got to have a very aggressive first 100 days agenda. The first year will be important and I think we cannot waste a moment,\" House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., said\n\nTrump's visit is important for Johnson's leadership post as well. The former president defended the speaker from Georgia Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's threat to oust him last month. At the same time, Trump has occasionally thrown a wrench into Johnson's legislative agenda, including briefly derailing his plans over a controversial spying law in April.\n\nTrump's four sets of criminal charges could also shape the House GOP's legislative agenda this year. A number of Republicans support a bill led by Rep. Russell Fry, R-S.C., that would allow presidents and vice presidents to move civil and criminal state cases to federal court instead. Johnson said he supports the proposal, but a number of Republican lawmakers are skeptical about the legislation. In addition to his New York hush money case, Trump also faces state-level charges in Georgia over allegations he tried to steal the state in the 2020 presidential election.\n\nThe meetings may also serve another purpose: Giving Trump face time with several of the people he is considering as his running mate. That includes Sens. JD Vance, R-Ohio, Tim Scott, R-S.C., and Marco Rubio, R-Fla., as well as House members such as Rep. Elise Stefanik, R-N.Y. and Byron Donalds, R-Fla.\n\nRep. Marc Molinaro, R-N.Y., told reporters he expects to hear Trump give a \"lay of the land as he sees it\" of the 2024 elections. Other lawmakers told USA TODAY they expect the meeting to be critical towards building a working relationship between congressional Republicans and the former president should the GOP take full control of Washington, picking up the White House and the Senate and maintaining control of the House. That kind of sweep would be an uphill battle for either party.\n\n\"We're working on cementing this relationship now so when January 20th comes, we have a plan in place to work together with the White House and Congress,\" Rep. Mark Alford, R-Texas, said, noting a major part of the GOP agenda is renewing Trump's 2017 tax cuts, which expire in 2025.\n\n\"That's the main thing that we need to make sure we talk about: That we communicate for the next few months, have a plan going into January,\" said Sen. Tommy Tuberville, R-Ala. As for what is on the table? \"You name it. All the crap that we had to put up for four years.\"\n\nWhat does Mike Johnson want after 2024?\n\nJohnson also met with Senate Republicans over lunch Wednesday to begin discussions on a potential party-line package to chase next year.\n\nJohnson told reporters after the meeting that he expressed interest in enacting new tax and spending cuts. Tax cuts passed during the Trump administration are set to expire in 2025, which means the next president will have a significant opportunity to rewrite the country's tax code.\n\n\"I think now we're in the education\" phase of teaching members what can and cannot be accomplished using the unique legislative tool known as \"reconciliation,\" said Sen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C. Reconciliation can bypass the Senate's 60-vote threshold for certain budget legislation.\n\nDemocrats used the tool in the first two years of the Biden administration to pass sweeping clean energy tax credits and other policies in the Inflation Reduction Act, a massive piece of legislation that aimed to address issues from transportation and the environment to insulin prices.\n\n\"Then it's appropriate to start talking about, ok, what does a common agenda look like?\" Tillis said of his Republican colleagues. \"This is something we need to do pretty early in Trump's tenure.\"", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [{"uri": "riley_beggin@yahoo.com", "name": "Riley Beggin", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "ken_tran@yahoo.com", "name": "Ken Tran", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capitol_Hill", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Capitol Hill"}, "location": {"uri": "8176484036", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "17:40:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T17:40:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T17:39:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.kpbs.org/news/politics/2024/06/13/trump-meets-with-gop-lawmakers-to-sketch-a-plan-for-a-possible-second-term", "title": "Trump meets with GOP lawmakers to sketch a plan for a possible second term", "body": "At a closed-door meeting with House Republicans Thursday morning, former President Donald Trump pledged to support members so they can \"win big\" in November, praised Speaker Mike Johnson and discussed a wide range of issues including inflation and abortion.\n\nThe meeting, which took place near the U.S. Capitol, was his first visit back since he left office and since hiscriminal convictions in the New York hush money trial. Trump is meeting with Senate Republicans this afternoon.\n\nIt is also the first time Trump has visited Capitol Hill since the January 6th riot at the Capitol. Trump was not present that day as his supporters stormed the building and he has not visited the Capitol building in the years that followed - including President Biden's inauguration, which Trump skipped.\n\n\"President Trump brought an extraordinary amount of energy, and excitement and enthusiasm this morning,\" Johnson said while flanked by other House leaders after their more than hour-long meeting.\n\nThe meetings mark a high-stakes affair for Trump and Republicans heading into the contentious final months of the campaign. While many Congressional Republicans are firmly behind Trump, there remains a divide among some as the former president faces multiple legal battles.\n\nSeveral members leaving the meeting highlighted Trump asking Georgia Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene to be \"nice\" to Johnson. Greene responded with a hand motion that signaled, \"maybe.\"\n\n\"President Trump was very much himself - no teleprompter, no notecards,\" said Greene, who led the failed effort to oust Johnson last month. \"He joked with everybody.\"\n\nGreene said there were no discussions about Trump's potential pick for vice president, and that Trump told members he \"feels a lot of states are in play\" with plans to spend money in New Jersey, New York, Minnesota and Virginia.\n\n\"He did say there's a few of you in the room that might not be happy with me because I'm supporting your opponent, but I will be doing tele-town halls for many of you, helping you get across the line, doing whatever it takes to win the House and win it big,\" she added.\n\nRep. Ralph Norman, R-S.C. said Trump was casting a wide net.\n\n\"There's no state he's not going in,\" he said.\n\nThat includes includes races where he isn't backing the incumbent.\n\nThe former president endorsed GOP Virginia Rep. Bob Good's primary challenger, John Maguire, ahead of next week's Republican primary. Good attended the meeting, but declined to discuss it with NPR on his way out.\n\nMembers said Trump did most of the talking in the meeting. Rep Ben Cline, R-Va., noted well over an hour into the session, \"it wasn't a discussion, Trump's just been talking,\" but he added Trump took some questions.\n\nTrump also took a swipe at those House GOP lawmakers who voted to impeach him in 2021, noting there weren't many left in Congress.\n\nLater, several members said he appeared to signal support of California Rep. David Valadao, who voted to impeach, but without naming him.\n\nHe also took a jab at Taylor Swift, noting he signed a bill during his administration to help songwriters, and that he was surprised Swift wasn't supporting him.\n\nSouth Carolina Rep. Nancy Mace said Trump devoted a significant portion of his remarks to speaking about abortion.\n\n\"Ensuring that women know that we care and that we're pro-woman and pro-life is a really important message for us going into November,\" Mace said. \"He talked about exceptions for rape, incest and life of the mother.\"\n\nMace, one of Trump's former enemies, now has his endorsement, and was congratulated on her recent primary win.\n\nRep. Marc Molinaro, running for reelection in a competitive district in New York, told reporters on the abortion discussion, \"his point was obviously to speak from your heart. And I've embraced this in my own district for the people I represent, just we've got to be respectful of the very difficult choices women have to make.\"\n\nNorman said the message from Trump on abortion was \"let the states decide.\" He told lawmakers he's not going to get into the details on specific restrictions and they shouldn't either, but if they weigh in on specific restrictions in terms of 8, 10, 12 week ban, \"use your heart.\"\n\nMultiple Republicans told NPR that Trump talked about ramping up pressure on China, and touted his own policy as president imposing tariffs on China.\n\nOne House Republican who has not yet endorsed Trump, Rep. Dave Schweikert, R-Ariz., said about the discussion, \"I was actually pleased it was mostly on economy, on inflation. He told reporters he planned to endorse Trump after the GOP convention.\n\nGOP lawmakers said Trump didn't weigh in on a specific tax strategy, or the speaker's proposal to push through an aggressive package early in 2025 using expedited budget rules, but urged them to vote to cut taxes.\n\n\"He talked about tax-free tips, which is a great opportunity for middle class workers, people who basically make a living on tips to not pay taxes on those things, a good thing, a popular thing with the middle class,\" Rep. Mike Garcia, R-Calif., said.\n\nWyoming GOP Sen. John Barrasso, who chairs the Senate Republican Conference, said he invited Trump to hear his \"plans for the summer and policy agenda for 2025,\" his spokesperson said.\n\nThe Senate meeting will also be a chance for Trump to address skeptics within the party. In recent months, more Senate Republicans, including those initially resistant to weigh in, have said they're supporting Trump's re-election run. Others, like Sen. Todd Young, R-Ind., have refused to back him or continue to avoid discussing their support for the former president.\n\nSen. Susan Collins of Maine, who was one of seven Senate Republicans to vote to convict Trump during his second impeachment trial, said she isn't attending Thursday's meeting because of a longstanding conflict.\n\nFor their part, congressional Democrats said today marked a reminder of a dark moment in the country's history, pointing to Trump's role in the Jan. 6 attack.\n\n\"On January 6th, Donald Trump lit a match to democracy with an insurrection on Capitol Hill, and, today, he's arrived at the scene of the crime and continues to throw fuel on the flame,\" said California Democratic Rep. Zoe Lofgren, who served on the former Jan. 6 committee.", "source": {"uri": "kpbs.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "KPBS"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8175373872", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "05:28:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T05:28:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T05:25:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://kion546.com/politics/cnn-us-politics/2024/06/12/donald-trump-back-in-washington-for-meetings-with-vice-presidential-contenders-congressional-allies-and-former-foes/", "title": "Donald Trump back in Washington for meetings with vice presidential contenders, congressional allies and former foes - KION546", "body": "By Kristen Holmes, Alayna Treene, Melanie Zanona and Lauren Fox, CNN\n\n(CNN) -- Former President Donald Trump is back in Washington for the first time since becoming the presumptive Republican nominee as well as a convicted felon, holding a pair of significant, closed-door meetings with key congressional allies, vice presidential hopefuls and even a few former outspoken opponents - all of whom are expected to line up behind him this fall.\n\nA bitter primary and general election cycle muddied by Trump's ongoing legal troubles have given Republicans little opportunity to sync up over the policies and proposals that generally drive an election year.\n\n\"He'll come and lead the team,\" GOP Rep. Matt Gaetz of Florida, a fierce Trump ally, told CNN. \"I think it's gonna be a pep rally environment for the former and future president.\"\n\nAhead of the meeting, Texas Republican Sen. John Cornyn noted it would be \"nice\" to \"get everybody singing from the same sheet of music.\" Cornyn has previously criticized Trump and said he preferred to see the GOP move in a different direction, before ultimately endorsing the former president in January.\n\nSenior campaign advisers said Trump was expected to express his campaign priorities and policies -- focusing on the economy, inflation, tax cuts and immigration during his meetings, first with House Republicans at the Capitol Hill club in the morning and then with Senate Republicans at the nearby National Republican Senatorial Committee building. He'll also reiterate his commitment to not cutting entitlement programs for seniors like Social Security and Medicare.\n\n\"We want to get everyone on the same page talking about policy, including the economy and inflation,\" one senior Trump adviser told CNN. \"That's the biggest factor in all the polling, it's the biggest thing people are worried about.\"\n\nTrump, who will be accompanied by his two top campaign officials, Susie Wiles and Chris LaCivita, among others, is also expected to discuss details around a potential second term agenda, including how to immediately implement his policy goals, with the help of lawmakers, if reelected to the White House. Meanwhile, House Republicans have been eager for information to help them jumpstart legislative action on Capitol Hill next year.\n\n\"We want to be part of that plan to hit the ground running,\" GOP Rep. Darrell Issa of California told CNN. \"When most presidents get elected, they anticipate they have eight years. This president knows he has four.\"\n\nAdvisers said the meetings would also be an opportunity to allow lawmakers to ask questions or bring up any pressing matters ahead of the November election, with Trump planning to open the floor to members after his remarks.\n\nHouse Majority Steve Scalise told CNN he's already talked to Trump directly about using a special budgetary tool to avoid the 60-vote threshold in the Senate - known as reconciliation - to advance tax cuts, border wall funding and other priorities if Republicans control all of Washington.\n\nSome of Trump's plans for a second term agenda have been outlined by the former President himself during rallies and interviews, including mass deportations of undocumented immigrants and leaving reproductive rights to the states, but other elements have been only proposed vaguely or behind closed doors, and leaked out by media outlets.\n\nSen. John Barrasso, the third-ranking Senate Republican, invited the full GOP conference to the Thursday event.\n\nHowever some senators skeptical of Trump would not commit to attending. Sen. Lisa Murkowski, one of a handful of GOP senators who have not endorsed Trump's 2024 election bid, said she would not attend due to a conflict. Sen. Todd Young of Indiana wouldn't say if he was planning to attend, adding that he wasn't talking about Trump this week.\n\nThough Trump won't be inside the US Capitol building, his appearance on the Hill will also mark his first time meeting with some key Republicans since the January 6, 2021, insurrection there, including Senate GOP Leader Mitch McConnell.\n\nMcConnell, who has maintained an icy relationship with the former president ever since the Capitol attack, told CNN he will attend the meeting. The two have not spoken since the electoral college certified Joe Biden's victory in December 2020, however McConnell endorsed Trump earlier this year.\n\nAny tension is likely to be balanced out by some of Trump's biggest cheerleaders and potential vice-presidential picks, who will also be in attendance, including Sens. Tim Scott, Marco Rubio and JD Vance.\n\nOf those attending, many said they were looking for a more urgent focus, including Trump laying out a specific strategy to beat President Joe Biden.\n\n\"I will be honest with you. To think that we are going to talk a whole lot about a governing agenda on Thursday seems a little na\u00efve to me. That's like measuring the curtains,\" said Sen. Thom Tillis, a Republican from North Carolina. \"This is about winning in November, and my guess is we may touch on the agenda next year, but that's a multi-variable equation not the least of which is how well we do here in Congress to take the gavels back.\"\n\nOthers see it as an opportunity to try and reset the party after months of internal tensions over the future of House Speaker Mike Johnson, aiding the war in Ukraine and the divisions over the best strategy on border security.\n\nIn the House, a chamber that has traditionally been friendlier to Trump, members said the former president will find a supportive and enthusiastic audience, including some dressed to impress.\n\n\"I just think he wants to get everybody on the same page,\" said Sen. Markwayne Mullin, a key Trump ally. \"There's been a little tension there in the Senate. And so it's just trying to keep the tension from building and saying our focus is Joe Biden and this administration, not each other.\"\n\nGOP Rep. Troy Nehls said he has several different Trump ties to choose from, though he complained that his gold, Trump-branded sneakers are back in Texas.\n\n\"He will know that I support him 110%, and I will do everything I can to fight like hell to make sure that he's the next president,\" Nehls said.\n\nRep. Elise Stefanik, who - as Republican conference chair - was in charge of organizing the House meeting, will also chair the event. Stefanik is one of a short list of vice presidential hopefuls to receive vetting materials from the Trump campaign. Rep. Byron Donalds is also on that list and is expected to attend Thursday.\n\nTrump's visit comes as House GOP leadership is facing increasing pressure from the right flank to go after the Justice Department and defend Trump in the wake of his hush money conviction in New York.\n\nOne legislative proposal Republican leaders are now actively pursuing is a bill that would allow current and former presidents to move state-level cases to federal court. The legislation passed out of committee last September, but GOP leaders only started formally whipping the bill this week - on the eve of Trump's Capitol Hill visit and two weeks after his conviction.\n\nOne thing both House and Senate Republicans agreed on: Trump was unlikely to stay on message.\n\nWhen asked if they believe Trump will discuss policy plans and campaign strategy and while avoiding airing his grievances, one GOP lawmaker told CNN, \"You know the answer to that. It ain't in his DNA.\"\n\n\"What do I expect? You have no idea what Trump is going to talk about. It's just totally unpredictable,\" said Sen. Chuck Grassley, a Republican from Iowa.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8175309093", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "04:26:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T04:26:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T04:24:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/trump-is-returning-to-capitol-hill-to-meet-with-republican-lawmakers-a-first-since-jan/article_48507aaa-a9aa-5265-8cbb-61f20ff30b2d.html", "title": "Trump is returning to Capitol Hill to meet with Republican lawmakers, a first since Jan. 6 attack", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Donald Trump is making a triumphant return to Capitol Hill to meet with House and Senate Republicans, his first since sending the mob to \"fight like hell\" ahead of the Jan.6, 2021 attack, as GOP lawmakers find themselves newly energized and reinvigorated by his bid to retake the White House.\n\nDespite the federal charges against Trump for conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, and his recent guilty verdict in an unrelated hush money trial, the Republican former president arrives Thursday emboldened as the party's presumptive nominee. He has successfully purged the GOP of critics, silenced skeptics and enticed once-critical lawmakers aboard his MAGA-fueled campaign.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\n\"We're excited to have Trump back,\" said House Speaker Mike Johnson, who led one of the lawsuits challenging the 2020 election, and had his biggest fundraising day yet after Trump's felony conviction.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe Republican speaker demurred over whether he's asked Trump to respect the peaceful transfer of presidential power and commit to not doing another Jan. 6. \"Of course he respects that, we all do, and we've all talked about it, ad nauseum.\"\n\nTrump is scheduled to deliver remarks to both groups at the House and Senate campaign headquarters near the U.S. Capitol and discuss issues animating his campaign -- including mass immigration deportations but also tax cuts and other priorities for a potential second term.\n\nIn between, Trump is expected to speak at the Business Roundtable downtown which routinely invites the presumptive presidential nominees to address the executives' group. Many potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, that are laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\nBut the private meetings with House and Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol are infused with symbolism of Trump's return as the U.S. president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of presidential power.\n\n\"It's frustrating,\" said former U.S. Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of Jan. 6, when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building trying to overturn President Joe Biden's election.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nDunn spoke of the \"irony\" of Trump returning to the area and lawmakers now embracing him. \"It just shows the lack of backbone they have when they're truly putting party and person over country,\" he said. \"And it's sad.\"\n\nMany of those who once stood up to Trump are long gone from office and the Republicans who remain seem increasingly enthusiastic about the possibility of him retaking the White House, and the down-ballot windfall that could mean for their own GOP majorities in Congress.\n\nJohnson met with senators on Wednesday ahead of Trump's arrival as the Republicans mapped out potential priorities.\n\nOutgoing Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who once blamed Trump for the \"disgraceful\" attack that he called an \"insurrection\" now endorses the party's presumptive nominee and said: \"Of course I'll be at the meeting.\"\n\nSen. John Thune, the GOP whip who is vying to replace McConnell as leader, told The Associated Press that he's interested in hearing from Trump about the fall election and \"ways in which we, as a team, and him individually can appeal to the constituencies and people that may not traditionally vote Republican.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThune said, \"I think there's an opportunity there to really make this a big win.\"\n\nAs democracies around the world come under threat from a far-rightward shift, experts warn that the U.S. system, once seemingly immune from authoritarian impulses, is at risk of populist and extremist forces like those that Trump inspired to sack the Capitol.\n\n\"This is just another example of House Republicans bending the knee to Donald Trump,\" said Rep. Pete Aguilar of California, the chairman of the House Democratic caucus.\n\nMaking Jan. 6 a cornerstone of his reelection campaign, Trump celebrates those who stormed the Capitol as \"warriors\" and \"patriots,\" and he has vowed to pardon any number of the more than 1,300 America convicted of crimes for the assault on the seat of U.S. democracy.\n\nMoreover, Trump has vowed to seek retribution by ousting officials at the U.S. Justice Department, which is prosecuting him in a four-count indictment to overturn the election ahead of the Jan. 6 attack and another case over storing classified documents at his Mar-A-Largo home.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nRepublicans, particularly in the House but increasingly in the Senate, are vigorously following his lead, complaining of an unfair justice system. The House voted to hold hAttorney General Merrick Garland in contempt of Congress and is re-investigating the House committee that investigated Jan. 6.\n\nAlongside Trump, the House and Senate GOP campaign arms scored some of their highest fundraising periods yet after a jury found him guilty in the New York hush money case.\n\nWhen former GOP Speaker Paul Ryan on Fox News reiterated this week that he wouldn't be voting for Trump and wished Republicans had another choice for president, he was immediately ostracized by Trump allies.\n\n\"Paul Ryan, you're a piece of garbage,\" said Rep. Troy Nehls, R-Texas. \"We should kick you out of the party.\"\n\nOf the Republicans who voted to impeach Trump over Jan. 6 and convict him on the charge of inciting the insurrection, only a few remain in office.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nSen. Susan Collins, R-Maine, and Sen. Lisa Murkowski, R-Alaska, are not expected to attend Thursday's closed-door session with Trump.\n\nBut Sen. Bill Cassidy, R-La., said he would likely join the Trump meeting at GOP senators' campaign headquarters, expecting \"he's going to be the next president, so you have to work\" together.\n\nAsked if he was concerned about the direction of the Trump Republican Party, Cassidy: \"Let the day's own troubles be sufficient for the day. You can fill yourself up with anxiety about tomorrow, but will it change a thing? No.\"\n\nSen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C., who confronted Trump at times but did not join in the vote to convict him in the Capitol attack, said he did not expect the meeting to be contentious as Republicans hope to seize the Senate majority this fall.\n\n\"Look, we've got to win. And our ability to get a majority in the Senate is intrinsically linked to Trump winning. So we're like, one team, one vision. And I think that will be largely what we talk about,\" Tillis said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Jill Colvin and Mary Clare Jalonick contributed to this report.\n\nRead more on the U.S. Election at thestar.com", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Star"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "Text size\n\nDonald Trump returns to Washington on Thursday to rally support from Republican lawmakers and the business community following his historic criminal conviction in his New York hush money trial.\n\nThe former president, who is running to unseat Joe Biden in November, will have separate closed-door sessions with House members at a private club near the US Capitol and with senators at their campaign headquarters nearby, and address dozens of CEOs.\n\n\"The speaker and the House GOP Leadership look forward to hosting President Trump on Thursday morning to discuss growing the House Republican majority and the 2025 legislative agenda,\" a spokesman for House Speaker Mike Johnson told AFP.\n\nIt will be Trump's first meeting with lawmakers on Capitol Hill since leaving the White House in 2021 and his first trip to Washington since he was convicted in New York in May on all 34 felony counts of falsifying business records.\n\nThe party has circled the wagons around its standard-bearer since the guilty verdicts, with numerous lawmakers denigrating a justice system they baselessly claim is biased against conservatives.\n\nHouse Republicans face an uphill battle to reclaim the lower chamber from the Democrats in November's elections, which are expected to be tight from the presidential race down through many of the key House and Senate contests.\n\nSenate Republicans have a much more favorable map, and are confident of flipping their 49-51 minority in the upper chamber.\n\nAt least five centrist senators have yet to commit to attending on Thursday, although Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, who has not spoken to Trump since berating him from the Senate floor over the 2021 insurrection, has said he will be there.\n\nTrump was impeached for inciting the attack, when a mob of his supporters stormed the Capitol seeking to prevent the peaceful transfer of power to Biden, who beat Trump by more than seven million votes.\n\n\"I said three years ago, right after the Capitol was attacked, that I would support our nominee, regardless of who it was, including him... And of course, I will be at the meeting,\" McConnell told reporters.\n\nThursday's events are expected to be more of an effort to boost morale and ensure the party is moving in one direction ahead of the election than to drill down on specific policy proposals.\n\nBut Trump is likely to be quizzed on plans to extend the tax cuts he implemented in 2017, as well as his proposals for a tough illegal immigration crackdown and his view of the war in Ukraine.\n\nThe conflict has exposed fissures between Trump's isolationist \"America First\" movement and more traditional conservatives who want to see Russia's Vladimir Putin defeated with the help of American weapons.\n\nThe former president is also due to make his case for a White House return to chief executives at a meeting of Washington lobby group Business Roundtable.\n\nPolitical news outlet Axios quoted a source familiar with Trump's expected remarks who said the former president was likely to focus on his plan \"to immediately reduce inflation and roll back anti-business Biden regulations.\"\n\nAn election forecast model combining state and national polls with economic indicators, out Wednesday from The Economist, gives Trump a two-in-three chance of winning reelection. Elise Stefanik, who chairs the House Republican Conference, called the meeting a \"very successful\" political gathering.\n\n\"We are 100 percent united behind his candidacy and are ready to work on behalf of the American people,\" Stefanik told reporters, calling Trump's appearance a \"unifying event.\"\n\nSenate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, who has been an outspoken critic of former Trump for years but supported him for president in March, called the meeting \"really positive.\"\n\n\"He and I had a chance to talk a little bit, we shook hands a few times,\" McConnell told reporters. \"He received many ovations. make more of an effort to flip the state, which hasn't supported a Republican for president since 2004, that could push the Biden campaign to devote more resources to a state considered safe for president. president.\n\nThe Biden campaign has six field offices and has hosted several popular events in the commonwealth, including a pickleball tournament to woo senior voters on Wednesday.\n\n\"Virginians have rejected Trump every time he has run here, and his MAGA allies were soundly defeated last year after campaigning on his agenda of banning abortion in the {"uri": "2024-06-387863086", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "04:23:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T04:23:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T04:00:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://keyt.com/politics/cnn-us-politics/2024/06/12/donald-trump-back-in-washington-for-meetings-with-vice-presidential-contenders-congressional-allies-and-former-foes/", "title": "Donald Trump back in Washington for meetings with vice presidential contenders, congressional allies and former foes", "body": "By Kristen Holmes, Alayna Treene, Melanie Zanona and Lauren Fox, CNN\n\n(CNN) -- Former President Donald Trump is back in Washington for the first time since becoming the presumptive Republican nominee as well as a convicted felon, holding a pair of significant, closed-door meetings with key congressional allies, vice presidential hopefuls and even a few former outspoken opponents - all of whom are expected to line up behind him this fall.\n\nA bitter primary and general election cycle muddied by Trump's ongoing legal troubles have given Republicans little opportunity to sync up over the policies and proposals that generally drive an election year.\n\n\"He'll come and lead the team,\" GOP Rep. Matt Gaetz of Florida, a fierce Trump ally, told CNN. \"I think it's gonna be a pep rally environment for the former and future president.\"\n\nAhead of the meeting, Texas Republican Sen. John Cornyn noted it would be \"nice\" to \"get everybody singing from the same sheet of music.\" Cornyn has previously criticized Trump and said he preferred to see the GOP move in a different direction, before ultimately endorsing the former president in January.\n\nSenior campaign advisers said Trump was expected to express his campaign priorities and policies -- focusing on the economy, inflation, tax cuts and immigration during his meetings, first with House Republicans at the Capitol Hill club in the morning and then with Senate Republicans at the nearby National Republican Senatorial Committee building. He'll also reiterate his commitment to not cutting entitlement programs for seniors like Social Security and Medicare.\n\n\"We want to get everyone on the same page talking about policy, including the economy and inflation,\" one senior Trump adviser told CNN. \"That's the biggest factor in all the polling, it's the biggest thing people are worried about.\"\n\nTrump, who will be accompanied by his two top campaign officials, Susie Wiles and Chris LaCivita, among others, is also expected to discuss details around a potential second term agenda, including how to immediately implement his policy goals, with the help of lawmakers, if reelected to the White House. Meanwhile, House Republicans have been eager for information to help them jumpstart legislative action on Capitol Hill next year.\n\n\"We want to be part of that plan to hit the ground running,\" GOP Rep. Darrell Issa of California told CNN. \"When most presidents get elected, they anticipate they have eight years. This president knows he has four.\"\n\nAdvisers said the meetings would also be an opportunity to allow lawmakers to ask questions or bring up any pressing matters ahead of the November election, with Trump planning to open the floor to members after his remarks.\n\nHouse Majority Steve Scalise told CNN he's already talked to Trump directly about using a special budgetary tool to avoid the 60-vote threshold in the Senate - known as reconciliation - to advance tax cuts, border wall funding and other priorities if Republicans control all of Washington.\n\nSome of Trump's plans for a second term agenda have been outlined by the former President himself during rallies and interviews, including mass deportations of undocumented immigrants and leaving reproductive rights to the states, but other elements have been only proposed vaguely or behind closed doors, and leaked out by media outlets.\n\nTrump's reception among House and Senate Republicans is likely to vary\n\nSen. John Barrasso, the third-ranking Senate Republican, invited the full GOP conference to the Thursday event.\n\nHowever some senators skeptical of Trump would not commit to attending. Sen. Lisa Murkowski, one of a handful of GOP senators who have not endorsed Trump's 2024 election bid, said she would not attend due to a conflict. Sen. Todd Young of Indiana wouldn't say if he was planning to attend, adding that he wasn't talking about Trump this week.\n\nThough Trump won't be inside the US Capitol building, his appearance on the Hill will also mark his first time meeting with some key Republicans since the January 6, 2021, insurrection there, including Senate GOP Leader Mitch McConnell.\n\nMcConnell, who has maintained an icy relationship with the former president ever since the Capitol attack, told CNN he will attend the meeting. The two have not spoken since the electoral college certified Joe Biden's victory in December 2020, however McConnell endorsed Trump earlier this year.\n\nAny tension is likely to be balanced out by some of Trump's biggest cheerleaders and potential vice-presidential picks, who will also be in attendance, including Sens. Tim Scott, Marco Rubio and JD Vance.\n\nOf those attending, many said they were looking for a more urgent focus, including Trump laying out a specific strategy to beat President Joe Biden.\n\n\"I will be honest with you. To think that we are going to talk a whole lot about a governing agenda on Thursday seems a little na\u00efve to me. That's like measuring the curtains,\" said Sen. Thom Tillis, a Republican from North Carolina. \"This is about winning in November, and my guess is we may touch on the agenda next year, but that's a multi-variable equation not the least of which is how well we do here in Congress to take the gavels back.\"\n\nOthers see it as an opportunity to try and reset the party after months of internal tensions over the future of House Speaker Mike Johnson, aiding the war in Ukraine and the divisions over the best strategy on border security.\n\nIn the House, a chamber that has traditionally been friendlier to Trump, members said the former president will find a supportive and enthusiastic audience, including some dressed to impress.\n\n\"I just think he wants to get everybody on the same page,\" said Sen. Markwayne Mullin, a key Trump ally. \"There's been a little tension there in the Senate. And so it's just trying to keep the tension from building and saying our focus is Joe Biden and this administration, not each other.\"\n\nGOP Rep. Troy Nehls said he has several different Trump ties to choose from, though he complained that his gold, Trump-branded sneakers are back in Texas.\n\n\"He will know that I support him 110%, and I will do everything I can to fight like hell to make sure that he's the next president,\" Nehls said.\n\nRep. Elise Stefanik, who - as Republican conference chair - was in charge of organizing the House meeting, will also chair the event. Stefanik is one of a short list of vice presidential hopefuls to receive vetting materials from the Trump campaign. Rep. Byron Donalds is also on that list and is expected to attend Thursday.\n\nTrump's visit comes as House GOP leadership is facing increasing pressure from the right flank to go after the Justice Department and defend Trump in the wake of his hush money conviction in New York.\n\nOne legislative proposal Republican leaders are now actively pursuing is a bill that would allow current and former presidents to move state-level cases to federal court. The legislation passed out of committee last September, but GOP leaders only started formally whipping the bill this week - on the eve of Trump's Capitol Hill visit and two weeks after his conviction.\n\nOne thing both House and Senate Republicans agreed on: Trump was unlikely to stay on message.\n\nWhen asked if they believe Trump will discuss policy plans and campaign strategy and while avoiding airing his grievances, one GOP lawmaker told CNN, \"You know the answer to that. It ain't in his DNA.\"\n\n\"What do I expect? You have no idea what Trump is going to talk about. It's just totally unpredictable,\" said Sen. Chuck Grassley, a Republican from Iowa.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company.
