{"uri": "2024-06-388557221", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "15:19:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T15:19:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T15:17:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/donald-trump-capitol-hill-meet-republican-lawmakers-9391054/", "title": "Trump arrives on Capitol Hill to meet with Republican lawmakers | World News - The Indian Express", "body": "The Republican presidential candidate is due to meet with Republicans in the House of Representatives in the morning and have lunch with Senate Republicans to coordinate campaign strategies.\n\nDonald Trump arrived on Capitol Hill on Thursday to meet with Republican lawmakers to build unity ahead of the November 5 election, which could hand his party control of the White House and both chambers of Congress.\n\nTrump's motorcade pulled up to a side entrance of a Republican office building a block from the US Capitol, avoiding a crowd of protesters out front.\n\nThe Republican presidential candidate is due to meet with Republicans in the House of Representatives in the morning and have lunch with Senate Republicans to coordinate campaign strategies.\n\nTrump and current Democratic President Joe Biden each enjoyed unified governments in their first two years in office, but saw their parties lose control of the House during midterm elections, which impeded their ability to pass legislation.\n\n\"The meeting will be forward-focused on how Republicans can work together to advance policies to save America, including protecting Social Security and Medicare, securing the southern border, and cutting taxes for hardworking families,\" a senior Trump campaign official said.\n\nThe Republican presidential candidate is also due to speak on Thursday to the Business Roundtable, a Washington, DC-based association of more than 200 corporate chief executives.\n\nAlso read | Biden vs Trump: What to expect from presidential debates\n\n\"Our ability to get a majority in the Senate is intrinsically linked to President Trump winning. So, we're like one team/one vision, and I think that'll be largely what we talk about,\" Republican Senator Thom Tillis told reporters.\n\nRepublicans hope to see Trump defeat Biden, extend their current razor-thin 218-213 majority in the House and take control of a Senate that Democrats currently lead 51-49.\n\nOLD GRIEVANCES\n\nBut the visit has also put a spotlight on longstanding tensions between Trump and members of Congress, including Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who has not spoken to the former president since he acknowledged Biden's election victory in December 2020. Trump's false claims that his defeat was the result of fraud inspired the January 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.\n\nDespite their differences, the Kentucky Republican emphasized his support for Trump's candidacy. \"I support him. He's earned the nomination by the voters all across the country. And of course, I'll be at the meeting,\" McConnell told reporters on Wednesday.\n\nOthers, including moderates such as Susan Collins, Lisa Murkowski and Mitt Romney, will not attend, citing scheduling conflicts.\n\nHouse Speaker Mike Johnson met with Senate Republicans over lunch on Wednesday to talk about how a united Republican government could use a parliamentary vehicle called budget reconciliation to bypass Democrats in the Senate.\n\n\"We have big policy changes that we'd like to enact,\" Johnson told reporters afterward. \"So, we want to make the most use of that and be coordinated between the two chambers.\"\n\nAlso read | He said he was ashamed of storming the capitol. Now he's running for office.\n\nA main focus for House and Senate Republicans will be making permanent tax cuts under Trump's 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act that will otherwise expire next year.\n\nLawmakers also expect to discuss their spending plans for the fiscal year beginning October 1 and how to handle the looming January 1 deadline to raise or suspend the nation's debt ceiling. Brinkmanship around debt-ceiling deadlines has spooked financial markets in the past.\n\nRepublican centrists also hope Trump will persuade hardline conservatives to get in line after ousting former Speaker Kevin McCarthy in October, attempting to oust Johnson last month and repeatedly blocking their own party's legislation over the past year.\n\n\"The president has an opportunity to reaffirm to the members of our conference how important it is to stick together,\" said US Representative Anthony D'Esposito. \"Our success will be depend on us sticking together as Republicans.\"", "source": {"uri": "8176636726", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "19:58:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T19:58:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T19:56:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/all-hands-on-deck-trump-vows-to-help-gop-in-house-races/article_85913d56-7441-534b-8f09-c62d087291ae.html", "title": "'All hands on deck': Trump vows to help GOP in House races", "body": "WASHINGTON -- House Republican lawmakers serenaded former President Donald Trump on Thursday, as he urged them to hold the line on hot-button issues like abortion, immigration and trade tariffs -- and work harder to expand their paper-thin majority.\n\nTrump was on Capitol Hill for the first time since a mob of his supporters stormed the legislative hall on Jan. 6, 2021, trying to stop lawmakers from counting Electoral College votes showing Trump lost the 2020 election. It also marked his first appearance on the Hill since becoming a convicted felon two weeks ago, and put him face-to-face with Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., with whom he has clashed, for the first time in three years.\n\nTrump's morning session in private with House Republicans at the Capitol Hill Club was described as something of a pep rally for conservative causes. Rep. Byron Donalds, R-Fla., and others said the atmosphere was a mix of civil and serious, with some lighter moments. Trump was slated to meet with GOP senators later in the day.\n\n\"The president was having a little fun cracking jokes, that kind of thing,\" said Donalds, mentioned on some lists as a potential Trump running mate. \"But then, also talking seriously just about [members] just working hard to get to the finish line in this election.\"\n\nHouse Appropriations Chairman Tom Cole, R-Okla., described the session as \"a pretty good rally-the-troops kind of speech.\" Trump will turn 78 on Friday, and several members, with grins, said House Republicans sang \"Happy Birthday.\"\n\nAs they dodged a handful of anti-Trump protesters outside, multiple members said Trump said Speaker Mike Johnson is doing a \"great job,\" and he teased Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, the Georgia Republican who has clashed with Johnson, R-La. Members said Trump asked if she has been more \"nice\" to Johnson. \"Some people kind of laughed. A few cheered,\" said Rep. Tim Burchett, R-Tenn. \"I thought she took it very gracious.\"\n\nLawmakers said Trump stood by his boasting about how conservatives on the Supreme Court -- including three that he appointed -- ended federal abortion protections. He also vowed to again use tariffs as president and endorsed a House-passed Republican immigration measure known as H.R. 2.\n\n\"He's a big believer in tariffs,\" Cole said, noting Trump spoke about the trade tactic \"at great length,\" and added: \"He clearly supports them as a tool.\"\n\nOn abortion, \"he still believes that the Dobbs decision was the right decision for America, and the American people need to decide the issue, as they are doing right now,\" said Republican Study Committee Chair Kevin Hern, R-Okla., referring to the Supreme Court decision that ended federal protections for abortion access.\n\nAt campaign rallies and in other public remarks of late, Trump has said the Dobbs ruling rightfully handed the hot-button issue -- on which polls show voters siding with Democrats -- to state governments. To that end, he told House members Thursday that state \"legislatures need to make that decision and we're seeing that happen across America,\" Hern said.\n\n\"He said there may be a time and place for the federal government to get involved, but right now, what needs to be done is the voices of the people in the states [should be heard],\" the chairman added. \"Some are going the right way for Republicans and some are not and he acknowledged that.\"\n\nHis meetings with Hill Republicans were intended as a show of support for the presumptive GOP presidential nominee following his conviction on 34 criminal counts of falsifying business records. It also was meant as a display of Republican unity after, especially on the House side, GOP members have clashed with themselves in recent months.\n\nWhile Republican Sens. Susan Collins of Maine, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska and Mitt Romney of Utah -- all Trump critics -- said they would skip the afternoon session with Trump, the former president's popularity within the party is as strong as ever. For instance, 80.4% of GOP voters had a favorable view of Trump, according to a FiveThirtyEight analysis. (Less than one-third, 17.8%, reported having an unfavorable view.)\n\nTrump, despite becoming the first former U.S. president to be convicted by a jury, continues to run a competitive race against President Joe Biden. Another FiveThirtyEight metric put them in a dead heat nationally, with Trump leading 40.9% to Biden's 40%.\n\nRatings by Inside Elections with Nathan L. Gonzales give Trump the advantage five months from Election Day in the Electoral College race, with a projected 235 votes to Biden's 226 -- but both would be shy of the 270 needed to secure the presidency.\n\nHern told reporters that Trump described the swing states that are expected to decide the presidential race as \"looking really good right now,\" noting that Trump told House members \"people are really turning out in huge numbers\" and that the former president believes \"his message is being well received.\"\n\nAs the 2024 campaign heats up, Cole -- who faces a primary challenge on Tuesday -- said the House GOP conference \"will be extraordinarily supportive\" of Trump, and along with Senate Republicans \"will give him an exceptional platform -- lots of chips to play.\"\n\nInside Elections and other political prognosticators see control of both chambers as up for grabs. To that end, Donalds said Trump indicated he intends to get involved in congressional races. That's despite the former president's poor record with helping the party win congressional races since he first was on the ballot in 2016.\n\n\"He's going to work hard. You know, he wants everybody to be successful,\" he said. \"It's all hands on deck.\"\n\nBut Hern said Trump made clear that \"he's not going to carry the load for us -- we can't stop working as individuals.\"\n\nAs always, both sessions were vintage Trump. \"He ran the gamut\" of issues, said Rep. Nancy Mace, R-S.C. But did he show any cards about who he will select to be his running mate during his third White House bid?\n\n\"No,\" Donalds said with a chuckle behind sunglasses on one of the warmest days so far this year in Washington, D.C. \"We didn't get into that.\"\n\n-------\n\n(Aidan Quigley contributed to this report.)\n\n\u00a92024 CQ-Roll Call, Inc., All Rights Reserved. {"uri": "8173884045", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-12", "time": "08:51:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-12T08:51:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-12T08:50:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2024/jun/12/trump-gop-members-of-house-senate-to-meet/", "title": "Trump, GOP members of House, Senate to meet", "body": "WASHINGTON -- House Republicans will meet privately with Donald Trump on Thursday, as the former president who is now the party's presumptive nominee returns to Capitol Hill for the first time since his supporters attacked the building on Jan. 6, 2021, in an attempt to overturn President Joe Biden's election.\n\nTrump was already scheduled to meet with Senate Republicans and he will now hold a separate session with colleagues in the House. House GOP Conference Chairwoman Rep. Elise Stefanik of New York advised lawmakers early Tuesday of the coming meeting with Trump.\n\nIt's a pivotal moment for the indicted former president, weeks before he is to be sentenced after being found guilty in the hush money trial and ahead of the Republican National Convention when he is expected to become the formal GOP nominee for president.\n\nThe Trump campaign did not confirm the meeting with House Republicans, but a senior campaign official said the Senate meeting will be focused on policy issues -- including tax cuts.\n\nTrump's return to the GOP campaign offices across from the Capitol, his first since the mob of supporters rioted at the Capitol in 2021, comes as he faces other legal charges, including the four-part federal indictment brought by Justice Department Special Prosecutor Jack Smith in the conspiracy to overturn the 2020 election results.\n\nMost Republicans have endorsed Trump in the expected rematch against Biden, including Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, and other leaders who were critical of him in the aftermath of the 2021 attack.\n\nMany of the Republicans in Congress have joined Trump in attacking the U.S. justice system for the cases against him. House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., led lawmakers in rallying to Trump's defense outside the New York courthouse last month in the hush money trial.\n\nBRAGG TO TESTIFY\n\nManhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg has agreed to testify before Congress on July 12, a day after Trump's sentencing.\n\nA spokesperson for Bragg's office confirmed Tuesday that he will appear before the House Select Subcommittee on the Weaponization of the Federal Government alongside Matthew Colangelo, the former high-ranking Justice Department official who was hired by Bragg in 2022 and helped lead the Trump investigation.\n\nBragg and Colangelo will face what's likely to be a hostile, Republican-controlled hearing where the chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, has accused both men of conducting a \"political prosecution\" in the case against the former president. It will mark the latest effort by Trump's closest allies in Congress to discredit the recent 34-count conviction by going after local and federal prosecutors who have charged him.\n\n\"It undermines the rule of law to spread dangerous misinformation, baseless claims, and conspiracy theories following the jury's return of a full-count felony conviction in People v. Trump,\" a spokesperson for the Manhattan district attorney's office said. \"Nonetheless, we respect our government institutions and plan to appear voluntarily before the subcommittee after sentencing.\"\n\nBragg, a Democrat, sued Jordan last year, seeking to halt a House Judiciary Committee inquiry into Trump's indictment. He later agreed to let the Republican-led committee question ex-prosecutor Mark Pomerantz, who once oversaw the investigation but left the job after clashing with Bragg over the direction of the case.\n\nSoon after Trump's April 2023 arraignment, Jordan took the Judiciary Committee on the road for a field hearing near Bragg's offices to examine what he decried as the Democrat's \"pro-crime, anti-victim\" policies. Democrats described the hearing and various efforts since by Republicans as a partisan stunt aimed at amplifying conservative anger at Bragg.\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by Lisa Mascaro, Farnoush Amiri and Michael R. Sisak of The Associated Press.\n\nFILE - Rioters loyal to President Donald Trump rally at the U.S. Capitol in Washington on Jan. 6, 2021. As Trump makes a comeback bid to return to power, Republicans in Congress have become even more likely to cast doubts on President Joe Biden's 2020 victory. {"uri": "8176697715", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "20:57:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T20:57:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T20:56:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.thestar.com.my/news/world/2024/06/14/trump-talks-tariffs-and-taxes-calls-republican-host-city-039horrible039", "title": "Trump talks tariffs and taxes, calls Republican host city 'horrible'", "body": "WASHINGTON (Reuters) -Donald Trump criticized U.S. aid to Ukraine and suggested raising tariffs to replace the U.S. income tax on a Thursday visit to Capitol Hill where he also called the city hosting his party's presidential convention \"horrible.\"\n\nIn separate meetings with Republicans in the House of Representatives and the Senate, Trump sought to mend divisions ahead of the Nov. 5 election that could see his party win control of the White House and both chambers of Congress.\n\nTrump floated the idea of reducing the U.S. income tax and replacing it with tariffs, said Representatives Thomas Massie and Marjorie Taylor Greene.\n\nParticipants said he shook hands with Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell, despite their frosty relationship, and encouraged hard-liner Greene to \"be nice\" to House Speaker Mike Johnson, after her failed attempt to depose him.\n\n\"There's tremendous unity in the Republican Party,\" Trump said after the Senate meeting.\n\nBut Republicans scrambled to explain after several media outlets reported that Trump privately called Milwaukee a \"horrible\" city, roughly one month before he is due to receive his party's presidential nomination there.\n\nThat could potentially alienate residents of the biggest city in Wisconsin, one of a handful of competitive states that will determine the outcome of the election.\n\nA campaign spokesperson and several Republican lawmakers said Trump was referring to what they said were the city's problems with crime and voter fraud. A nonpartisan audit of the 2020 election in Wisconsin found no evidence of irregularities.\n\nMEMORIES OF JAN. 6\n\nTrump's supporters stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, fueled by his false claims that his defeat was the result of fraud. Thursday's visit was his first public appearance on Capitol Hill since that day and Democrats said he was not welcome.\n\n\"After inciting a deadly insurrection that defiled the halls of Congress, how dare Trump show his face on these grounds?\" Democratic Representative Bennie Thompson said in a statement.\n\nThe Biden campaign on Thursday began running an ad in battleground states highlighting the violence of Jan. 6.\n\nRepublican lawmakers said Trump told them he would work to expand the party's narrow 218-213 House majority and take control of a Senate that Democrats currently lead 51-49.\n\nTrump also advised House Republicans not to push a national ban on abortion and urged them to abandon the intra-party squabbling that has hobbled their effectiveness, lawmakers said.\n\nIt was Trump's first face to face meeting with McConnell since the Jan. 6 attack. The two had not spoken since a few weeks before then, when McConnell affirmed Biden's 2020 victory. Two moderate Republican senators, Susan Collins and Lisa Murkowski, skipped the event.\n\nMcConnell did not appear with Trump at a news conference after the meeting.\n\nTIPS AND TARIFFS\n\nTrump also urged lawmakers to cut taxes on income from tips, an idea he first floated on Sunday to appeal to service workers, multiple lawmakers said.\n\nTrump used tariffs aggressively during his 2017-2021 term in office, placing levies of up to 25% on a wide range of Chinese products as one of many efforts to thwart competition.\n\nSenator Mike Rounds said that cutting taxes on tips could help Republicans win over working-class voters.\n\n\"If there was something we could do to really energize that particular segment of the population, that might be a real popular thing to do,\" Rounds told reporters.\n\nBiden's support among voters without college degrees or living in households earning $50,000 a year or less has fallen sharply, Reuters/Ipsos polling shows, though large numbers of those voters have not shifted their support to Trump.\n\nTrump also criticized a $60 billion aid package for Ukraine that recently passed with Republican support, lawmakers said.\n\n\"He's like, if Ukraine wins, what will be the benefit?\" Republican Representative Don Bacon told reporters.\n\nTrump told Republicans they should allow states to set their own policies on abortion, rather than push for a nationwide ban following the Supreme Court's 2022 decision that ended the nationwide guarantee of abortion access. Many in the party want to outlaw the procedure entirely.\n\n\"He reiterated he thought that was the right decision, that some states will do one thing and some states will do another,\" Republican Representative French Hill told reporters.\n\nTrump also spoke to the Business Roundtable, an association of more than 200 corporate chief executives.\n\n(Reporting by David Morgan, Andy Sullivan and Gram Slattery; Additional reporting by Ismail Shakil and Katherine Jackson; Editing by Scott Malone, Lincoln Feast, Nick Zieminski, Rod Nickel and Daniel Wallis)", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com.my", David Valadao of California.\n\nI never liked him, Trump said of Valadao, according to a GOP staffer.\n\nAs a number of House Republicans find themselves in competitive primary races, the former speaker said he wanted to hold teletown halls but acknowledged his help would not be welcomed by some, given that he had supported their main opponents.\n\nTrump did not hesitate to acknowledge tensions between House Speaker Mike Johnson and Republican Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, who unsuccessfully tried to oust Johnson against Trump's wishes. The former president playfully asked Greene, a loyal ally of his whom he strongly supports, to be nice to the speaker.\n\nHe's always so nice, he recognizes me, and he said to me: are you nice to President Johnson? He was joking. And I said huh, as she gestured with her hands. He said OK, be nice to him and I nodded, she added.\n\nJohnson, after the meeting, said the former president told him he was doing a very good job and planned to be fully prepared to implement Trump's plans if he wins in November.\n\nThe former president's conviction also weighed heavily during Thursday's meeting.\n\nTrump's allies on Capitol Hill immediately took action after the guilty verdict proposing to defund the Justice Department and even shut down the government. House Republicans voted Wednesday to hold Attorney General Merrick Garland in contempt of Congress. And one of the legislative proposals that Republican leaders are actively pursuing is a bill that would allow current and former presidents to bring state-level cases in federal court. The bill passed out of committee last September, but Republican Party leaders only began formally adopting it this week, on the eve of Trump's visit to the Capitol and two weeks after his conviction.\n\nDuring his meeting with Republican lawmakers, Trump called the Justice Department dirty bastards, according to another source in the room.\n\nOklahoma Republican Rep. Kevin Hern said the former president expressed grave concern that the federal government was being weaponized.\n\nAt a news conference after the meeting, House Majority Whip Tom Emmer said the former president's felony convictions only energized the party that would propel them to victory in November.\n\n\"Anyone who thought that this president was going to be overthrown after the show trial, after this crooked trial that we saw in New York, I think, again, that just gave him even more energy,\" Emmer said. And what he did for us upstairs earlier was he showed us this energy and this positive attitude, despite all the garbage that they threw at him with their legal speeches and their absurdities.\n\nTrump had a direct message for House Republicans on how to approach abortion through November, an issue on which Republicans have struggled to unite in the wake of the overturning of Roe v. Wade.\n\nJohnson reported that Trump asked the group to exercise their own conscience to talk about it, share their beliefs and do it in a way that makes sense to people. He called on Republicans to follow their beliefs, but cautioned how they will approach the issue on the campaign trail and argued for exceptions.\n\nHe spoke out and called for exceptions for rape, maternal life and incest. He talked about how we need to talk about this, correctly quote his words, not mine, GOP Rep. Nancy Mace told CNN. And I really appreciated her comments as a woman, as a suburban mom.\n\nTrump also explained how Roe v. Wade ultimately turned the decision over to the states as they had always wanted, although he noted that some of them hadn't made very good decisions.\n\nBut like Ronald Reagan, you have to have three choices: motherhood, rape and incest, you have to do it, but you have to follow your own heart, Trump said, according to a source in the room.\n\nTrump's message came as the Supreme Court dismissed a lawsuit challenging the Food and Drug Administration's approach to regulating the abortion pill mifepristone, with a ruling that will continue to allow the pills to be sent to patients without an in-person medical visit.\n\nThe former president also discussed a handful of other priorities, including his proposal to eliminate taxes on tips, building the southern border and stopping aid to Ukraine, even though a number of legislators from her party support her.\n\nThere were a number of moments where the former president veered off topic.\n\nAs Trump raged about crime rates and so-called election integrity issues, the former president called Milwaukee, where Republicans are holding their convention this summer, horrible, according to a source in the room.\n\nRep. Derrick Van Orden, a Wisconsin Republican in the room, made clear to CNN that Trump was specifically referring to crime in Milwaukee and not the city itself.\n\nIn bizarre moment, Trump called Pelosis daughter wacky, then claimed his daughter once told him that he and the former House speaker would have had a great romance in another life, according to a lawmaker present in the room.\n\nIn response to Trump's comments, one of Pelosis daughters posted on X: Speaking on behalf of Pelosi's 4 daughters, this is a LIE. {"uri": "2024-06-388298139", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "11:35:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T11:35:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T11:14:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/us/house-senate-unity/2024/06/13/id/1168578/", "title": "Republicans Hope for Unity Message in Trump Visit to Congress", "body": "Republicans hope a pair of visits from former President Donald Trump on Thursday will bring unity to their sometimes bitterly divided caucuses in the Senate and House of Representatives, as the party heads toward the Nov. 5 election.\n\nTrump is due to meet with House Republicans on Thursday morning and have lunch with Senate Republicans, aiming to coordinate campaign strategies to deliver a \"trifecta\" of Republican control over the White House and both chambers of Congress.\n\nTrump and current Democrat President Joe Biden each enjoyed unified governments in their first two years in office, but saw their parties lose control of the House during midterm elections, which impeded their ability to pass legislation.\n\n\"The meeting will be forward-focused on how Republicans can work together to advance policies to save America, including protecting Social Security and Medicare, securing the southern border, and cutting taxes for hardworking families,\" a senior Trump campaign official said.\n\nThe Republican presidential candidate is also due to speak Thursday to the Business Roundtable, a Washington, D.C.-based association of more than 200 corporate chief executives.\n\n\"Our ability to get a majority in the Senate is intrinsically linked to President Trump winning. So, we're like one team/one vision, and I think that'll be largely what we talk about,\" Sen. Thom Tillis, R-N.C., told reporters.\n\nRepublicans hope to see Trump defeat Biden, extend their current razor-thin 218-213 majority in the House and take control of a Senate that Democrats currently lead 51-49.\n\nOld Grievances\n\nBut the visit has also put a spotlight on longstanding tensions between Trump and members of Congress, including Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., who has not spoken to the former president since he acknowledged Biden's election victory in December 2020. Trump's seeking election integrity investigations inspired the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.\n\nDespite their differences, McConnell emphasized his support for Trump's candidacy.\n\n\"I support him. He's earned the nomination by the voters all across the country. And of course, I'll be at the meeting,\" McConnell told reporters Wednesday.\n\nOthers, including moderates such as Sens. Susan Collins, R-Maine; Lisa Murkowksi, R-Alaska; and Mitt Romney, R-Utah, will not attend, citing scheduling conflicts.\n\nHouse Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., met with Senate Republicans over lunch Wednesday to talk about how a united Republican government could use a parliamentary vehicle called budget reconciliation to bypass Democratic objections in the Senate.\n\n\"We have big policy changes that we'd like to enact,\" Johnson told reporters afterward. \"So, we want to make the most use of that and be coordinated between the two chambers.\"\n\nA main focus for House and Senate Republicans will be making permanent tax cuts under Trump's 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act that will otherwise expire next year.\n\nLawmakers also expect to discuss their plans around spending for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 and how to handle the looming Jan. 1 deadline to raise or suspend the nation's debt ceiling. Brinkmanship around debt-ceiling deadlines has spooked financial markets in the past.\n\nHouse Republican centrists also hope Trump will persuade hardline conservatives who ousted former Speaker Kevin McCarthy in October, sought to oust Johnson last month and have blocked their own party's legislation over the past year, to get in line with the rest of the conference.\n\n\"The president has an opportunity to reaffirm to the members of our conference how important it is to stick together,\" Rep. "https://www.unionleader.com/news/military/trump-criticizes-ukraine-aid-talks-tax-cuts-and-tariffs-with-republicans/article_ba3873ec-8ea5-57b6-ac70-59310f9c9050.html", "title": "Trump criticizes Ukraine aid, talks tax cuts and tariffs with Republicans", "body": "WASHINGTON - Donald Trump on Thursday criticized U.S. aid to Ukraine, urged Republican lawmakers to cut taxes on gratuities and talked up tariffs in a visit to Capitol Hill, participants said, as he sought to build party unity ahead of the Nov. 5 election.\n\nIn a closed-door meeting, Trump said he would work to expand the party's narrow 218-213 House of Representatives majority and help re-elect even the two remaining Republican House members who voted to impeach him after the Jan. 6, 2021 assault on the U.S. Capitol by his supporters.\n\nTrump also encouraged House Republicans not to push a national ban on abortion and encouraged them to abandon the inter-party squabbling that has hobbled their effectiveness, lawmakers said.\n\n\"We have to plan to lead because there's so many problems to fix,\" House Speaker Mike Johnson told reporters afterward.\n\nTrump was due to meet Senate Republicans for lunch to discuss campaign strategies.\n\nTrump and Democratic President Joe Biden each enjoyed unified governments during their first two years in office, but saw their parties lose control of the House during midterm elections, which impeded their ability to pass legislation.\n\nThe Republican presidential candidate is also due to speak on Thursday to the Business Roundtable, a Washington, D.C.-based association of more than 200 corporate chief executives.\n\nRepublicans hope to see Trump defeat Biden, extend their current razor-thin House majority and take control of a Senate that Democrats currently lead 51-49.\n\nTrump urged lawmakers to cut taxes on income from tips, an idea he first floated on Sunday to appeal to service workers.\n\nTrump criticized a $60-billion aid package for Ukraine that recently passed with Republican support, lawmakers said.\n\n\"He's like, if Ukraine wins, what will be the benefit?\" Republican Representative Don Bacon told reporters.\n\nBacon said Trump voiced support for tariffs on Chinese goods.\n\n\"He just said tariffs are a strong tool for the executive branch. And you can use it in your negotiations with China and get concessions.\"\n\nHard-line Republican Representative Matt Gaetz said Trump voiced support for tariffs to protect the U.S. steel industry.\n\nTrump used tariffs aggressively during his 2017-2021 term in office, placing levies of up to 25% on a wide range of Chinese products as one of many efforts to thwart competition.\n\nTrump told Republicans that they should allow states to set their own policies on abortion, rather than push for a nationwide ban following the Supreme Court's 2022 decision that ended the nationwide guarantee of abortion access. Many in the party want to outlaw the procedure entirely.\n\n\"He reiterated he thought that was the right decision, that some states will do one thing and some states will do another,\" Republican Representative French Hill told reporters.\n\nTrump also encouraged far-right Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, who led an unsuccessful effort to oust Johnson, to work constructively with him, lawmakers said.\n\nOLD GRIEVANCES\n\nDemocrats said Trump was not welcome on Capitol Hill after his false claims of fraud following his 2020 election defeat inspired the Jan. 6, 2021, attack.\n\n\"After inciting a deadly insurrection that defiled the halls of Congress, how dare Trump show his face on these grounds?\" Democratic Representative Bennie Thompson said in a statement.\n\nThe visit also put a spotlight on longstanding tensions between Trump and members of Congress, including Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who has not spoken to the former president since he acknowledged Biden's election victory in December 2020.\n\nDespite their differences, McConnell emphasized his support for Trump's candidacy on Wednesday.\n\nOthers, including moderates such as Susan Collins and Lisa Murkowski, will not attend, citing scheduling conflicts.\n\n(Reporting by David Morgan and Andy Sullivan; Editing by Scott Malone, Lincoln Feast, Nick {"uri": "8176453120", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "17:14:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T17:14:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T17:13:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://rollcall.com/?p=753334", "title": "'All hands on deck': Trump vows to help GOP in House races - Roll Call", "body": "Republicans sing 'Happy Birthday' to former president two weeks after conviction\n\nHouse Republican lawmakers serenaded former President Donald Trump on Thursday, as he urged them to hold the line on hot-button issues like abortion, immigration and trade tariffs -- and work harder to expand their paper-thin majority.\n\nTrump was on Capitol Hill for the first time since a mob of his supporters stormed the legislative hall on Jan. 6, 2021, trying to stop lawmakers from counting Electoral College votes showing Trump lost the 2020 election. It also marked his first appearance on the Hill since becoming a convicted felon two weeks ago, and put him face-to-face with Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., with whom he has clashed, for the first time in three years.\n\nTrump's morning session in private with House Republicans at the Capitol Hill Club was described as something of a pep rally for conservative causes. Rep. Byron Donalds, R-Fla., and others said the atmosphere was a mix of civil and serious, with some lighter moments. Trump was slated to meet with GOP senators later in the day.\n\n\"The president was having a little fun cracking jokes, that kind of thing,\" said Donalds, mentioned on some lists as a potential Trump running mate. \"But then, also talking seriously just about [members] just working hard to get to the finish line in this election.\"\n\nHouse Appropriations Chairman Tom Cole, R-Okla., described the session as \"a pretty good rally-the-troops kind of speech.\" Trump will turn 78 on Friday, and several members, with grins, said House Republicans sang \"Happy Birthday.\"\n\nAs they dodged a handful of anti-Trump protesters outside, multiple members said Trump said Speaker Mike Johnson is doing a \"great job,\" and he teased Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, the Georgia Republican who has clashed with Johnson, R-La. Members said Trump asked if she has been more \"nice\" to Johnson. \"Some people kind of laughed. A few cheered,\" said Rep. Tim Burchett, R-Tenn. \"I thought she took it very gracious.\"\n\nLawmakers said Trump stood by his boasting about how conservatives on the Supreme Court -- including three that he appointed -- ended federal abortion protections. He also vowed to again use tariffs as president and endorsed a House-passed Republican immigration measure known as H.R. 2.\n\n\"He's a big believer in tariffs,\" Cole said, noting Trump spoke about the trade tactic \"at great length,\" and added: \"He clearly supports them as a tool.\"\n\nOn abortion, \"he still believes that the Dobbs decision was the right decision for America, and the American people need to decide the issue, as they are doing right now,\" said Republican Study Committee Chair Kevin Hern, R-Okla., referring to the Supreme Court decision that ended federal protections for abortion access.\n\nAt campaign rallies and in other public remarks of late, Trump has said the Dobbs ruling rightfully handed the hot-button issue -- on which polls show voters siding with Democrats -- to state governments. To that end, he told House members Thursday that state \"legislatures need to make that decision and we're seeing that happen across America,\" Hern said.\n\n\"He said there may be a time and place for the federal government to get involved, but right now, what needs to be done is the voices of the people in the states [should be heard],\" the chairman added. \"Some are going the right way for Republicans and some are not and he acknowledged that.\"\n\nHis meetings with Hill Republicans were intended as a show of support for the presumptive GOP presidential nominee following his conviction on 34 criminal counts of falsifying business records. It also was meant as a display of Republican unity after, especially on the House side, GOP members have clashed with themselves in recent months.\n\nWhile Republican Sens. Susan Collins of Maine, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska and Mitt Romney of Utah -- all Trump critics -- said they would skip the afternoon session with Trump, the former president's popularity within the party is as strong as ever. For instance, 80.4 percent of GOP voters had a favorable view of Trump, according to a FiveThirtyEight analysis. (Less than one-third, 17.8 percent, reported having an unfavorable view.)\n\nTrump, despite becoming the first former U.S. president to be convicted by a jury, continues to run a competitive race against President Joe Biden. Another FiveThirtyEight metric put them in a dead heat nationally, with Trump leading 40.9 percent to Biden's 40 percent.\n\nRatings by Inside Elections with Nathan L. Gonzales give Trump the advantage five months from Election Day in the Electoral College race, with a projected 235 votes to Biden's 226 -- but both would be shy of the 270 needed to secure the presidency.\n\nHern told reporters that Trump described the swing states that are expected to decide the presidential race as \"looking really good right now,\" noting that Trump told House members \"people are really turning out in huge numbers\" and that the former president believes \"his message is being well received.\"\n\nAs the 2024 campaign heats up, Cole -- who faces a primary challenge on Tuesday -- said the House GOP conference \"will be extraordinarily supportive\" of Trump, and along with Senate Republicans \"will give him an exceptional platform -- lots of chips to play.\"\n\nInside Elections and other political prognosticators see control of both chambers as up for grabs. To that end, Donalds said Trump indicated he intends to get involved in congressional races. That's despite the former president's poor record with helping the party win congressional races since he first was on the ballot in 2016.\n\n\"He's going to work hard. You know, he wants everybody to be successful,\" he said. \"It's all hands on deck.\"\n\nBut Hern said Trump made clear that \"he's not going to carry the load for us -- we can't stop working as individuals.\"\n\nAs always, both sessions were vintage Trump. \"He ran the gamut\" of issues, said Rep. Nancy Mace, R-S.C. But did he show any cards about who he will select to be his running mate during his third White House bid?\n\n\"No,\" Donalds said with a chuckle behind sunglasses on one of the warmest days so far this year in Washington, D.C. \"We didn't get into that.\"", "source": {"uri": "rollcall.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Roll Call"}, "authors": [{"uri": "john_t_bennett@rollcall.com", "name": "John T. He mingled with Republicans, despite past tensions, and aimed to unify the party. His remarks on Milwaukee and past events sparked controversy, while his policy suggestions drew mixed reactions.\n\ncriticized U.S. aid to Ukraine, urged his fellow Republicans to cut taxes on gratuities and talked up tariffs on a Thursday visit to Capitol Hill where he also called the city hosting his party's presidential convention \"horrible.\" In separate meetings with Republicans in the House of Representatives and the Senate, Trump sought to mend divisions ahead of the\n\nNov. 5 election that could see his party win control of the White House and both chambers of Congress.\n\nParticipants said he shook hands with Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell, despite their frosty relationship, and encouraged hard-line Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene to \"be nice\" to House Speaker Mike Johnson, after her failed attempt to depose him. \"There's tremendous unity in the Republican Party,\" Trump said after the Senate meeting.\n\nBut Republicans scrambled to explain after several media outlets reported that Trump privately called\n\nMilwaukee a \"horrible\" city, roughly one month before he is due to receive his party's presidential nomination there. That could potentially alienate residents of the biggest city in Wisconsin, one of a handful of competitive states that will determine the outcome of the election.\n\nA campaign spokesman and several Republican lawmakers said Trump was referring to the city's problems with crime and vote fraud. A nonpartisan audit of the 2020 election in Wisconsin found no evidence of irregularities. MEMORIES OF JAN. 6\n\nTrump's supporters stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, fueled by his false claims that his defeat was the result of fraud. Thursday's visit was his first public appearance on Capitol Hill since that day and Democrats said he was not welcome back. \"After inciting a deadly insurrection that defiled the halls of Congress, how dare Trump show his face on these grounds?\" Democratic Representative Bennie Thompson said in a statement.\n\nRepublican lawmakers said Trump told them he would work to expand the party's narrow 218-213 House majority and take control of a Senate that Democrats currently lead 51-49. Trump also advised House Republicans not to push a national ban on abortion and urged them to abandon the intra-party squabbling that has hobbled their effectiveness, lawmakers said.\n\nIt was Trump's first face to face meeting with McConnell since the Jan. 6 attack. The two had not spoken since a few weeks before then, when McConnell affirmed Biden's 2020 victory. Two moderate Republican senators, Susan Collins and Lisa Murkowski, skipped the event. TIPS AND TARIFFS\n\nTrump urged lawmakers to cut taxes on income from tips, an idea he first floated on Sunday to appeal to service workers and voiced support for tariffs on Chinese goods and to protect the U.S. steel industry, multiple lawmakers said. Trump used tariffs aggressively during his 2017-2021 term in office, placing levies of up to 25% on a wide range of Chinese products as one of many efforts to thwart competition.\n\nSenator Mike Rounds said that cutting taxes on tips could help Republicans with working-class voters. \"These are the folks you really want to help. I think everybody recognizes that these folks have a real challenge and they work hard for the tips they get,\" Rounds told reporters. \"If there was something we could do to really energize that particular segment of the population, that might be a real popular thing to do.\"\n\nBiden's support among voters without college degrees or living in households earning $50,000 a year or less has fallen sharply\n\n, Reuters/Ipsos polling\n\nshows, though large numbers of those voters have not shifted their support to Trump. Trump also criticized a $60-billion aid package for Ukraine that recently passed with Republican support, lawmakers said.\n\n\"He's like, if Ukraine wins, what will be the benefit?\" Republican Representative Don Bacon told reporters. Trump told Republicans that they should allow states to set their own policies on abortion, rather than push for a nationwide ban following the Supreme Court's 2022 decision that ended the nationwide guarantee of abortion access. Many in the party want to outlaw the procedure entirely.\n\n\"He reiterated he thought that was the right decision, that some states will do one thing and some states will do another,\" Republican Representative French Hill told reporters. Trump also spoke to the Business Roundtable, an association of more than 200 corporate chief executives.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a {"uri": "2024-06-388643076", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "16:43:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T16:43:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T16:38:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/06/13/politics/trump-closed-door-meeting-house-gop/index.html", "title": "Inside Donald Trump's gripe-filled closed-door meeting with House GOP", "body": "Former President Donald Trump led House Republicans through a gripe-filled closed-door meeting on Capitol Hill on Thursday, airing grievances about his legal and electoral challenges, attacking his critics in the room, and only briefing addressing policy matters like abortion and taxes, according to multiple GOP lawmakers in the room.\n\nIn his first time returning to the Capitol campus area since leaving office after the January 6, 2021, riot, the former president met with lawmakers for over an hour.\n\nIn between rants about Taylor Swift and former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Trump went after his detractors - those who have since lost their seats and some who were in the room - as he warned Republicans to not be afraid of the hot button issue of abortion.\n\nIn a sign that the former president is reveling in how the party has fallen in line behind him, Trump bragged that most of the 10 House Republicans who voted to impeach him were no longer in office and singled out one of the remaining two GOP lawmakers left: GOP Rep. David Valadao of California.\n\n\"I never loved him,\" Trump said of Valadao, according to a GOP member.\n\nAs a number of House Republicans find themselves in competitive primary races, the former president said he wanted to do tele-town halls, but acknowledged his help would not be welcomed by some, given that he had endorsed their primary opponents.\n\nTrump did not shy away from acknowledging the bad blood between House Speaker Mike Johnson and GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, who unsuccessfully tried to oust Johnson against Trump's wishes. The former president playfully asked Greene, a staunch ally of his who he strongly supports, to be nice to the speaker.\n\n\"He's always so sweet, recognizing me, and he said 'are you being nice to Speaker Johnson?' He was joking. And I said 'eh,'\" as she gestured with her hands. \"He said 'OK be nice to him' and I nodded my head,\" she added.\n\nJohnson, after the meeting, said the former president told him that he was doing \"a very good job\" and that he plans to be \"fully prepared\" to implement Trump's plans if he wins in November.\n\nThe former president's conviction also hung heavy over Thursday's meeting.\n\nTrump's allies on Capitol Hill immediately sprung into action following the guilty verdict -proposing to defund the Department of Justice and even shut down the government. House Republicans voted to hold Attorney General Merrick Garland in contempt of Congress on Wednesday. And one legislative proposal Republican leaders are now actively pursuing is a bill that would allow current and former presidents to move state-level cases to federal court. The legislation passed out of committee last September, but GOP leaders only started formally whipping the bill this week - on the eve of Trump's Capitol Hill visit and two weeks after his conviction.\n\nIn his meeting with GOP lawmakers, Trump called the Department of Justice \"dirty no good bastards,\" according to another source in the room.\n\nGOP Rep. Kevin Hern of Oklahoma said the former president expressed he was \"gravely concerned\" about the federal government being weaponized.\n\nIn a news conference after the meeting, House Majority Whip Tom Emmer said that the former president's felony convictions have only energized the party that will propel them to victory in November.\n\n\"Anybody who thought that this President was going to be down after the sham trial, after that crooked trial that we saw in New York, I think, again, it's only given him even more energy,\" Emmer said. \"And what he did for us upstairs just now is, he showed us that energy and he showed us that positive outlook, despite all the garbage they've been throwing at him with their lawfare and their nonsense.\"\n\nTrump tells GOP lawmakers to 'follow your own heart' on abortion\n\nTrump had a direct message for House Republicans on how to approach abortion leading into November, an issue Republicans have struggled to unify around in the wake of Roe v. Wade being overturned.\n\nJohnson relayed that Trump told the group to \"exercise your own conscience to talk about it, share your conviction, and do that in a way that makes sense to people. And I think he had made a good point.\"\n\nTrump, in a low voice, advised Republicans to not be afraid of the issue, according to sources in room, and claimed that Democrats are the extreme ones on the topic. He called on Republicans to follow their convictions but cautioned how they address the matter on the campaign trail and advocated for exceptions.\n\n\"He talked and pushed for exceptions for rape, life of the mother and incest. He talked about the way that we need to talk about it, quote correctly, his words, not mine,\" GOP Rep. Nancy Mace told CNN. \"And I really appreciated his comments as a woman, as a suburban mom.\"\n\nTrump also talked about how Roe v. Wade finally put the decision to the states as they always wanted, though he noted some of them made \"not so good\" decisions.\n\n\"But like Ronald Reagan, you have to have three choices: life of mother, rape and incest you have to do, but you have to follow your own heart,\" Trump said, according to a source in the room.\n\nTrump's message came as the Supreme Court rejected a lawsuit challenging the Food and Drug Administration's approach to regulating the abortion pill mifepristone with a ruling that will continue to allow the pills to be mailed to patients without an in-person doctor's visit.\n\nThe former president also ticked through a handful of other priorities, including his proposal to eliminate taxes on tips, building the southern border, and halting further aid for Ukraine, even though a number of lawmakers in his party support it.\n\nTrump off topic\n\nThere were a number of moments where the former president went off topic.\n\nAs Trump was ranting about crime rates and so-called election integrity issues, the former president called Milwaukee - where Republicans are holding their convention this summer - \"horrible,\" according to a source in the room.\n\nRep. Derrick Van Orden, a Wisconsin Republican who was in the room, made clear to CNN that Trump was \"specifically referring to crime in Milwaukee\" and not the city itself.\n\nIn one bizarre moment, Trump called Pelosi's daughter a \"wacko\" and then claimed her daughter once told him that he and the former House speaker would have had a \"great romance\" in another life, according to a lawmaker in the room..\n\nIn response to Trump's comments, one of Pelosi's daughters posted on X: \"speaking for all 4 Pelosi daughters -- this is a LIE. His deceitful, deranged obsession with our mother is yet another reason Donald Trump is unwell, unhinged and unfit to step foot anywhere near her -- or the White House.\"\n\nHe also questioned why popstar Taylor Swift would support President Joe Biden over him, whom he referred to as a \"dope.\"\n\n\"Why would she endorse this dope,\" Trump said, according to a member in the room. \"He doesn't know how to get off a stage.\"\n\nThe former president even said at one point of Hannibal Lecter: \"nNice guy ... he even had a friend over for dinner.\"\n\nAt the start of the meeting, House Republicans sang happy birthday to the former president, whose birthday is Friday, and presented him with the game ball and bat from the congressional baseball game that Republican won on Wednesday, according to a source in the room.", "source": {"uri": "cnn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNN"}, "authors": [{"uri": "annie_grayer@cnn.com", "name": "Annie Grayer", "type": "author", "isAgency": {"uri": "8175882789", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "11:06:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T11:06:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T11:06:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/senate/3040658/trump-faces-gop-boycotts-meeting-senate-republicans/", "title": "Trump faces boycotts ahead of Senate GOP meeting- Washington Examiner", "body": "There will be notable absences on Thursday when presumptive GOP presidential nominee Donald Trump meets with Senate Republicans in Washington, D.C., for the first time since leaving the White House.\n\nSome centrist Republican senators who oppose the former president told the Washington Examiner they plan to skip the meeting due to unspecified scheduling conflicts, much to the chagrin of GOP leaders who are billing the event as a chance to build party unity heading into the election.\n\nNotably, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) will attend despite his frosty relationship with the former president and no contact between the two since before the 2021 Capitol riot.\n\n\"I said three years ago, right after the Capitol was attacked, that I would support our nominee, regardless of who it was, including him,\" McConnell told reporters Wednesday. \"I've said earlier this year I support him. He's earned the nomination by the voters all across the country, and of course, I'll be at the meeting tomorrow.\"\n\nMcConnell endorsed Trump in March, a stunning reversal from previously blaming him for \"disgraceful\" acts on Jan. 6, 2021, and after Trump's attacks against the senator's wife, former Trump Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao, that have been panned as racist.\n\nSens. Susan Collins (R-ME) and Lisa Murkowski (R-AK) told the Washington Examiner they won't attend because of busy schedules. Sen. Mitt Romney (R-UT) said he won't either because he has a flight to catch.\n\n\"I've got a conflict,\" Murkowski said. \"We just got the invite [Monday]. I've got a pretty crazy week. I've just got a lot going on.\"\n\nSen. Bill Cassidy (R-LA) initially told the Washington Examiner he was undecided due to his schedule but later told reporters he was inclined to attend.\n\n\"I think he's going to be the next president,\" Cassidy said. \"You got to work with the next president.\"\n\nCollins, Murkowski, Cassidy, and Romney are the remaining of the seven GOP senators who voted to convict Trump of impeachment over the Capitol riot. The other three have since retired from Congress.\n\nApproached off the Senate floor by reporters, an aide accompanying Sen. Todd Young (R-IN), the former chairman of Senate Republicans' campaign arm under Trump, said the senator would not be answering any questions related to the former president.\n\nSen. Rand Paul (R-KY) said he will \"probably\" attend.\n\nThe invite to Trump was extended by Republican Conference Chairman John Barrasso (R-WY) to discuss the GOP's 2025 agenda.\n\n\"I believe it will be helpful to hear directly from President Trump about his plans for the summer and to also share our ideas for a strategic governing agenda in 2025,\" Barrasso wrote in an email invitation to GOP colleagues on Monday.\n\nTrump was already slated to be in town to meet with the Business Roundtable lobbying group. He'll meet with House Republicans at the Capitol Hill Club on Thursday morning before joining Senate Republicans at the National Republican Senatorial Committee later that afternoon.\n\nOther Senate Republicans were disappointed to hear there would be some GOP boycotts.\n\n\"I would hope that we'd all be unified for -- hopefully -- the next president of the United States because if we're not, we're going to get our ears beat off,\" Sen. Tommy Tuberville (R-AL) said.\n\n\"He's our nominee,\" Sen. Rick Scott (R-FL), one of three Republicans vying to be McConnell's successor as the next GOP leader, said. \"We got to win the White House. We got to win the Senate. We got to win the House.\"\n\nSens. John Cornyn (R-TX) and Minority Whip John Thune (R-SD) are also running to replace McConnell and emphasized party unity.\n\n\"[Trump's] team is coordinating with us on all the key Senate races,\" Thune said. \"I think it'll be just an attempt to make sure that we're united as we head into November.\"\n\nCornyn stressed that \"unity is helpful.\"\n\nDemocrats were eager to use the meeting as another opportunity to whack Republicans for their affinity to Trump.\n\n\"No other former president enjoys having their ass kissed more than Trump, so it's going to be a lot of that,\" Sen. John Fetterman (D-PA) said.\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER\n\nFetterman then motioned to Sen. J.D. Vance (R-OH), a potential vice presidential running mate to Trump, who exited a nearby elevator.", "source": {"uri": "washingtonexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Examiner"}, "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.ayradvertiser.com/news/national/24386835.donald-trump-returns-capitol-hill-whips-republican-legislators/", "title": "Donald Trump returns to Capitol Hill and whips up Republican legislators", "body": "He was embraced by Republican legislators who find themselves newly energised by his bid to retake the White House.\n\nDespite pending federal charges against Mr Trump for conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, and his recent guilty verdict in an unrelated hush money trial, the Republican former president arrived emboldened as the party's presumptive nominee.\n\nHe has successfully purged the Republican Party of critics, silenced most sceptics and enticed once-critical legislators aboard his MAGA-fuelled campaign.\n\nA packed room of House of Representatives Republicans sang Happy Birthday to Mr Trump in a private breakfast meeting at Republican Party campaign headquarters across the street from the Capitol.\n\nThe legislators gave him a baseball and bat from the annual congressional game.\n\nMr Trump bragged that even his telephone rallies for legislators could draw bigger crowds than mega-popstar Taylor Swift, who has yet to make any endorsement.\n\n\"There's tremendous unity in the Republican Party,\" Mr Trump said in brief remarks later at Senate Republican Party headquarters.\n\nMr Trump spent about an hour each with House and Senate Republicans delivering free-wheeling remarks, fielding questions and discussing issues - including Russia and immigration, tax cuts and other priorities for a potential second term.\n\nDuring the morning session, Mr Trump said he thinks House speaker Mike Johnson is doing a \"terrific job\", according to a Republican in the private breakfast meeting.\n\nMr Trump asked Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, the speaker's chief Republican critic, if she was being \"nice\" to Mr Johnson, another Republican said.\n\n\"President Trump brought an extraordinary amount of energy, excitement and enthusiasm this morning,\" Mr Johnson said afterwards, noting high fundraising tallies since the guilty verdict.\n\n\"We're feeling good.\"\n\nThe Republican speaker had demurred earlier over whether he has asked Mr Trump to respect the peaceful transfer of presidential power and commit to not doing another January 6.\n\nHe said: \"Of course he respects that, we all do, and we've all talked about it, ad nauseum.\"\n\nThursday afternoon offered the first encounter in years between Mr Trump and Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who once blamed Mr Trump for the \"disgraceful\" attack that he called an \"insurrection\" but now endorses the party's presumptive nominee.\n\nMr McConnell said Mr Trump received standing ovations from the senators and the two \"had a really positive meeting\".\n\nThe senator said: \"He and I got a chance to talk a little bit, shook hands a few times.\"\n\nMany potential priorities for a new White House administration are being formulated by a constellation of outside groups, including Project 2025, laying the groundwork for executive and legislative actions, though Mr Trump has made clear he has his own agenda.\n\nOn one major controversial issue, Mr Trump told legislators that abortion rules should be left to the states and said he supported exceptions for rape, incest and to save the life of the mother, legislators said.\n\n\"Anybody who thought that this president was going to be down after the sham trial, it's only giving him even more energy,\" said Representative Tom Emmer, the Republican Party whip.\n\n\"Donald Trump is crushing this election.\"\n\nBut Mr Trump's private meetings with House and Senate Republicans so close to the Capitol were infused with the symbolism of his return as the US president who threatened the American tradition of the peaceful transfer of power.\n\n\"It's frustrating,\" said former US Capitol Police officer Harry Dunn, who made his own unsuccessful run for Congress as a Maryland Democrat in the aftermath of January 6, the day when police engaged in hand-to-hand fighting to stop Trump supporters who stormed the building in an effort to overturn Joe Biden's election.\n\nMr Dunn spoke of the \"irony\" of Mr Trump returning to the area and legislators now embracing him.\n\n\"It just shows the lack of backbone they have when they're truly putting party and person over country,\" he said.\n\n\"And it's sad.\"\n\nMr Biden was overseas on Thursday attending a summit of the Group of Seven leading industrialised nations, but the president's {"uri": "2024-06-388212560", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "10:23:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T10:23:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T06:06:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/top-news/articles/2024-06-13/republicans-hope-for-unity-message-in-trump-visit-to-congress", "title": "Republicans Hope for Unity Message in Trump Visit to Congress", "body": "WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Republicans hope that a pair of visits from former President Donald Trump on Thursday will bring unity to their sometimes bitterly divided caucuses in the Senate and House of Representatives, as the party heads toward the Nov. 5 election.\n\nTrump is due to meet with House Republicans Thursday morning and have lunch with Senate Republicans, aiming to coordinate campaign strategies to deliver a \"trifecta\" of Republican control over the White House and both chambers of Congress.\n\nTrump and current Democratic President Joe Biden each enjoyed unified governments in their first two years in office, but saw their parties lose control of the House during midterm elections, which impeded their ability to pass legislation.\n\n\"The meeting will be forward-focused on how Republicans can work together to advance policies to save America, including protecting Social Security and Medicare, securing the southern border, and cutting taxes for hardworking families,\" a senior Trump campaign official said.\n\nThe Republican presidential candidate is also due to speak on Thursday to the Business Roundtable, a Washington, D.C.-based association of more than 200 corporate chief executives.\n\n\"Our ability to get a majority in the Senate is intrinsically linked to President Trump winning. So, we're like one team/one vision, and I think that'll be largely what we talk about,\" Republican Senator Thom Tillis told reporters.\n\nRepublicans hope to see Trump defeat Biden, extend their current razor-thin 218-213 majority in the House and take control of a Senate that Democrats currently lead 51-49.\n\nOLD GRIEVANCES\n\nBut the visit has also put a spotlight on longstanding tensions between Trump and members of Congress, including Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who has not spoken to the former president since he acknowledged Biden's election victory in December 2020. Trump's false claims that his defeat was the result of fraud inspired the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.\n\nDespite their differences, the Kentucky Republican emphasized his support for Trump's candidacy. \"I support him. He's earned the nomination by the voters all across the country. And of course, I'll be at the meeting,\" McConnell told reporters on Wednesday.\n\nOthers, including moderates such as Susan Collins, Lisa Murkowksi and Mitt Romney, will not attend, citing scheduling conflicts.\n\nHouse Speaker Mike Johnson met with Senate Republicans over lunch on Wednesday to talk about how a united Republican government could use a parliamentary vehicle called budget reconciliation to bypass Democratic objections in the Senate.\n\n\"We have big policy changes that we'd like to enact,\" Johnson told reporters afterward. \"So, we want to make the most use of that and be coordinated between the two chambers.\"\n\nA main focus for House and Senate Republicans will be making permanent tax cuts under Trump's 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act that will otherwise expire next year.\n\nLawmakers also expect to discuss their plans around spending for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 and how to handle the looming Jan. 1 deadline to raise or suspend the nation's debt ceiling. Brinkmanship around debt-ceiling deadlines has spooked financial markets in the past.\n\nHouse Republican centrists also hope Trump will persuade hardline conservatives who ousted former Speaker Kevin McCarthy in October, sought to oust Johnson last month and have blocked their own party's legislation over the past year, to get in line with the rest of the conference.\n\n\"The president has an opportunity to reaffirm to the members of our conference how important it is to stick together,\" said U.S. Representative Anthony D'Esposito. \"Our success will be depend on us sticking together as Republicans.\"\n\n(Reporting by David Morgan; Editing by Scott Malone and Lincoln Feast.)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-06-388497398", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "14:25:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T14:25:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T10:06:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/trump-arrives-on-capitol-hill-to-meet-with-republican-lawmakers/article_556129ff-a1d7-589b-aab8-a8bbe28330e5.html", "title": "Trump arrives on Capitol Hill to meet with Republican lawmakers", "body": "By David Morgan\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) -Donald Trump arrived on Capitol Hill on Thursday to meet with Republican lawmakers to build unity ahead of the Nov. 5 election, which could hand his party control of the White House and both chambers of Congress.\n\nTrump's motorcade pulled up to a side entrance of a Republican office building a block from the U.S. Capitol, avoiding a crowd of protesters out front.\n\nThe Republican presidential candidate is due to meet with Republicans in the House of Representatives in the morning and have lunch with Senate Republicans to coordinate campaign strategies.\n\nTrump and current Democratic President Joe Biden each enjoyed unified governments in their first two years in office, but saw their parties lose control of the House during midterm elections, which impeded their ability to pass legislation.\n\n\"The meeting will be forward-focused on how Republicans can work together to advance policies to save America, including protecting Social Security and Medicare, securing the southern border, and cutting taxes for hardworking families,\" a senior Trump campaign official said.\n\nThe Republican presidential candidate is also due to speak on Thursday to the Business Roundtable, a Washington, D.C.-based association of more than 200 corporate chief executives.\n\n\"Our ability to get a majority in the Senate is intrinsically linked to President Trump winning. So, we're like one team/one vision, and I think that'll be largely what we talk about,\" Republican Senator Thom Tillis told reporters.\n\nRepublicans hope to see Trump defeat Biden, extend their current razor-thin 218-213 majority in the House and take control of a Senate that Democrats currently lead 51-49.\n\nOLD GRIEVANCES\n\nBut the visit has also put a spotlight on longstanding tensions between Trump and members of Congress, including Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who has not spoken to the former president since he acknowledged Biden's election victory in December 2020. Trump's false claims that his defeat was the result of fraud inspired the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.\n\nDespite their differences, the Kentucky Republican emphasized his support for Trump's candidacy. \"I support him. He's earned the nomination by the voters all across the country. And of course, I'll be at the meeting,\" McConnell told reporters on Wednesday.\n\nOthers, including moderates such as Susan Collins, Lisa Murkowski and Mitt Romney, will not attend, citing scheduling conflicts.\n\nHouse Speaker Mike Johnson met with Senate Republicans over lunch on Wednesday to talk about how a united Republican government could use a parliamentary vehicle called budget reconciliation to bypass Democrats in the Senate.\n\n\"We have big policy changes that we'd like to enact,\" Johnson told reporters afterward. \"So, we want to make the most use of that and be coordinated between the two chambers.\"\n\nA main focus for House and Senate Republicans will be making permanent tax cuts under Trump's 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act that will otherwise expire next year.\n\nLawmakers also expect to discuss their spending plans for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 and how to handle the looming Jan. 1 deadline to raise or suspend the nation's debt ceiling. Brinkmanship around debt-ceiling deadlines has spooked financial markets in the past.\n\nRepublican centrists also hope Trump will persuade hardline conservatives to get in line after ousting former Speaker Kevin McCarthy in October, attempting to oust Johnson last month and repeatedly blocking their own party's legislation over the past year.\n\n\"The president has an opportunity to reaffirm to the members of our conference how important it is to stick together,\" said U.S. Representative Anthony D'Esposito. \"Our success will be depend on us sticking together as Republicans.\"\n\n(Reporting by David Morgan; Writing by Andy Sullivan; Editing by Scott Malone, Lincoln Feast and Nick Zieminski)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8175791753", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-13", "time": "10:12:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-13T10:12:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-13T10:11:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2981327-unity-in-the-ranks-trumps-mission-to-rally-republicans", "title": "Unity in the Ranks: Trump's Mission to Rally Republicans | Politics", "body": "Republicans are hopeful that visits from former President Donald Trump will unify their divided caucuses in the Senate and House. Trump's meetings aim to strategize for the upcoming Nov. 5 election, focusing on policies to protect Social Security, secure the border, and cut taxes, amid existing intra-party tensions.\n\nRepublicans hope that a pair of visits from former President Donald Trump on Thursday will bring unity to their sometimes bitterly divided caucuses in the Senate and House of Representatives, as the party heads toward the Nov. 5 election.\n\nTrump is due to meet with House Republicans Thursday morning and have lunch with Senate Republicans, aiming to coordinate campaign strategies to deliver a \"trifecta\" of Republican control over the White House and both chambers of Congress. Trump and current Democratic President Joe Biden each enjoyed unified governments in their first two years in office, but saw their parties lose control of the House during midterm elections, which impeded their ability to pass legislation.\n\n\"The meeting will be forward-focused on how Republicans can work together to advance policies to save America, including protecting Social Security and Medicare, securing the southern border, and cutting taxes for hardworking families,\" a senior Trump campaign official said. The Republican presidential candidate is also due to speak on Thursday to the Business Roundtable, a Washington, D.C.-based association of more than 200 corporate chief executives.\n\n\"Our ability to get a majority in the Senate is intrinsically linked to President Trump winning. So, we're like one team/one vision, and I think that'll be largely what we talk about,\" Republican Senator Thom Tillis told reporters. Republicans hope to see Trump defeat Biden, extend their current razor-thin 218-213 majority in the House and take control of a Senate that Democrats currently lead 51-49.\n\nOLD GRIEVANCES But the visit has also put a spotlight on longstanding tensions between Trump and members of Congress, including Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, who has not spoken to the former president since he acknowledged Biden's election victory in December 2020. Trump's false claims that his defeat was the result of fraud inspired the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.\n\nDespite their differences, the Kentucky Republican emphasized his support for Trump's candidacy. \"I support him. He's earned the nomination by the voters all across the country. And of course, I'll be at the meeting,\" McConnell told reporters on Wednesday. Others, including moderates such as Susan Collins, Lisa Murkowksi and Mitt Romney, will not attend, citing scheduling conflicts.\n\nHouse Speaker Mike Johnson met with Senate Republicans over lunch on Wednesday to talk about how a united Republican government could use a parliamentary vehicle called budget reconciliation to bypass Democratic objections in the Senate. \"We have big policy changes that we'd like to enact,\" Johnson told reporters afterward. \"So, we want to make the most use of that and be coordinated between the two chambers.\"\n\nA main focus for House and Senate Republicans will be making permanent tax cuts under Trump's 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act that will otherwise expire next year. Lawmakers also expect to discuss their plans around spending for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 and how to handle the looming Jan. 1 deadline to raise or suspend the nation's debt ceiling. Brinkmanship around debt-ceiling deadlines has spooked financial markets in the past.\n\nHouse Republican centrists also hope Trump will persuade hardline conservatives who ousted former Speaker Kevin McCarthy in October, sought to oust Johnson last month and have blocked their own party's legislation over the past year, to get in line with the rest of the conference. \"The president has an opportunity to reaffirm to the members of our conference how important it is to stick together,\" said U.S. Representative Anthony D'Esposito. \"Our success will be depend on us sticking together as Republicans.\"\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": The visit comes as lawmakers gear up for elections in the fall.\n\nThis was former President Trump's first visit to Capitol Hill since leaving office.\n\nIt comes as most polls show trump tied with President Joe Biden in the race for the White House.\n\n\"There's tremendous unity in the Republican party,\" said Trump.\n\nHe spoke behind closed doors with House and Senate Republicans about the upcoming election and legislative priorities, from immigration to tax policy.\n\n\"We're going to bring back common sense to the government,\" said Trump.\n\nEven though a New York jury convicted the former president, who still faces a number of other charges, congressional Republicans have embraced him as their presumptive nominee.\n\n\"We are 100 percent unified behind his candidacy,\" said Rep. Elise Stefanik (R-N.Y.).\n\nCongressional Democrats say the meeting comes as no surprise.\n\n\"House Republicans have capitulated and done the bidding of former president Trump every day for the past 18 months,\" said Rep.
